DIVISION 3. - BUILDING AND STANDARDS COMMISSION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Building and standards commission, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 54.033(e). 

Sec. 2-100. - Established. 
    There is hereby established a building and standards commission, to hear and determine cases concerning alleged violations of city ordinances, as authorized by Chapter 54, Subchapter C, Texas Local Government Code (V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 54.031 et seq.). 
(Code 1988, § 2-66; Ord. No. 1000, § 3, 4-9-1996) 
Sec. 2-101. - Membership. 
(a)  Appointment; composition. The members of the commission shall be nominated and appointed by the city council and the commission shall be composed of one five member panel with two alternate members who shall serve in the absence of one or more regular members at the request of the mayor or city manager. 
(b)  Terms of office; vacancies. Members shall be appointed for terms of two years. Vacancies shall be filled for an unexpired term in the manner in which original appointments are required to be made. 
(c)  Compensation. Members shall serve without any form of compensation. 
(Code 1988, § 2-67; Ord. No. 1000, § 3, 4-9-1996; Ord. No. 1154, § 1, 12-16-1998) 
Sec. 2-102. - Meetings. 
(a)  Chair; vice-chair. The chair of the commission, or in his or her absence the vice-chair, shall preside over all hearings and meetings. He or she shall determine all questions of order, procedure, and as to the reception of evidence. 
(b)  Proceedings. The commission shall establish rules and regulations for its own procedures consistent with state law, the Code of Ordinances and the city Charter. Hearings shall not be required to be conducted in accordance with the technical rules relating to evidence and testimony. All hearings before the commission are open to the public and all deliberations and decisions of the commission shall be made in a public meeting. 
(c)  Quorum. Four members of the commission shall constitute a quorum. 
(d)  Record of proceedings. The chief building official or his or her designee shall act as secretary for the commission and shall make a detailed record of its proceedings which shall set forth the reason for its decisions, the vote of each member participating therein, the absence of a member and any failure of a member to vote. 
(Code 1988, § 2-68; Ord. No. 1000, § 3, 4-9-1996) 
Sec. 2-103. - Commission decisions. 
    The decisions of the commission shall be determined by the concurring vote of four of the five members. Any member of the commission who did not hear the evidence during a hearing or who has a personal interest in the case shall not vote or take part in the decision. 
(Code 1988, § 2-69; Ord. No. 1000, § 3, 4-9-1996) 
Secs. 2-104-2-134. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT COMMITTEE 

Sec. 2-135. - Membership, terms and rules. 
    There is hereby created the community development committee to be composed of seven members to be appointed by the director of development services or his or her designee for a term of two years. Appointments shall be by place. Upon expiration of a member's term, or in cases of premature vacancies, the director of development services or his or her designee shall select and appoint a person to the board. The members of this board shall be subject to all requirements and provisions applicable to all board or committee members as may be established by the city council. 
(Code 1975, § 2-102; Code 1988, § 2-96; Ord. No. 955, § 2, 5-9-1995; Ord. No. 1055, § 1, 5-27-1997) 
Sec. 2-136. - Organization; terms; compensation; meetings. 
    At its first meeting of each year the board shall elect a chair and vice-chair who shall serve during the year. The director of development services or his or her designee shall provide a secretary to keep a permanent record of proceedings. The board shall comply with the Texas Open Meetings Law (V.T.C.A., Government Code ch. 551) and other laws of the state and the city. The board shall serve without any form of compensation; however, board members may be reimbursed for preapproved direct expenses subject to limitations within the budget of the city and the established procedures of the city for disbursing such fund. 
(Code 1975, § 2-103; Code 1988, § 2-97; Ord. No. 1055, § 1, 5-27-1997) 
Sec. 2-137. - Powers and duties. 
    The community development committee shall serve as a consulting and admonitory board to the city staff on matters pertaining to allocation of community development block grant and HOME program funds for the city. It shall be the duty of the community development committee to act in an advisory capacity, to study and recommend policies relating to the use of community development block grant and HOME program funds and other matters involving community development issues as may be referred to it by the city staff, including the following: 
(1)  Conduct public hearings to solicit citizen input on the use of community development block grant and HOME program funds and on the consolidated plan for community development. 
(2)  Assist staff in making recommendations of the city council on the specific allocation of community development block grant and HOME program funds. 
(3)  Assist staff in developing approaches to improve the living environment of the city low and moderate income residents and to eliminate blighting neighborhood conditions. 
(Code 1988, § 2-98; Ord. No. 1055, § 1, 5-27-1997) 
Secs. 2-138-2-157. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - COULTER AIRFIELD ADVISORY COMMITTEE 

Sec. 2-158. - Membership, terms and rules. 
(a)  The Coulter Airfield Advisory Committee shall be composed of seven members appointed by the city council. The members of the committee shall consist of six citizens of the city residing inside the incorporated limits of the city and one member residing within Brazos County. 
(b)  The committee members shall serve two-year staggered terms. Any vacancies on the committee shall be filled by the city council. 
(c)  At its first meeting of each year, the committee shall elect from its members a chair and vice-chair. The majority of the committee shall constitute a quorum. 
(d)  The committee shall adopt rules for the transaction of business and keep a record of these activities and minutes of all meetings. 
(Code 1975, § 2-104; Code 1988, § 2-111; Ord. No. 955, § 3, 5-9-1995; Ord. No. 1053, § 1, 5-27-1997; Ord. No. 1383, §§ 1, 2, 1-14-2003) 
Sec. 2-159. - Duties. 
    The committee is designated to function solely in an advisory capacity on the use and development of Coulter Airfield. The duties of the committee shall include: 
(1)  Help plan a long range aviation program and encourage public interest therein; 
(2)  Make from time-to-time such general studies of airport construction and operation as may be useful in keeping the airfield efficient and adequate for the needs of the city and of the air transportation industry; 
(3)  Make recommendations with respect to expansions, improvements, maintenance and operations to the city manager and/or his or her designee. 
(Code 1975, § 2-105; Code 1988, § 2-112; Ord. No. 1053, § 1, 5-27-1997; Ord. No. 1383, § 3, 1-14-2003) 
Secs. 2-160-2-186. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - BRYAN CEMETERIES ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 2-187. - Created; purpose. 
    The Bryan Cemeteries Advisory Board is hereby created to advise the city council on all matters pertaining to the aesthetics and operations of the municipal cemeteries. Specifically, the board shall assist the city council in the following duties: 
(1)  Participate in drafting the "Bryan Cemetery Guidelines" and hold public hearings on the issue. These guidelines will be codified in an ordinance adopted by the city council. The guidelines will set standards for the planning, development, maintenance of the cemeteries, including rules regarding the placement of monuments, plantings and other items placed on cemetery grounds. The board will also participate and advise the city council as to the efficacy of these guidelines, and make amendatory recommendations. 
(2)  Types of fees charged and amounts. 
(3)  Review all proposed gifts and endowments for the council, in accordance with chapter 22. 
(4)  Advise the city council on the uses of the funds dedicated to the cemeteries, as set forth in chapter 22. 
(Code 1988, § 2-126; Ord. No. 1387, § 1, 3-25-2003) 
Sec. 2-188. - Membership, qualifications, terms and rules. 
(a)  The board shall be composed of seven members all appointed by city council. 
(b)  Five of the seven members must be citizens of the city and two of the seven members must be property owners in any of the city owned cemeteries, regardless of his or her residency. In some instances, these qualifications may overlap. 
(c)  Members shall have two year staggered terms. Each member may serve up to three two-year terms. 
(d)  The board shall elect a chair and a vice-chair from its membership annually. 
(e)  Four members shall constitute a quorum. The city manager or his or her designee will serve as secretary for the board and shall be an ex officio member and shall not count towards a quorum. No action may be taken without a quorum present and voting. 
(f)  The board shall set its meeting schedule and shall prescribe its own rules of order. 
(g)  Members of the board shall comply with the terms of the attendance policy adopted by the city council. 
(h)  The board shall serve without compensation but shall be reimbursed expenses appropriate for conducting the duties of the board. 
(i)  The board shall be subject to the Texas Open Meetings Act (V.T.C.A., Government Code ch. 551) and the Texas Public Information Act (V.T.C.A., Government Code ch. 552) as applicable to city councils of home rule cities. 
(Code 1988, § 2-127; Ord. No. 1387, § 1, 3-25-2003) 
Secs. 2-189-2-214. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - EASTERWOOD FIELD JOINT AIRPORT ZONING BOARD 

Sec. 2-215. - Created; powers and duties. 
    Subject to like provisions being made by the city council of the City of College Station, Texas, the commissioner's court of Brazos County, Texas, and the commissioners' court of Burleson County, Texas, by proper order, duly promulgated and entered on their minutes, and as authorized by the provisions of V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 241.001 et seq., there is hereby created a joint airport zoning board, to be known as the Easterwood Field Joint Airport Zoning Board, which shall have the powers and exercise the duties set forth in V.T.C.A., Local Government Code §§ 241.003 and 241.014. 
(Code 1975, § 2-109; Code 1988, § 2-141) 
Sec. 2-216. - Composition. 
    The Easterwood Field Joint Airport Zoning Board shall be composed of nine members, two to be appointed by the city council of the city, two to be appointed by the city council of the City of College Station, Texas, two members to be appointed by the commissioners' court of the county, and two members to be appointed by the commissioners' court of Burleson County, Texas. The ninth member shall be elected by a majority of the members so appointed and shall serve as chair of the Easterwood Field Joint Airport Zoning Board. 
(Code 1975, § 2-110; Code 1988, § 2-142) 
Secs. 2-217-2-240. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - BRYAN TEXAS UTILITIES BOARD 

Sec. 2-241. - Created; purpose. 
(a)  The utilities board is hereby created for the management and control of the electric utility of the city which shall also include the management and control of ancillary services. The utilities board is created subject to the conditions and restrictions set out in this division. As used in this division, the term "electric utility" of the city, shall mean all facilities necessary or appropriate for operation of an electric utility located within the service area of the electric utility of the city and ancillary services that are currently offered in the regulated market existing on the date of adoption of this division or in the future after any deregulation. 
(b)  The board shall manage and operate the electric utility in an efficient and businesslike manner in the best interests of the city, while being responsive to the needs of urban and rural customers. The board shall set the policies and goals for operation of the electric utility but shall delegate to the manager of the electric utility ("manager") the day to day operation of the electric utility and such other duties as the board may find appropriate. 
(c)  This division does not create a separate legal entity for ownership and operation of the electric utility, nor does this division transfer any assets or obligations of the electric utility. 
(d)  The board shall be named the utilities board. 
(Code 1988, § 2-156; Ord. No. 1281, § 1, 5-8-2001) 
Sec. 2-242. - Duties and limitations on the board. 
    The board shall have the authority and duty to: 
(1)  Set policy for, manage, operate and control the electric utility. 
(2)  Recommend the annual budget for the electric utility and any amendments thereto to the city council for its consideration and approval. Budgeted revenues will include revenues based on rates set by the council for services regulated by the council and revenues based on rates set by the board for competitive and other services. 
(3)  Engage in ratemaking and set rates, terms and conditions for competitive energy services. Competitive energy services include the following: 
a.  Wholesale sales of electricity and ancillary services; 
b.  Retail customer energy services which are capable of being provided on a competitive basis. Examples of retail customer energy services include, but are not limited to the marketing, sale, design, construction, installation, or retrofit, financing, operation and maintenance, warranty and repair of, or consulting with respect to electric and ancillary services. 
(4)  Set rates for miscellaneous services including extension, construction, or removal of facilities. 
(5)  Acquire and sell land in the name of the city for easements only, provided that the acquisition of land by eminent domain shall first be specifically authorized by the council. 
(6)  Designation of representatives to serve on the TMPA board shall be done by the city council; and all contracts between the City of Bryan and TMPA or TMPA member cities must be approved by city council. 
(7)  Determine the method and procedures used to purchase goods and services that provide the best value for the electric utility, as required by section 6 of the city Charter. Subject to the limitations of the preceding sentence and the further limitations set forth in the approved annual budget for utilities, the board is specifically granted the authority set forth in V.C.T.A., Local Government Code § 252.022(c) to adopt a resolution that sets forth the procurement procedures for purchases by the various divisions of utilities and the public purpose to be achieved by those procedures. 
(8)  Have primary responsibility to assure that all covenants and conditions contained in any bond or other debt instrument or agreement regarding the electric utility are promptly and fully performed by the electric utility. 
(9)  Authorize the manager to purchase equipment and services, provide for operation of the electric utility, perform long range and strategic planning for operation and expansion of the electric utility, subject to the policies and goals and the approved budget. The board may direct the manager to provide the board with periodic reports. 
(Code 1988, § 2-157; Ord. No. 1281, § 1, 5-8-2001; Ord. No. 1955, §§ 1-3, 4-25-2012) 
Sec. 2-243. - Powers retained by the city council. 
(a)  The council shall have the following authority and duties relating to the electric utility: 
(1)  Determine the amount of funds, if any, which may be transferred from the electric utility operating fund to the general fund for the city subject to the limitations of the city Charter. 
(2)  Determine whether to adopt customer choice, as defined in applicable laws and regulations, and if so adopted, determine the amount of stranded investment and any competition transition charge. 
(3)  Set rates for retail sales of electricity, distribution (wires) service and metering of electricity until such time as the council shall determine to adopt customer choice. Upon adoption of customer choice, setting the rates for retail sales of electricity, distribution (wires) service and metering of electricity shall come within the authority of the board. 
(4)  Issue and refund bonds and other debt instruments. 
(5)  Take property by eminent domain. 
(6)  Approve the annual budget of the electric utility and any amendments thereto. 
(7)  All other powers not specifically delegated to the board by this division are retained by the council. 
(b)  The board shall make recommendations to the council prior to the council taking action regarding these matters and the council shall make the final determination. The board and the manager shall carry out the final decisions of the council. 
(Code 1988, § 2-158; Ord. No. 1281, § 1, 5-8-2001) 
Sec. 2-244. - Membership of the board. 
    The board shall be composed of seven voting members. 
(1)  The seven members shall occupy seven positions with the following qualifications: 
a.  Position 1. A person who is a residential customer of the city. 
b.  Position 2. A person who is a commercial customer or employed by a commercial customer of the city. 
c.  Positions 3 and 4. Persons who have experience and expertise in the field of marketing, finance, law, or engineering. 
d.  Positions 5, 6, and 7. Persons who have experience in electric generation, transmission or distribution. 
(2)  All of the members of the board shall be qualified voters within the State of Texas and residents of the Bryan Texas Utilities electric utility service area, Brazos County or have a commercial account with Bryan Texas Utilities. 
(3)  Each of the members of the board shall be appointed by the council after a candidate is recommended by the board. If the council does not agree with the candidate recommended by the board, the board shall submit a new candidate to the council. All appointments shall be for staggered terms of three years. Council shall appoint persons meeting the above qualifications to fill vacancies. 
(4)  The mayor or a council member appointee of the mayor shall serve as an ex officio non-voting member of the board. 
(5)  A former member of a City of Bryan city council, board, or commission may be appointed by the city council to serve as an ex officio non-voting member of the Bryan Texas Utilities Board for the purpose of serving on the Texas Public Power Association (TPPA) and/or American Public Power Association (APPA) legislative affairs committee(s) when no active or regular BTU board member wishes to serve in that capacity. 
(6)  The council shall designate a member to serve as chairperson to serve for one year and may reappoint or remove the chair person from such service at any time. 
(7)  The board may elect such other officers as it deems necessary. 
(8)  The board shall adopt bylaws setting meetings, which must be at least monthly, requirements for attendance at meetings, rules of procedure and such other matters as deemed appropriate by the board. No action may be taken by the board without at least four members present and voting. 
(9)  The board shall be subject to the Texas Open Meetings and Texas Public Information Act as applicable to city councils of home rule cities. 
(10)  The board shall serve without compensation but shall be reimbursed expenses appropriate for conducting the duties of the board. 
(11)  The members of the board shall be indemnified and held harmless from liability incurred in the performance of their duties provided such indemnity and hold harmless expenses shall come only from revenues of the electric utility. The city attorney or other counsel appointed by the board shall advise and represent the board, as appropriate. 
(Code 1988, § 2-159; Ord. No. 1281, § 1, 5-8-2001; Ord. No. 1291, § 1, 6-26-2001; Ord. No. 1484, § 1, 7-27-2004; Ord. No. 1866, § 1, 4-27-2010; Ord. No. 2207 , § 1, 3-29-2017) 
Sec. 2-245. - Goals and objectives. 
    The council shall determine goals and objectives for the electric utility. These goals and objectives shall guide the board in the performance of its duties. The council shall review these goals and objectives at intervals of no more than six months and shall consider, amend as appropriate and adopt goals and objectives on a yearly basis. 
(Code 1988, § 2-160; Ord. No. 1281, § 1, 5-8-2001) 
Sec. 2-246. - Reports. 
    The board shall keep the council informed of the status and future plans for the electric utility. The board shall report at least quarterly to the council regarding these matters and shall prepare a detailed annual report, including recommendations for future direction of the electric utility. The board shall have the financial statements of the electric utility audited on an annual basis. When completed, the audits shall be public documents. 
(Code 1988, § 2-161; Ord. No. 1281, § 1, 5-8-2001) 
Sec. 2-247. - Budget and transfer of funds. 
    After approval of the budget by the council, the board shall cause the electric utility to be operated within the provisions of the budget, subject to amendments approved by the council. Subject to limits imposed by the city Charter, the board shall periodically recommend the amount of funds, if any, which may be transferred from the electric utility operating fund to the general fund for the city. The final determination on the transfer of such funds shall be made by the council, considering the recommendations of the board and the fiscal soundness of the electric utility. All recommendations for the transfer of funds from the electric utility accounts or recommendations against the transfer of such funds shall be accompanied by such financial reporting and analysis as the board deems necessary to support its recommendation to the council. 
(Code 1988, § 2-162; Ord. No. 1281, § 1, 5-8-2001) 
Sec. 2-248. - Dispute resolution and removal of the board or board members. 
(a)  In the event of a conflict between the council and the board, the board may be removed by the council and new board members may be appointed by the council. In addition, a board member may be removed by the council for cause which shall be stated in the removal resolution of the council. Prior to removal of the entire board, the council shall give written notice to the board of the nature of the conflict and the proposed remedy. The dispute shall be resolved to the satisfaction of the council within 45 days after receipt of the notice by the board or the council shall have the right to remove the board. During the 45-day period, the city manager for the city shall make a recommendation as to the resolution of the conflict and this recommendation shall be considered by the council and the board. 
(b)  If during the 45-day period, it appears to either the board or the council that resolution of the conflict may not be accomplished, either the board or the council may request agreement by the other of the appointment of a mediator to facilitate resolution of the conflict. The expenses of mediation shall be paid jointly by the board and the council. 
(c)  The processes for removal of the board and individual board members set forth in this section are not intended to create any expectation of continued service on the board for the duration of a member's term. The council retains the right to remove a board member or the entire board at the council's will and pleasure. The council retains the further right to repeal or amend any provision of this division at any time. 
(Code 1988, § 2-163; Ord. No. 1281, § 1, 5-8-2001) 
Sec. 2-249. - Consideration of customers and taxpayers of the city. 
    The board shall provide a process whereby it shall receive and respond to input from customers and city taxpayers so that the electric utility will be operated in a manner consistent with the interests of the customers and city taxpayers. 
(Code 1988, § 2-164; Ord. No. 1281, § 1, 5-8-2001) 
Secs. 2-250-2-276. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - INDUSTRIAL WASTE HEARING BOARD 

Sec. 2-277. - Appointment, composition, etc. 
(a)  An industrial waste hearing board shall be appointed by the city council as needed for arbitration of differences between the operations manager of the municipal services division and sewer users on matters concerning interpretation and execution of the provisions of section 122-149 et seq., by the operations manager of the municipal services division. 
(b)  The industrial waste hearing board shall have five members consisting of: 
(1)  A registered professional engineer; 
(2)  A practicing sanitary engineer; 
(3)  A representative of industry or manufacturing enterprise; 
(4)  An attorney; 
(5)  A representative selected at large, for his or her interest in accomplishing the objectives of section 122-149 et seq. 
(c)  The industrial waste hearing board shall set a hearing date and give written notice to the sewer user not less than 30 days after the sewer user files a notice of appeal in writing with the director of public works. 
(d)  The decision of the industrial waste hearing board must be in writing and indicate the vote upon such decision. Each decision must be properly filed in the office of the operations manager of municipal services and must be open to public inspection; a certified copy must be sent by mail or otherwise to the appellant. 
(e)  Within ten days from the date the industrial waste hearing board issues its decision, the appellant may file with the secretary a written application for appeal to the city council, stating his or her objections to the industrial waste hearing board's decision and requesting a hearing. A hearing date shall be set and notice given to the person whose signature appears on said application. At said hearing the appellant shall present testimony, evidence or argument in support of his or her objections to the findings and decision of the industrial waste hearing board and the hearing board will defend the same. The city council shall either reject, modify or uphold the industrial waste hearing board decision. 
(Code 1975, § 2-114; Code 1988, § 2-171) 
Secs. 2-278-2-302. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 10. - BRYAN-COLLEGE STATION PUBLIC LIBRARY SYSTEM BOARD 

Sec. 2-303. - Established; membership. 
(a)  There is hereby created the Bryan-College Station Public Library System Board to act as an advisory board to the city councils of each city. The board is to be composed of eight members. Four members from the city are to be appointed by the community librarian and four members from the City of College Station are to be appointed by the College Station City Council. Appointments shall be by place. 
(b)  Each board member's term shall be for two-year staggered terms to provide for continuity within the advisory board. The members of this board shall be subject to all requirements and provisions applicable to all board or committee members as may be established by the city council. 
(Code 1975, § 2-97; Code 1988, § 2-186; Ord. No. 580, § 1, 5-27-1985; Ord. No. 955, § 4, 5-9-1995; Ord. No. 1052, § 1, 5-27-1997) 
Sec. 2-304. - Library organization; compensation; meetings. 
(a)  At its first meeting of each year the board shall elect a chair and vice-chair who shall serve during the year. The community librarian shall provide a secretary to keep a permanent record of proceedings. The board shall comply with the Texas Open Meetings Act (V.T.C.A., Government Code ch. 551) and other laws of the state and the Cities of Bryan and College Station. The board shall serve without any form of compensation; however, board members may be reimbursed for pre-approved direct expenses, subject to limitations within the budget of the Cities of Bryan and College Station and the established procedures for disbursing such funds. 
(b)  The board shall meet as required. 
(c)  The board shall adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations as it deems best to govern its actions. 
(d)  The presence of any five members at a meeting of the board shall constitute a quorum. 
(e)  The community librarian or his or her designee shall attend all board meetings. 
(Code 1975, § 2-98; Code 1988, § 2-187; Ord. No. 580, § 1, 5-27-1985; Ord. No. 1052, § 1, 5-27-1997) 
Sec. 2-305. - Powers and duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the Bryan-College Station Public Library System Board: 
(1)  To encourage the development of the public library system; 
(2)  To recommend to the city council policies and programs for the advancement of the libraries; 
(3)  To cooperate with all other public and private groups in advancing the best interests of the Bryan-College Station Public Library System; and 
(4)  To render to the city council all recommendations it considers advisable regarding the Bryan-College Station Public Library System. 
(Code 1975, § 2-99; Code 1988, § 2-188; Ord. No. 580, § 1, 5-27-1985; Ord. No. 1052, § 1, 5-27-1997) 
Secs. 2-306-2-328. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 11. - MUNICIPAL POWER AGENCY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal power agencies, V.T.C.A., Utilities Code § 163.051 et seq.; contents of concurrent ordinance creating agency, V.T.C.A., Utilities Code § 163.057. 

Sec. 2-329. - Established, appointment, etc. 
(a)  Established. The city council hereby establishes and creates a municipal power agency, without taxing power, and such agency shall: 
(1)  Be known as the "Texas Municipal Power Agency"; 
(2)  Have boundaries which include the territory within the corporate limits of the Cities of Bryan, Denton, Garland and Greenville; and 
(3)  Be governed by a board of directors consisting of eight persons, who shall serve by places. 
(b)  Terms. The initial term of office of the director (calculated from the date of the passage of this section) and the governing body of the particular public entity who may appoint such director to fill each place, shall be as follows: 
Place 
Number Initial Term Appointing Public Entity 1 One year City of Bryan 2 Two years City of Bryan 3 One year City of Denton 4 Two years City of Denton 5 One year City of Garland 6 Two years City of Garland 7 One year City of Greenville 8 Two years City of Greenville  
Successors in office (for each place) shall be appointed by the governing body of the public entity appointing the initial director for such place for a term of two years. Vacancies in office in each place shall be filled for the unexpired term by the governing body of the public entity which originally filled such position. 
(c)  Re-creation of agency. In accordance with V.T.C.A., Utilities Code § 163.055, the right is reserved by this governing body to join with the other public entities specified in subsection (a) of this section to provide for the re-creation of such power agency by the addition and deletion, either or both, of a public entity so long as there is no impairment of obligation of any existing obligation of the agency. 
(Code 1975, § 2-123; Code 1988, § 2-201) 
Secs. 2-330-2-346. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 12. - PARKS AND RECREATION ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 2-347. - Membership, terms and rules. 
(a)  The parks and recreation advisory board of the city shall consist of nine members appointed by the city council. The members of the board shall be citizens of the city and shall serve without remuneration. 
(b)  Members of the board shall serve for two-year staggered terms with a maximum of three reappointments. With the exception of appointments to fill unexpired terms, all appointments shall be for two years. Members of the board shall comply with the terms of the policy for attendance as adopted by the city council. 
(c)  They shall elect one of their members as chair, and the majority shall constitute a quorum. The city manager or his or her designee shall serve as secretary to the board. 
(d)  The board shall prescribe its own rules of order and procedure and set its own monthly meeting time. 
(Code 1975, § 2-115; Code 1988, § 2-211; Ord. No. 585, § 1, 7-8-1985; Ord. No. 955, § 5, 5-9-1995) 
Sec. 2-348. - Duties. 
    The parks and recreation advisory board shall serve in an advisory capacity concerning park planning, development and maintenance; recreation programming; golf course operations and maintenance; and matters of policy pertaining to the delivery of leisure services to the citizens of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 2-116; Code 1988, § 2-112) 
Secs. 2-349-2-369. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 13. - PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-370. - Organization. 
(a)  The planning and zoning commission shall be composed of nine members, each of whom shall be appointed by the city council. The city council shall consider the qualifications of members based upon devotion to the best interest of the city and its citizens. The members shall serve for three-year staggered terms. An appointee may be reappointed one time. Vacancies occurring within an appointees' term shall be filled as provided by the Charter. The members of the commission shall serve without remuneration for their services as members of the commission, and shall hold no other municipal office. 
(b)  The planning and zoning commission shall select from its membership a chair and vice-chair and such other officers as it may deem necessary. Such election shall be for a period of one year. It shall adopt rules for the practical and efficient transaction of business, and shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings, and determinations, which record shall be a public record. At least one meeting per month shall be held, and additional meetings may be held from time-to-time upon the call of the chair. 
(Code 1988, § 2-226; Ord. No. 1092, § 1, 11-11-1997) 
Sec. 2-371. - Purpose, duties and functions. 
    The duties and functions of the planning and zoning commission include the following: 
(1)  To hold public hearings concerning planning and zoning matters including rezonings, conditional use permits, master plans, ordinance revisions, plats, replats, annexations, and street, alley and easement vacations and dedications; 
(2)  To review amendments to the comprehensive plan, the elements of which are outlined in V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 211.004; 
(3)  To recommend to and advise the city council on matters involving the comprehensive plan, zoning ordinance, and subdivision regulations; 
(4)  To review, approve, or deny all subdivision plats submitted, when required by chapter 110; 
(5)  To review annually capital improvement projects for consistency with the comprehensive plan; 
(6)  To establish ad hoc or standing committees for the purpose of making recommendations and/or advising and informing the commission as a whole; 
(7)  To keep abreast of new planning methods to focus on the needs and priorities of the community; 
(8)  To study planning items relating to zoning, general development, and future growth of the city; 
(9)  To review and make recommendations to the city council on all rezonings, ordinance revisions, annexations, easement releases, and right-of-way abandonments; 
(10)  To make an annual report to the city council, giving a statement of its work during the preceding year. In such annual report the commission shall also make recommendations for future planning and zoning projects to be undertaken; 
(11)  To propose special studies to the city council for approval; 
(12)  To hold public hearings and to review, approve, or deny requested variances from the standards set forth in the "lot area, height, and setback requirements" in chapter 62, excluding any encroachments into city rights-of-way or easements, which shall remain the exclusive jurisdiction of the city council; 
(13)  To hold public hearings and to review, approve, or deny requested variances from the standards set forth in the "wireless telecommunications facilities" in chapter 62. 
(Code 1988, § 2-227; Ord. No. 1092, § 1, 11-11-1997; Ord. No. 1286, § 1, 5-22-2001; Ord. No. 1318, § 1, 11-27-2001) 
Secs. 2-372-2-400. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 14. - BOARD OF ADJUSTMENT AND APPEALS 

Sec. 2-401. - Established; purpose. 
    The board of adjustments and appeals is hereby established for the purpose of hearing appeals concerning decisions and rulings by the chief building official of the city concerning building, electric, gas, mechanical and plumbing codes; suspending or revoking electrical licenses for the reasons and according to the procedures set forth in section 14-74; hearing appeals concerning decisions and rulings by the chief fire official of the city concerning the fire code; and variance requests to said codes. The board of adjustments and appeals shall serve as the board of appeals as authorized in the International Building Code. Any conflicts that may arise between the above referenced standard codes and the city Code shall be resolved in favor of the language contained in the city Code. 
(Code 1988, § 2-231; Ord. No. 677, § 1, 12-16-1987; Ord. No. 994, § 1, 4-9-1996; Ord. No. 1099, § 1, 12-16-1997) 
Sec. 2-402. - Membership. 
(a)  The board of adjustments and appeals shall be composed of seven members to be appointed by the city council as follows: 
(1)  An architect; 
(2)  An engineer; 
(3)  A member of the building construction trade; 
(4)  A member of the plumbing trade; 
(5)  A member of the mechanical trade; 
(6)  A master electrician; 
(7)  A journeyman electrician. 
(b)  The chief building official for the city shall be an ex officio member. The fire official for the city shall be an ex officio member. 
(Code 1988, § 2-232; Ord. No. 677, § 1, 12-16-1987; Ord. No. 1099, § 2, 12-16-1997) 
Sec. 2-403. - Terms of office. 
    The members of the board shall be appointed for staggered terms of three years provided however that the journeyman electrician member shall be appointed for a two-year term. 
(Code 1988, § 2-233; Ord. No. 677, § 1, 12-16-1987; Ord. No. 1099, § 3, 12-16-1997) 
Sec. 2-404. - Quorum. 
    Four of the members of the board shall constitute a quorum. In varying the application of any provisions of this Code or in modifying an order of the official, affirmative votes of the majority present shall be required. A board member shall not act in a case in which he or she has a personal interest. 
(Code 1988, § 2-234; Ord. No. 677, § 1, 12-16-1987; Ord. No. 1099, § 4, 12-16-1997) 
State Law reference- Board of adjustment, quorum, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 211.008(d). 
Sec. 2-405. - Secretary of board. 
    The chief building official or his or her designee shall act as secretary of the board of adjustments and appeals and shall make a detailed record of all its proceedings, which shall set forth the reasons for its decisions, the vote of each member, the absence of a member, and any failure of a member to vote. 
(Code 1988, § 2-235; Ord. No. 677, § 1, 12-16-1987) 
Sec. 2-406. - Procedures. 
    The board shall establish rules and regulations for its own procedure not inconsistent with the provisions of this Code. The board shall meet at the call of the chair or within 15 calendar days after the notice of appeal has been received. Appeals shall be presented in a form acceptable to the chief building official. The board shall, in every case, reach a decision without unreasonable or unnecessary delay. Each decision shall also include the reasons for the decision. If a decision reverses or modifies a refusal, order or disallowance of the chief building official or varies the application of any provision of the Code, the chief building official shall immediately take action in accordance with such decision. Every decision shall be promptly filed in writing in the office of the chief building official, and shall be open to public inspection. A copy shall be sent by mail or otherwise to the appellant and a copy shall be kept publicly posted in the office of the chief building official for two weeks after filing. Every decision of the board shall be final, subject however to such remedy as any aggrieved party might have at law or in equity. 
(Code 1988, § 2-236; Ord. No. 677, § 1, 12-16-1987; Ord. No. 1099, § 5, 12-16-1997) 
DIVISION 15. - HISTORIC LANDMARK COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-407. - Established; membership. 
(a)  There is hereby created a commission to be known as the historic landmark commission to be composed of seven members to be appointed by the city council for a term of three years with a maximum of one reappointment for a total of six continuous years. Appointments shall be by place. In the case of vacancies on the commission, the city council shall appoint a replacement to serve the remainder of that term. The unexpired term shall not apply when calculating service for the maximum service of six years. The members of this commission shall be subject to all requirements and provisions applicable to all board or committee members as may be established by the city council. The historic landmark commission shall be composed of the following members: 
(1)  A member of a local historic commission or historic preservation group; 
(2)  A registered architect residing within the county; 
(3)  A resident or property owner in the east side historic district; 
(4)  A resident or property owner in the downtown historic district; 
(5)  Three members at large. 
(b)  All members should be residents of the county, and reside within the city if possible. All members should have knowledge and experience in the architectural, cultural, social, economic, ethnic or political history of the city. No one business shall constitute a majority membership on the commission. 
(c)  Membership in historic preservation organizations is encouraged for all members of the commission and does not disqualify members from serving in another capacity required by the composition of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 1813, § 2, 6-9-2009) 
Sec. 2-408. - Purpose. 
(a)  The historic landmark commission shall thoroughly familiarize itself with buildings, structures, sites, districts, areas and lands within the city which may be eligible for designation as historic landmarks and shall: 
(1)  Establish criteria to be used in determining whether certain buildings, structures, sites, districts, areas, lands and other objects should be designated as historic landmarks; 
(2)  Review, consider and take action on certificates of appropriateness. 
(3)  Establish guidelines to be used in determination of whether to grant or deny certificates of appropriateness; 
(4)  Formulate suggestions for private and public action which may involve various city departments in preservation of historic preservation overlay districts; 
(5)  Suggest sources of funds for preservation and restoration activities and acquisitions, to include federal sources, state sources, private and foundation sources, as well as municipal sources; 
(6)  Recommend to the proper agencies incentives designed to encourage historic preservation; 
(7)  Establish policies and procedures of the historic landmark commission; and 
(8)  A preservation plan shall be kept on file, to be reviewed annually. 
(b)  The historic landmark commission shall recommend to the city planning and zoning commission ordinances designating certain buildings, structures, sites, districts, areas and lands in the city as historic landmarks. The historic landmark commission shall hold a public hearing on all proposed ordinances and the owner of any land included in the proposed ordinance shall be given at least ten days' written notice of the public hearing. 
(Ord. No. 1813, § 2, 6-9-2009) 
Sec. 2-409. - Appointment of historic preservation officer. 
    The city manager or a designee shall appoint a qualified city staff person to serve as historic preservation officer. This officer shall serve as the liaison to the historic landmark commission and shall advise the commission on matters submitted to it and provide information on historic preservation to the public. 
    The officer is responsible for coordinating the city's preservation activities with those of state and federal agencies and with local, state, and national nonprofit preservation organizations. 
(Ord. No. 1813, § 2, 6-9-2009) 
DIVISION 16. - DESIGN REVIEW BOARD 

Sec. 2-410. - Membership. 
    The design review board is composed of five members appointed by city council for a three year term with a maximum of one reappointment for a total of six continuous years. In the case of vacancies on the board, the city council shall appoint a replacement to serve the remainder of that term. The unexpired term does not apply when calculating service for the maximum service of six years. 
( Ord. No. 2074, § 2 , 11-18-2014) 
Sec. 2-411. - Qualifications. 
(a)  The design review board shall be composed of the following members: 
(1)  One to two registered architects; 
(2)  Two planning and zoning commission members; and 
(3)  One to two contractors, builders, or developers. 
(b)  All members should be residents of Brazos County, and reside within the City of Bryan if possible. All members must have knowledge of the architectural, cultural, social, economic, ethnic or political history of the city. No one business shall constitute a majority membership on the board. 
( Ord. No. 2074, § 2 , 11-18-2014) 
Sec. 2-412. - Duties and functions. 
(a)  Hold public hearings, hear appeals, authorize variances, and take other actions concerning design matters as authorized by ordinance; 
(b)  Make recommendations to and advise the city council on matters involving building design standards and building design guidelines; and 
(c)  Establish policies and procedures of the design review board. 
( Ord. No. 2074, § 2 , 11-18-2014) 
DIVISION 17. - AUDIT COMMITTEE 

Sec. 2-413. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created the audit committee as an advisory committee of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2289 , § 2, 8-14-2018) 
Sec. 2-414. - Purpose and duties. 
    The purpose of the audit committee is to assist the city council in fulfilling its financial oversight responsibilities. The audit committee shall have the following responsibilities: 
(a)  Advise the city council and management on the selection of the independent auditor. 
(b)  Monitor the integrity of the city's financial and compliance reporting process. 
(c)  Monitor the systems of internal controls regarding finance, accounting, and legal compliance. 
(d)  Monitor the performance of the city's independent auditors. 
(e)  Monitor the internal audit process. 
(f)  Provide a whistleblower mechanism for citizens and employees to report suspected fraudulent activities; conduct special investigations of suspected fraudulent activities. 
(g)  Provide an avenue of communication among the independent auditor, the city internal auditor (or appropriate party), management, and the city council. 
(h)  Review and provide recommendations on the city's financial and budgetary policies, reports, and procedures. 
(i)  Establish, review, and update periodically a Code of Ethics and Conduct for elected and appointed officials. 
(j)  Evaluate special projects for financial consequences, assess alternatives, and make appropriate recommendations at the request of the city manager or city council and perform any other activities consistent with this division, the city's Charter, and governing law, as the city council deems necessary or appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 2289 , § 2, 8-14-2018) 
Sec. 2-415. - Membership, qualifications, term of office. 
(a)  The audit committee shall be comprised of five members appointed by the Bryan City Council. Three members shall be sitting members of the city council and two members shall be representatives from the community. Community representatives must be registered voters of the City of Bryan, who, to the extent possible, shall be finance professionals such as accountants, certified public accountants, auditors, or shall have equivalent experience. 
(b)  All members of the audit committee shall have a basic understanding of finance and accounting and be able to read and understand fundamental financial statements. At least one member of the audit committee shall have accounting or related financial management expertise. 
(c)  Community representatives on the audit committee shall serve a term of two years. The community representative members' terms shall be determined by the city council, and any committee member serves at the will of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2289 , § 2, 8-14-2018) 
Sec. 2-416. - Authority. 
    The audit committee has the authority to conduct any investigation appropriate to fulfilling its responsibilities, and has direct access to the independent auditors, city internal auditor (or appropriate party), as well as anyone in the organization. The committee has unrestricted access to all information, including documents and personnel, and has the ability to recommend retention of special legal, accounting, or other consultants or experts it deems necessary in the performance of its duties. 
(Ord. No. 2289 , § 2, 8-14-2018) 
Sec. 2-417. - Meetings and procedures. 
(a)  The audit committee shall meet a minimum of four times annually, or more frequently as circumstances dictate. The committee should meet at least annually with management and the independent auditor to discuss matters the committee or one of the other parties believes should be discussed. 
(b)  A majority of the members of the audit committee shall constitute a quorum for the conduct of business. The members of the Audit Committee shall regularly attend meetings and shall serve without compensation except for reimbursement of authorized expenses attendant to the performance of their duties. 
(c)  The audit committee shall adopt bylaws establishing its own rules of procedure, subject to review and approval by the Bryan City Council. The audit committee shall regularly review and re-assess the adequacy of these bylaws and may make recommendations for modifications to the Bryan City Council. 
(d)  The audit committee meetings shall be open to the public with exceptions for closed meetings as provided by the Texas Open Meetings Act, Texas Government Code, Chapter 551. 
(Ord. No. 2289 , § 2, 8-14-2018) 
Secs. 2-418, 2-419. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 18. - BRYAN SENIOR ADVISORY COMMITTEE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2289 , § 3, adopted Aug. 14, 2018, redesignated the former Div. 17 as a new Div. 18 to read as herein set out. 

Sec. 2-420. - Created; purpose. 
    There is hereby created the Bryan Senior Advisory Committee to serve in advisory capacity concerning activities, events, or programs for senior citizens, as well as issues or concerns specifically impacting seniors. The senior advisory committee shall report to the parks and recreation advisory board. 
(Ord. No. 2093 , § 1, 4-28-2015) 
Sec. 2-421. - Membership; eligibility. 
(a)  Members of the committee must: 
(1)  Reside within the corporate limits of the city; 
(2)  Be at least 55 years of age or older; and 
(3)  Not have served more than two full consecutive terms on the committee. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided in this section, members are appointed for two-year staggered terms. Half the positions filled upon the committee's creation shall be for one-year terms and half shall be for two-year terms. The determination of which members shall serve initial terms of one year and initial terms of two years shall be determined by a drawing at the first meeting of the senior advisory committee. 
(c)  The committee shall consist of at least six, but no more than 22 members, depending on the availability of eligible candidates. 
(d)  Members shall be appointed by the city council and shall report to the parks and recreation advisory board. Special consideration shall be given to ensure parity of representation from existing groups geared towards seniors as well as ensuring a broad cross section of the community from all areas of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2093 , § 1, 4-28-2015; Ord. No. 2123, § 1 , 11-10-2015) 
Sec. 2-422. - Meetings; duties. 
(a)  A quorum of the committee is a majority of the positions currently filled. Meetings should be scheduled monthly at a time and location provided by the city manager. 
(b)  The committee may establish its own rules of procedure, subject to and in compliance with the city's charter, code of ordinances, and general policies established by the city council. Each year, the committee shall appoint a chair and vice chair. 
(c)  The committee shall provide recommendations and advice to the city council, through the parks and recreation advisory board, regarding issues concerning seniors, availability of activities for seniors, or any other topic within the purview of the committee. 
(Ord. No. 2093 , § 1, 4-28-2015) 
Secs. 2-423-2-452. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DEPARTMENTS, OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Charter reference- Administrative code, § 11; department of finance, § 12(a). 
State Law reference- Public offices and employees, V.T.C.A., Government Code ch. 601 et seq.; nepotism prohibited, V.T.C.A., Government Code ch. 573. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-453. - Authority and short title. 
    This article shall constitute the administrative code of the city, in accordance with section 11 of the Charter, and may be so cited. 
(Code 1975, § 2-1; Code 1988, § 2-246) 
Sec. 2-454. - Administrative organization. 
    The departments, offices and agencies of the city government, as set forth in the organization chart which is on file in the city secretary's office, and elsewhere in this article, are hereby created or continued in effect as the administrative organization of the city. The same shall have the functions, powers and duties customarily incident to such departments, offices and agencies, and as set forth in the Charter and this Code; provided, such organizational structure shall continue to be subject to such alterations, changes, additions, deletions and consolidations as authorized by the Charter. 
(Code 1975, § 2-2; Code 1988, § 2-247) 
Secs. 2-455-2-476. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Secs. 2-477-2-505. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - City Attorney[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Charter reference- Appointment, § 8(a). 

Sec. 2-506. - Legal department. 
    The legal department of the city shall be headed by the city attorney, who shall be appointed and hold office as provided in the Charter. 
(Code 1975, § 2-36; Code 1988, § 2-276) 
Charter reference- Appointment, § 8(a); qualifications and duties, § 8(d). 
Sec. 2-507. - Acting city attorney. 
    In case of the absence or disability of the city attorney for a period of greater than ten days, the city council may designate some qualified person to perform the duties of the office. The person designated shall have authority and it shall be his or her duty to perform the duties of the city attorney during such absence or disability of the city attorney. Such acting city attorney shall be removable peremptorily at the will of the city council. 
(Code 1988, § 2-277) 
Secs. 2-508-2-537. - Reserved. 
Subdivision III. - City Manager[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Charter reference- City manager, § 8(b); power to appoint employees of city, § 8(a). 

Sec. 2-538. - Appointment and term. 
    The administrative head of the city government for the city shall be the city manager, who shall be appointed by the city council, and whose term of office shall be as provided in the Charter. 
(Code 1975, § 2-26; Code 1988, § 2-291) 
Charter reference- Similar provisions, § 8(b). 
Sec. 2-539. - Acting city manager. 
    In case of the absence or disability of the city manager for a period of greater than ten days, the city council may designate some qualified person to perform the duties of the office, and the person so designated shall have authority and it shall be his or her duty to perform the duties of the city manager during such absence or disability of the city manager, and such acting city manager shall be removable peremptorily at the will of the city council. 
(Code 1975, § 2-27; Code 1988, § 2-292) 
Sec. 2-540. - Duties generally. 
    In addition to the duties imposed upon the city manager under the city Charter, the powers and duties of the city manager shall be as follows: 
(1)  To devote his or her working time and attention to the affairs of the city, and be responsible to the city council for the efficient administration of its affairs. 
(2)  To see that all laws and ordinances are enforced. 
(3)  With the advice of the city council, to appoint and remove all heads of departments, except those who are to be appointed by the city council as provided in the Charter. He or she shall have the power to appoint or remove all subordinate employees. 
(4)  To see that all terms and conditions imposed in favor of the city, or its inhabitants, in any public utility franchise are faithfully kept and performed and upon knowledge of any violation thereof to call the same to the attention of the city council. 
(5)  To act as budget officer and as such to prepare and submit to the city council, prior to the beginning of each fiscal year, a budget of proposed expenditures for the ensuing year, showing in as much detail as practicable the estimated amounts required by months for the efficient operation of each department of the city and the reasons for such estimated expenditures. 
(6)  The city manager, in addition to the duties imposed by subsection (5) of this section, shall make and file a budget as required by state law and the Charter of the city. 
(7)  To recommend to the city council the salaries to be paid each appointive officer and subordinate employee of the city. 
(8)  To recommend to the city council, in writing, from time-to-time, for adoption, such measures as he or she may deem necessary or expedient. 
(9)  In the absence or disability of any department head, to perform the duties of such department head. 
(10)  To do and perform such other duties as may be prescribed by ordinance or resolution or by the city council. 
(11)  Subject to his or her first having obtained the approval of the city council, the city manager shall have the authority to establish such other departments and divisions as he or she may deem necessary for the efficient administration of the affairs of the city where same are not expressly created in the Charter or by ordinance. 
(Code 1975, § 2-28; Code 1988, § 2-293) 
Charter reference- City council establishes departments by ordinance, § 8(b). 
Secs. 2-541-2-558. - Reserved. 
Subdivision IV. - City Secretary[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Charter reference- Appointment of city secretary, duties, § 8(c); clerk of municipal court, § 15. 

Sec. 2-559. - Appointment and term. 
    The city secretary shall be appointed and hold office as provided in the Charter. 
(Code 1975, § 2-32; Code 1988, § 2-306) 
Sec. 2-560. - Acting city secretary. 
    In case of the absence or disability of the city secretary for a period of greater than ten days, the city council shall designate some qualified person to perform the duties of the office, and the person so designated shall have authority, and it shall be his or her duty, to perform the duties of the city secretary during such absence or disability of the city secretary, and such acting city secretary shall be removable peremptorily at the will of the city council. 
(Code 1975, § 2-33; Code 1988, § 2-307) 
Sec. 2-561. - Duties generally. 
    In addition to those provided in the Charter, the city secretary shall have the following duties: 
(1)  Attend every meeting of the city council and keep accurate minutes of the proceedings in a book to be provided for that purpose; 
(2)  Engross and enroll all laws, resolutions and ordinances of the city council; 
(3)  Keep the corporate seal; 
(4)  Take charge of and preserve and keep all of the books, records, papers, ordinances, documents and files of the city and be their legal custodian; 
(5)  Countersign all commissions issued to the city officers and to keep a record and register thereof; 
(6)  Make all notices required under any regulation or ordinance of the city; 
(7)  Keep on file, properly indexed for ready reference, all ordinance records, minutes and records, contracts, leases and agreements; 
(8)  Keep the regular form deeds to be signed by the mayor conveying cemetery lots to the proper purchasers, and keep an accurate record of all lots owned and unsold with the approved selling price of each; and 
(9)  Post notice of all meetings as directed by the mayor or city manager and in accordance with state law. 
(Code 1975, § 2-34; Code 1988, § 2-308) 
Sec. 2-562. - Duties as to personnel. 
    The city secretary shall submit the names of such deputies and assistants as authorized by the city council to the city manager for his or her approval, and the city manager may refuse to approve same. Cause must be shown to the council why approval is withheld, and in the event that the council concurs with the city manager, the secretary is to nominate others. Any deputy so appointed may do and perform all duties as may now or hereafter be required of the city secretary. 
(Code 1975, § 2-35; Code 1988, § 2-309) 
Secs. 2-563-2-587. - Reserved. 
Subdivision V. - Health Authority 

Sec. 2-588. - Officer of county health unit. 
    The health authority of the city shall be the director or other duly designated officer of the county health unit. Reference in this Code to the health authority, director of health, department of health, city-county health unit and county health unit shall be construed to refer to the officer or agency of the county charged with the responsibility of enforcing health laws, ordinances, rules and regulations. 
(Code 1975, § 2-38; Code 1988, § 2-321) 
Secs. 2-589-2-609. - Reserved. 
Subdivision VI. - Municipal Judge[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Charter reference- Municipal court, § 15. 
State Law reference- Municipal judge, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 29.004. 

Sec. 2-610. - Established, presiding officer. 
    The judicial powers of the city shall be vested in a court to be known as the "Municipal Court of Record of the City of Bryan, Texas" as provided by the Charter. The court shall be presided over by the municipal judge, who shall be appointed and hold office as provided by the Charter. 
(Code 1975, § 2-37; Code 1988, § 2-336; Ord. No. 1941, § 1, 12-13-2011) 
Charter reference- Similar provisions, § 15. 
Secs. 2-611-2-638. - Reserved. 
Subdivision VII. - City Marshal 

Sec. 2-639. - Office created, appointment, number, qualifications. 
    There is hereby created the office of the city marshal, to be filled by qualified persons, appointed as provided by the city Charter, and administered by the city secretary, who is designated as municipal court clerk by the city Charter, through the municipal court administrator. There may be more than one city marshal appointed and employed at any time. The city marshal shall meet all qualifications necessary to be certified as a peace officer by the Texas Commission on Law Enforcement Officer Standards and Education. 
(Code 1988, § 2-337; Ord. No. 903, § 1, 2-8-1994) 
Sec. 2-640. - Duties. 
    The city marshals, acting under the direction of the city secretary through the municipal court administrator, shall perform the following duties: 
(1)  Execute warrants of arrest, subpoenas and other legal process issuing out of the municipal court; 
(2)  Execute other warrants of arrest, subpoenas and legal process as determined by the city secretary through the municipal court administrator; and 
(3)  Other duties as assigned, such duties not to be in conflict with provisions of this section and section 2-339. 
(Code 1988, § 2-338; Ord. No. 903, § 1, 2-8-1994) 
Sec. 2-641. - Authority; eligibility for pension. 
(a)  The city marshals shall serve as peace officers and have full police authority in the exercise of their assigned duties; however, they shall not be assigned the duties that are assigned to the police department of the city. 
(b)  The city marshals are not members of the police department of the city, and shall not be covered under the municipal civil service provisions of V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 143; however, they are eligible for membership in the Texas Municipal Retirement System. The city marshals are paid law enforcement officers for the purpose of qualifying for survivor's assistance benefits under the provisions of V.T.C.A., Government Code ch. 615. 
(Code 1988, § 2-339; Ord. No. 903, § 1, 2-8-1994) 
Sec. 2-642. - Oath of office. 
    Each city marshal shall be required to take an oath of office before entering upon the discharge of his or her duties. The oath shall be subscribed by the person taking it and shall be filed and preserved in the office of the city secretary. The form of oath shall be the same as required for members of the city council. 
(Code 1988, § 2-340; Ord. No. 903, § 1, 2-8-1994) 
Secs. 2-643, 2-644. - Reserved. 
Subdivision VIII. - City Internal Auditor 

Sec. 2-645. - Appointment and term. 
    The city internal auditor shall be appointed and hold office as provided in the Charter. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § 1, 11-24-2009) 
Sec. 2-646. - Duties generally. 
    The city internal auditor shall: 
(1)  Examine city operations to identify opportunities to reduce costs, increase efficiency, quality, and effectiveness, or otherwise improve management of a city function, program, service or policy; 
(2)  Communicate directly with the audit committee and the council, facilitate audit committee meetings, and regularly meet with council; 
(3)  Establish audit policies and procedures consistent with governmental auditing standards established by applicable law and regulations; 
(4)  Conduct performance or financial related audits, investigations, and other audit work to ensure that all financial and other reports being provided disclose fairly, accurately, and fully all information required by law; 
(5)  Conduct performance or financial related audits, investigations, and other audit work to ensure that city management is complying with applicable, laws, regulations, policies, and procedures; 
(6)  Identify, assess, and evaluate the city's risk areas, make appropriate recommendations for improved internal controls and accounting procedures, and research and adopt industry best practices where appropriate; and 
(7)  Operate a Fraud Hotline that investigates allegations of fraud, waste, or abuse of governmental resources through any communication means. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § 1, 11-24-2009) 
Secs. 2-647-2-672. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DEPARTMENTS 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 2-673. - Promulgation of rules and regulations. 
    The city manager may prescribe such general rules and regulations as he or she may deem necessary or expedient for the general conduct of the government of the city. The head of each department shall, in like manner, prescribe such rules and regulations as he or she may deem necessary and expedient for the proper conduct of his or her department, not inconsistent with the general rules and regulations prescribed by the city manager. 
(Code 1975, § 2-46; Code 1988, § 2-351) 
Sec. 2-674. - Duties of department heads and subordinate officers generally. 
    Each department head and subordinate officer shall perform all duties required of his or her office by state law and the Charter and ordinances of the city, and such other duties not in conflict therewith as may be required by the city manager. 
(Code 1975, § 2-47; Code 1988, § 2-352) 
Sec. 2-675. - Delegation of duties. 
    The city manager may direct any department, division, or bureau to perform the work for any other department, division, or bureau, or may delegate to any officer or employee any duties other than those established for the department, division, or bureau to which he or she may be assigned. 
(Code 1975, § 2-48; Code 1988, § 2-353) 
Sec. 2-676. - Transfer of personnel. 
    In order to expedite the work of any department or to adequately administer an increase in the duties which may devolve on any department, or to cope with periodical or seasonal changes, the city manager is empowered to transfer employees temporarily from one department to perform similar duties in another department; likewise, each department head shall have power to transfer employees from one division within his or her department to another division. 
(Code 1975, § 2-49; Code 1988, § 2-354) 
Sec. 2-677. - General responsibilities of department heads. 
    The heads of administrative departments shall be immediately responsible to the city manager for the effective administration of their respective departments and all activities assigned thereto. The city manager may set aside any action taken by a department head and may supersede him or her in the functions of his or her office. All department heads shall keep informed as to the latest practices in their particular field and shall inaugurate, with the approval of the city manager, such new practices as appear to be of benefit to the service and to the public. 
(Code 1975, § 2-50; Code 1988, § 2-355) 
Sec. 2-678. - Preservation of public records. 
    Each department head shall be held responsible for the preservation of all public records under his or her jurisdiction and shall provide a system of filing and indexing the same. No public records, reports, correspondence or other data relative to the business of any department shall be destroyed or removed permanently from the files without knowledge and approval of the city manager, city attorney or city secretary. 
(Code 1988, § 2-357) 
Sec. 2-679. - Cooperation between departments. 
    It shall be the duty of every department, subject to such rules as the city manager may prescribe, to furnish to any other department such service, labor, and materials as may be requisitioned by the head of such department, and as its own facilities permit, through the same procedure and subject to the same audit and control as other expenditures are incurred. 
(Code 1975, § 2-53; Code 1988, § 2-358) 
Sec. 2-680. - Departmental authority over employees. 
    Each department head shall have authority to appoint and remove, subject to the personnel regulations formulated by the city manager, all subordinates under him or her. 
(Code 1975, § 2-54; Code 1988, § 2-359) 
Secs. 2-681-2-705. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Fire Services Division 

Sec. 2-706. - Organization; department head. 
    The fire services division shall be composed of a fire chief and such other officers and employees as shall be determined from time-to-time by the city manager, with the approval of the city council. 
(Code 1975, § 2-63; Code 1988, § 2-371) 
Secs. 2-707-2-725. - Reserved.
