Sec. 2-726. - Established; organization. 
    There is hereby established a building services division. The division shall be under the control of the planning department. 
(Code 1975, § 2-64; Code 1988, § 2-386) 
Secs. 2-727-2-770. - Reserved. 
Subdivision IV. - Development Services Division 

Sec. 2-771. - Created; department head. 
    There is created a development services division of the city, at the head of which shall be the manager of the development services division. 
(Code 1975, § 2-66; Code 1988, § 2-416) 
Sec. 2-772. - Duties. 
    In addition to other duties as prescribed by the Charter, ordinance or order, the operations manager of development services shall be custodian of and responsible for all maps, plans, profiles, field notes, and other records and memoranda belonging to the city pertaining to his or her office and the work thereof, all of which he or she shall keep in proper order and condition, with full indexes thereof, and shall turn the same over to his or her successor, who shall give him or her duplicate receipts therefor, one of which shall be filed with the city secretary. All maps, plans, profiles, field notes, estimates, and other memoranda or professional work done by him or her or under his or her direction or control during his or her term of office shall be the property of the city. He or she shall have charge of the planning, opening, construction, paving, maintenance, and repair of all streets, boulevards, alleys, sidewalks, and public ways. He or she shall be responsible for the operation of the sewage treatment plant, and shall be technically responsible for water distribution, sewer system, and the water production department, and shall work and cooperate with the city planning commission. He or she shall do and perform such other duties relating to his or her department as may be required of him or her by the city manager and by ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 2-69; Code 1988, § 2-446) 
Sec. 2-773. - Cooperation with other departments. 
    It shall be the duty of the operations manager of development services, subject to the approval of the city manager, to furnish to any other department of the city such services, labor, and materials as may be requisitioned by the head of such department. The expense of such service, labor, and materials shall be charged to the department so furnished at actual cost. 
(Code 1975, § 2-70; Code 1988, § 2-447) 
Secs. 2-774-2-799. - Reserved. 
Subdivision V. - Police Services Division 

Sec. 2-800. - Organization; division head. 
    The police services division shall be under the direction of a chief of police, who shall be appointed as provided in the Charter and who, subject to the supervision of the city manager or his or her designee and to such rules, regulations and orders prescribed by the city manager not inconsistent with the Charter and ordinances of the city, shall have immediate control and direction of such department. He or she shall be vested with the disciplinary power of the department. 
(Code 1975, § 2-61; Code 1988, § 2-431) 
Sec. 2-801. - Duties. 
(a)  The police department shall be charged with the preservation of the peace and order of the city, the protection of all persons and property, and the enforcement of all criminal ordinances and all criminal laws of the city, the state, and the United States. The department shall suppress all riots, disturbances and breaches of the peace within the city; pursue and arrest any person fleeing from justice in any part of the state, or of the United States; arrest all persons found in the act of committing a breach of laws or ordinances, and take the offenders forthwith before the proper court to be dealt with according to law; make complaints to the proper officers of any person known or believed to be guilty of the violation of the ordinances of the city or of the penal laws of the state or the United States. 
(b)  The chief of police shall cause to be served and executed any criminal process directed to him, issued by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(c)  Adequate patrol of all parts of the city, so far as size of the police force permits, shall be maintained. 
(Code 1975, § 2-62; Code 1988, § 2-432) 
Secs. 2-802-2-847. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PENSIONS AND RETIREMENT[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
State Law reference- Texas Municipal Retirement System, V.T.C.A., Government Code ch. 851 et seq. 

Sec. 2-848. - Ordinances continued in effect. 
    All ordinances, as amended and on file with the city secretary, pertaining to participation in the Texas Municipal Retirement System, are continued in full force and effect. 
(Code 1975, § 2-55; Code 1988, § 2-466) 
Sec. 2-849. - Authorization of updated service credits. 
    On the terms and conditions set out in V.T.C.A., Government Code §§ 853.401-853.404, of Subtitle G of Title 8, Government Code, as amended (referred to in this article as the "TMRS Act"), each member of the Texas Municipal Retirement System (referred to in this article as the "system") who has current service credit or prior service credit in the system in force and effect on January 1 of the calendar year preceding such allowance, by reason of service in the employment of the city, and on such date had at least 36 months of credited service with the system, shall be and is hereby allowed updated service credit (as that term is defined in V.T.C.A., Government Code § 853.402(d)). 
(1)  On the terms and conditions set out in V.T.C.A., Government Code § 853.601, any member of the system who is eligible for updated service credits on the basis of service with this city, who has unforfeited credit for prior service and/or current service with another participating municipality or municipalities by reason of previous service, and was a contributing member on January 1 of the calendar year preceding such allowance, shall be credited with updated service credits pursuant to, calculated in accordance with, and subject to adjustment as set forth in V.T.C.A., Government Code § 853.601, both as to the initial grant hereunder and all future grants under this section. 
(2)  The updated service credit hereby allowed and provided for shall be 100 percent of the base updated service credit of the member (calculated as provided in V.T.C.A., Government Code § 853.402(c)). 
(3)  Each updated service credit allowed hereunder shall replace any updated service credit, prior service credit, special prior service credit, or antecedent service credit previously authorized for part of the same service. 
(4)  In accordance with the provisions of V.T.C.A., Government Code § 853.401(c), the deposits required to be made to the system by employees of the participating departments on account of current service shall be calculated from and after the effective date (January 1, 2002) of this section on the full amount of such person's compensation as an employee of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 2-56; Code 1988, § 2-467; Ord. No. 716, § 1, 11-28-1988; Ord. No. 808, § 1, 10-8-1991; Ord. No. 1075, § 1, 9-23-1997; Ord. No. 1315, § 1, 11-27-2001) 
Sec. 2-850. - Dates of allowances and increases. 
(a)  The initial allowance of updated service credits hereunder shall be effective January 1, 2002, subject to approval by the board of trustees of the system. An allowance of updated service credits shall be made hereunder on January 1 of each subsequent year until this section ceases to be in effect under V.T.C.A., Government Code § 853.404 (e), provided that, as to such subsequent year, the actuary for the system has made the determination set forth in V.T.C.A., Government Code §853.404(d). 
(b)  The initial increase in retirement annuities hereunder shall be effective on January 1, 2013, subject to approval by the board of trustees of the system. An increase in retirement annuities shall be made hereunder on January 1 of each subsequent year until this ordinance ceases to be in effect under subsection (e) of Section 853.404 of the TMRS Act, provided that, as to such subsequent year, the actuary for the system has made the determination set forth in subsection (d) of Section 853.404 of the TMRS Act, and provided further that, as to such subsequent year, the city has an ordinance in effect that provides for a simultaneous increase in updated service credits as that term is used in the TMRS Act. 
(Code 1988, § 2-467.1; Ord. No. 808, § 2, 10-8-1991; Ord. No. 1075, § 3, 9-23-1997; Ord. No. 1315, § 3, 11-27-2001; Ord. No. 1967, § 1, 8-28-2012) 
Sec. 2-851. - Increase in retirement annuities. 
(a)  On the terms and conditions set out in Sections 854.203 and 853.404 of Subtitle G of Title 8, Government Code, as amended (hereinafter referred to as the "TMRS Act"), the city hereby elects to allow and to provide for payment of the increases below stated in monthly benefits payable by the system to retired employees and to beneficiaries of deceased employees of the city under current service annuities and prior service annuities arising from service by such employees to the city. An annuity increased under this section replaces any annuity or increased annuity previously granted to the same person. 
(b)  The amount of the annuity increase under this section is computed as the sum of the prior service and current service annuities on the effective date of retirement of the person on whose service the annuities are based, multiplied by 50 percent of the percentage change in consumer price index for all urban consumers, from December of the year immediately preceding the effective date of the person's retirement to the December that is 13 months before the effective date of the increase under this section. 
(c)  An increase in an annuity that was reduced because of an option selection is reducible in the same proportion and in the same manner that the original annuity was reduced. 
(d)  If a computation hereunder does not result in an increase in the amount of an annuity, the amount of the annuity will not be changed hereunder. 
(e)  The amount by which an increase under this section exceeds all previously granted increases to an annuitant is an obligation of the city and of its account in the benefit accumulation fund of the system. 
(Code 1975, § 2-57; Code 1988, § 2-468; Ord. No. 807, § 1, 10-8-1991; Ord. No. 1075, § 2, 9-23-1997; Ord. No. 1315, § 2, 11-27-2001; Ord. No. 1967, § 1, 8-28-2012) 
Sec. 2-852. - Additional rights, credits and benefits. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of V.T.C.A., Government Code § 854.202(g), the city adopts the following provisions affecting participation of its employees in the Texas Municipal Retirement System: 
(1)  Any employee of the city who is a member of the system is eligible to retire and receive a service retirement annuity if the member has at least 20 years of credited service in the system performed for one or more municipalities that have adopted a like provision under V.T.C.A., Government Code § 854.202. Prior to adopting Ordinance No. 1075, from which this section is derived, the governing body of the city has: 
a.  Prepared an actuarial analysis of member retirement annuities at 20 years of service, and 
b.  Held a public hearing pursuant to the notice provisions of the Texas Open Meetings Act, V.T.C.A., Government Code ch. 551. 
(2)  If a vested member, as formerly described in V.T.C.A., Government Code § 854.204(b) prior to the repeal of such section, shall die before becoming eligible for service retirement and leaves surviving a lawful spouse whom the member has designated as beneficiary entitled to payment of the member's accumulated contributions in event of the member's death before retirement, the surviving spouse may by written notice filed with the system elect to leave the accumulated deposits on deposit with the system subject to the terms and conditions of V.T.C.A., Government Code § 854.204(b). If the accumulated deposits have not been withdrawn before such time as the member, if living, would have become entitled to service retirement, the surviving spouse may elect to receive, in lieu of the accumulated deposits, an annuity payable monthly thereafter during the lifetime of the surviving spouse in such amount as would have been payable had the member lived and retired at that date under a joint and survivor annuity (Option 1) payable during the lifetime of the member and continuing thereafter during the lifetime of the surviving spouse. 
(3)  At any time before payment of the first monthly benefit of any annuity, a surviving spouse to whom subsection (2) of this section applies may, upon written application filed with the system, receive payment of the accumulated contributions standing to the account of the member in lieu of any benefits otherwise payable under this section. In the event such a surviving spouse shall die before payment of the first monthly benefit of an annuity allowed under this section, the accumulated contributions credited to the account of the member shall be paid to the estate of such spouse. 
(4)  The rights hereinabove authorized shall be in addition to the plan provisions heretofore adopted and in force at the effective date of Ordinance No. 1075 (January 1, 1998) pursuant to the TMRS Act. 
(5)  Any employee of this city who is a member of the system is eligible to retire and receive a standard occupational disability retirement annuity under V.T.C.A., Government Code § 854.408, or an optional occupational disability retirement annuity under V.T.C.A., Government Code § 854.410, upon making application therefor upon such form and in such manner as may be prescribed by the board of trustees of the system, provided that the system's medical board has certified to said board of trustees: 
a.  That the member is physically or mentally disabled for further performance of the duties of the member's employment; 
b.  That the disability is likely to be permanent; and 
c.  That the member should be retired. 
Any annuity granted under this subsection shall be subject to the provisions of V.T.C.A., Government Code § 854.409. 
(6)  The provisions relating to the occupational disability program as set forth in subsection (5) of this section are in lieu of the disability program heretofore provided for under V.T.C.A., Government Code §§ 854.301-854.308. 
(Code 1988, § 2-469; Ord. No. 715, § 1, 11-14-1988; Ord. No. 1075, § 5, 9-23-1997) 
Sec. 2-853. - Prior service credit for probationary period of service. 
(a)  Any employee of this city who is a member of the Texas Municipal Retirement System and who performed service as a probationary employee for this city prior to September 1, 1989, for which the employee did not receive credited service in the system because the person, a probationary employee was not enrolled as a member of the system is hereby allowed to obtain prior service credit for the probationary period of such service, pursuant to the provisions of V.T.C.A., Government Code § 853.304. 
(b)  To obtain prior service credit allowable under subsection (a) of this section any employee entitled thereto shall file a detailed written statement of the service claimed with the city secretary within one year from the effective date of this section. 
(c)  As soon as practicable after the employee has filed a claim the prior service credit under V.T.C.A., Government Code § 853.304, the city personnel officer shall, if said officer determines that such service was performed as claimed, verify the prior service allowable (not to exceed six months) and the average monthly compensation paid the member during this period of employment, and shall certify to the board of trustees of the system the creditable prior service approved, and the average monthly compensation paid to the person by the city during this period of employment. 
(Code 1988, § 2-470; Ord. No. 749, §§ 1-3, 10-23-1989) 
Sec. 2-854. - Military service credit. 
(a)  Pursuant to V.T.C.A., Government Code § 853.502, as amended, the city hereby elects to allow eligible members in its employment to establish credit in the Texas Municipal Retirement System for active military service performed as a member of the armed forces or armed forces reserves of the United States or an auxiliary of the armed forces or armed forces reserves. Eligible members as used herein shall be those employees meeting the criteria set forth in V.T.C.A., Government Code §§ 853.502(b) and 853.503, and the amount and use of creditable military service shall be as further set forth in V.T.C.A., Government Code § 853.505. 
(b)  In order to establish credit for military service hereunder, a member must deposit with the Texas Municipal Retirement System (in that member's individual account in the Employees Saving Fund), an amount equal to the number of months for which credit is sought, multiplied by $15.00. The city agrees that its account in the municipality accumulation fund is to be charged at the time of the member's retirement with an amount equal to the accumulated amount paid by the member for military service credit, multiplied by the city's current service matching ratio in effect at the date the member applies for such military service credit. 
(Code 1988, § 2-471; Ord. No. 750, §§ 1, 2, 10-23-1989) 
Sec. 2-855. - Restricted prior service credit. 
(a)  On the terms and conditions set out in V.T.C.A., Government Code § 853.305, as amended, each member of the Texas Municipal Retirement System who is now or who hereafter becomes an employee of this city shall receive restricted prior service credit for service previously performed as an employee of any incorporated city or town in the United States or of any council of governments in this state for which the person has not otherwise received credit for service in this system, including combined service credit under V.T.C.A., Government Code § 803.001 et seq. The service credit hereby granted may be used only to satisfy length of service requirements for retirement eligibility, has no monetary value in computing the annuity payments allowable to the member, and may not be used in other computations, including computation of updated service credits. 
(b)  A member seeking to establish restricted prior service credit under this article must take the action required under V.T.C.A., Government Code § 853.305, while still an employee of the city. 
(Code 1988, § 2-472; Ord. No. 959, § 1, 7-11-1995) 
Sec. 2-856. - Deposits. 
    All employees of the city, who are members of the Texas Municipal Retirement System, shall make deposits to the system at the rate of seven percent of their individual earnings. 
(Code 1988, § 2-473; Ord. No. 1075, § 4, 9-23-1997; Ord. No. 1315, § 4, 11-27-2001) 
Sec. 2-857. - Termination of previous membership. 
    Pursuant to Section 853,003 of Subtitle G of Title 8, V.T.C.A., Government Code, as amended, the City of Bryan hereby elects to allow any member of the Texas Municipal Retirement System who is an employee of this city on the date of this section's final adoption who has terminated a previous membership in said system by withdrawal of deposits while absent from service, but who has at least 24 months of credited service as an employee of this city since resuming membership to deposit with the system in a lump sum the amount withdrawn, plus a withdrawal charge of five percent of such amount for each year from date of such withdrawal to date of redeposit, and thereupon such member shall be allowed credit for all service to which the member had been entitled at date of termination of earlier membership, with like effect as if all such service had been rendered as an employee of this city, whether so rendered or not. The city agrees to underwrite and hereby assumes the obligations arising out of the granting of all such credits, and agrees that all such obligations and reserves required to provide such credits shall be charged to this city's account in the municipality accumulation fund. The five percent per annum withdrawal charge paid by the member shall be deposited to the credit of the city's account in said municipality accumulation fund; and the deposits of the amount previously withdrawn by the member shall be credited to his or her individual account in the employees' savings fund of the system. 
(Ord. No. 1546, 8-23-2005) 
Sec. 2-858. - City elects to make future normal and prior service contributions to its account in the municipal accumulation fund of the system at such combined rate of the total compensation paid by the city to employees who are members of the system. 
    Pursuant to Section 855.407(g) of the TMRS Act, the city hereby elects to make future normal and prior service contributions to its account in the municipal accumulation fund of the cystem at such combined rate of the total compensation paid by the city to employees who are members of the system, as the system's actuary shall annually determine as the rate necessary to fund, within the amortization period determined as applicable to the city under the TMRS Act, the costs of all benefits which are or may become chargeable to or are to be paid out of the city's account in said accumulation fund, regardless of other provisions of the TMRS Act limiting the combined rate of city contributions. 
(Ord. No. 1735, § 1, 12-11-2007) 
Secs. 2-859-2-875. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - RECORDS RETENTION AND DISPOSITION 

Sec. 2-876. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Public record shall mean any record that is available for public inspection pursuant to V.T.C.A., Government Code ch. 552 (Public Information Act). 
    Record shall mean any document, paper, letter, book, map, photograph, sound or video recording, microfilm, magnetic tape, electronic medium or other information-recording medium, regardless of physical form or characteristic and regardless of whether public access to it is open or restricted under the laws of the state, created or received by the city or any of its officers or employees pursuant to law, including an ordinance, or in the transaction of public business. The term does not include: 
(1)  Extra identical copies of documents created only for convenience of reference or research by officers or employees of the city; 
(2)  Notes, journals, diaries and similar documents created by an officer or employee of the city for the officer's or employee's personal convenience; 
(3)  Blank forms; 
(4)  Stocks of publications; 
(5)  Copies of documents in any media furnished to members of the public to which they are entitled under V.T.C.A., Government Code ch. 552, or other state law; or 
(6)  Any records, correspondence, notes, memoranda or documents, other than a final written agreement described by V.T.C.A., Government Code § 2009.054(c), associated with a matter conducted under an alternative dispute resolution procedure in which personnel of a state department or institution, local government, special district or other political subdivision of the state participated as a party, facilitated as an impartial third party, or facilitated as the administrator of a dispute resolution system or organization. 
(Code 1975, § 2-34(3)(a); Code 1988, § 2-486) 
Sec. 2-877. - Records management officer. 
    The city secretary, and the successive holders of said office, shall serve as the records management officer for the city. As provided by state law, each successive holder of the office shall file his or her name with the director and librarian of the Texas State Library and Archives Commission within 30 days of the initial designation or of taking up the office, as applicable. 
(Code 1988, § 2-487; Ord. No. 764, § 1, 5-28-1990) 
Sec. 2-878. - Duties of records management officer. 
    In addition to other duties assigned in this section, the records management officer shall: 
(1)  Administer the records management program and provide assistance to department heads in its implementation; 
(2)  Plan, formulate, and prescribe records disposition policies, systems, standards, and procedures; 
(3)  In cooperation with department heads identify essential records and establish a disaster plan for each city office and department to ensure maximum availability of the records in order to reestablish operations quickly and with minimum disruption and expense following a natural disaster; 
(4)  Develop procedures to ensure the permanent preservation of the historically valuable records of the city; 
(5)  Establish standards for filing and storage equipment and for recordkeeping supplies; 
(6)  Study the feasibility of and, if appropriate, establish a uniform filing system and a forms design and control system for the city; 
(7)  Provide records management advice and assistance to all city departments by preparation of a manual or manuals of procedure and policy and by on-site consultation; 
(8)  Monitor records retention schedules and administrative rules issued by the Texas State Library and Archives Commission to determine if the records management program and the city's records control schedules are in compliance with state regulations; 
(9)  Disseminate to the city council and department heads information concerning state laws and administrative rules relating to local government records; 
(10)  Instruct records liaison officers and other personnel in policies and procedures of the records management plan and their duties in the records management program; 
(11)  Direct records liaison officers or other personnel in the conduct of records inventories in preparation for the development of records control schedules as required by state law and this section; 
(12)  Ensure that the maintenance, preservation, microfilming, destruction or other disposition of city records is carried out in accordance with the policies and procedures of the records management program and the requirements of state law; 
(13)  Maintain records on the volume of records destroyed under approved records control schedules, the volume of records microfilmed or stored electronically, and the estimated cost and space savings as the result of such disposal or disposition; 
(14)  Report annually to the city council on the implementation of the records management plan in each department of the city, including summaries of the statistical and fiscal data compiled under subsection (13) of this section; 
(15)  Bring to the attention of the city council noncompliance by city personnel with the policies and procedures of the records management program or the Local Government Records Act (V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 201 et seq.). 
(Code 1988, § 2-488; Ord. No. 764, § 1, 5-28-1990) 
Sec. 2-879. - Policy. 
    There is hereby adopted by the city council for the purpose of establishing rules and regulations for the retention and disposition of records accumulated by the city, the rules and provisions set out in the records retention manual. A true and correct copy is to be kept on file with the city secretary. The manual is hereby incorporated herein by reference as fully as if set out at length herein. The provisions of such manual shall be controlling in the retention and disposition of records prepared, received or accumulated by any department, officer or employee of city, except as might otherwise be herein provided as required by federal or state law. Any amendments to the manual shall be approved by the city manager and the city secretary. 
(Code 1975, § 2-34(3)(b); Code 1988, § 2-489; Ord. No. 764, § 1, 5-28-1990) 
Sec. 2-880. - Destruction. 
(a)  Any employee of the city disposing of or destroying any record of the city other than by the method and procedure provided in the records retention manual shall be deemed to be acting without authority of law. 
(b)  Any record, the subject matter of which is in litigation, may not be destroyed until such litigation is final. Such records shall be retained in such form and manner and for such time as may be prescribed by the city attorney. 
(Code 1975, § 2-34(3)(c), (d); Code 1988, § 2-490; Ord. No. 764, § 1, 5-28-1990) 
Secs. 2-881-2-910. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SELF-INSURANCE AND RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-911. - Definitions. 
    The following terms, as used in this article, have the following meanings unless the context requires otherwise: 
    Act shall include an omission or failure to act. 
    Administrative expenses shall mean the expenses of administering the program, including (but not limited to) the following: 
(1)  The compensation paid to any claims adjustor or any professional actuary; 
(2)  The expenses of defending any claim, including (but not limited to) the following: 
a.  The compensation paid to expert witnesses; 
b.  Attorney's fees and expenses; and 
c.  Investigation expenses; 
(3)  Any expenses incurred by the city in the course of any financing undertaken to provide funding for the fund or to repay any obligation incurred by the city in the course of such financing; 
(4)  The cost of program insurance (including any compensation paid to brokers) that is purchased in accordance with the program ordinance; or 
(5)  The cost of charges or compensation paid to any city employee involved in the program and any consultant services utilized on behalf of the program. 
    Advertising injury shall mean any injury to a person that results from the promotional activities of the city if such injury arises out of libel, slander, defamation, violation of right to privacy, commercial piracy, unfair competition, or infringement of copyright, title, or slogan. 
    Advertising injury claim shall mean a program general liability claim in which the damages are asserted to be the result of advertising injury. 
    Annual period shall mean the fiscal year of the city as established by the city council. 
    Assumed general liability claim shall mean any plan claim for which the city, in the judgment of the city manager, or by operation of law is liable. 
    Assumed risks shall mean the risks for which the city has assumed liability pursuant to the risk assumption ordinance. 
    Bodily injury shall mean any physical harm or physical illness sustained by any individual, including a resulting death. 
    Claim shall mean any claim or suit against the city (whether in its capacity as a municipal corporation or as an insurer under the Municipal Workers' Compensation Law, V.T.C.A., Labor Code ch. 504) or any claim or suit against any plan member that the city is responsible for defending under the risk assumption ordinance, regardless of whether any damages resulting from such claim or suit are permitted under the program ordinance to be paid from the fund. 
    Claims adjuster shall mean any person designated as claims adjuster as provided by section 2-1002. 
    Corporate general liability claim shall mean any corporate general liability damages, together with the corporate general liability expenses that result from the claim giving rise to such corporate general liability damages, but does not include a workers' compensation payment. 
    Corporate general liability conduct shall mean any of the following: 
(1)  Any error or omission that causes an injury; 
(2)  Any conduct of the city or a plan member that: 
a.  Causes bodily injury, property damage, or regulatory injury that is not intended or expected by the actor; 
b.  Causes advertising injury that: 
1.  Is not intended or expected by the actor; and 
2.  Does not arise out of any statement that the actor knows is false; or 
c.  Causes personal injury or property damage (regardless of whether intended or expected by the actor) that results from: 
1.  The use of reasonable force for the purpose of protecting persons or property; or 
2.  The discharge of the actor's official duties for the city. 
    Corporate general liability damages shall mean the damages for which the city, in the judgment of the city manager is liable as a result of a claim arising from corporate general liability conduct. 
    Corporate general liability expenses shall mean the court costs, pre-judgment and post-judgment interest, attorneys' fees, and any other expenses or costs for which the city is liable as a result of a claim giving rise to corporate general liability damages. 
    Corporate general liability risks shall mean the risks for which the city, as a municipal corporation, may be held liable by operation of law in the course of performing its governmental or proprietary functions. 
    Damages shall mean compensatory damages, punitive damages, special damages, or any other classification of damages that lawfully may be awarded against the city or plan member as a result of a claim. 
    Error or omission shall mean any act of a plan member that results in or constitutes an erroneous or improper discharge of such plan member's official duties for the city (including the making of an incorrect statement), but that does not constitute legally actionable fraud or an intentional or knowing breach of duty. 
    Excluded payment shall mean any of the following payments: 
(1)  The payment of a program claim that is not made while the program is in effect in accordance with applicable claims administration procedures; 
(2)  The payment of any program claim involving damages that arise from the exercise by the city of its power of eminent domain; 
(3)  The payment of all or that portion of any program claim, or of any other item for which a withdrawal from the fund is permitted by section 2-968(a), that, in lieu of payment from the fund, can be paid from: 
a.  The proceeds of insurance carried by the city, including (but not limited to) casualty or liability insurance, workers' compensation insurance, or property insurance; 
b.  The proceeds of any insurance carried under any health, accident, or similar plan of benefits provided by the city; or 
c.  Any fund, reserves, or other source of payment available to the city that has been designated or otherwise set aside for such use. 
(4)  The payment of any program general liability claim arising from an injury that results from the distribution (whether by sale, gift or otherwise) of an alcoholic beverage, other than a distribution at an activity or function that is incidental to the city's business, that: 
a.  Is in violation of the law; 
b.  Is to a minor or to an individual who is under the influence of alcohol; or 
c.  Causes or contributes to the intoxication of any individual. 
(5)  The payment of any program claim arising from an injury that results from declared or undeclared war (including civil war, insurrection, rebellion, or similar hostility) or any act or condition incident to war; or 
(6)  The payment of any program claim: 
a.  In which the city's liability exists by virtue of the Texas Tort Claims Act, V.T.C.A., Civil Practice and Remedies Code ch. 101, regardless of whether the city is a defendant, that exceeds the limits of liability applicable to the city under that statute; 
b.  In which the city's liability exists by virtue of the Municipal Workers' Compensation Law that exceeds the limits of liability applicable to the city under that statute; 
c.  That the city is otherwise granted immunity from paying or precluded from paying by law; or 
d.  In an amount that exceeds any limits prescribed by the program ordinance in the amount of withdrawals that may be made from the fund to pay program claims. 
    Finance director shall mean the individual having the responsibility for the management of the city's financial affairs. 
    Fund shall mean the risk management fund created by section 2-943. 
    Fund surplus shall mean the amount of money in the fund that is in excess of the amount that, in the opinion of a professional actuary, is required to maintain the fund on an actuarially sound basis, to the extent the chief administrative officer of the city believes is reasonably practicable, for the period of time and the risks of loss for which it is then funded. 
    Injury shall mean any of the following injuries: 
(1)  Advertising injury; 
(2)  Personal injury; 
(3)  Property damage; 
(4)  Regulatory injury. 
    Law shall include the federal and state constitutions and statutes, the city Charter and ordinances, any administrative rules having the force and effect of law, and any controlling judicial decisions applicable to the city. 
    Municipal Workers' Compensation Law shall mean V.T.C.A., Labor Code ch. 504, as amended. 
    Occurrence shall mean an episode, an incident or series of related incidents, or an event or series of related events that results in compensable injury to one or more persons. 
    Personal injury shall mean any bodily injury; mental harm, anguish, or illness (regardless of whether accompanied by bodily injury); discrimination; humiliation; assault; false or improper service of process; false imprisonment; damage to character; reputation, or integrity; invasion of privacy; violation of property rights; or violation of civil rights. 
    Personal injury claim shall mean any program general liability claim in which the damages are asserted to be the result of personal injury. 
    Plan claim shall mean any plan claim as described in the risk assumption ordinance. 
    Plan loss expenses shall mean any plan loss expenses as described in the risk assumption ordinance. 
    Program shall mean the Bryan Self-Insurance and Risk Management Program established by section 2-941. 
    Program claim shall mean any: 
(1)  Program general liability claim; or 
(2)  Workers' compensation payment. 
    Program general liability claim shall mean any assumed general liability claim or any corporate general liability claim. 
    Program insurance shall mean any insurance (other than the self-insurance provided by the fund) that is obtained by the city pursuant to section 2-1025. 
    Program ordinance shall mean this article and any amendments hereto. 
    Program risks shall mean any of the following risks: 
(1)  The assumed risks; 
(2)  The corporate general liability risks; 
(3)  The workers' compensation risks. 
    Property damage shall mean any damage to or destruction of tangible property or the loss of use of tangible property. 
    Property damage claim shall mean a program general liability claim in which the damages are asserted to be the result of property damage. 
    Regulatory injury shall mean any economic loss sustained by a person as a result of the performance by the city of its regulatory or property acquisition functions. 
    Regulatory injury claim shall mean a program general liability claim in which the damages are asserted to be the result of regulatory injury. 
    Risk assumption ordinance shall mean section 2-947 which establishes the city officer and employee liability plan as from time-to-time amended. 
    Risk manager shall mean the person serving as the risk manager pursuant to section 2-1024. 
    Termination date means December 1, 2018, or any other date of termination of the program specified by ordinance or resolution of the city. 
    Workers' compensation payment shall mean any payment of compensation, benefits, expenses, or other charges for which the city is liable, as an insurer, as a result of a claim by an employee of the city or any other person pursuant to the Municipal Workers' Compensation Law. 
    Workers' compensation risks shall mean the risks for which the city may be held liable under the Municipal Workers' Compensation Law. 
(Code 1988, § 2-501; Ord. No. 719, § 1.01, 11-28-1988; Ord. No. 1145, § 1, 11-24-1998; Ord. No. 1787, § 1, 11-25-2008) 
Secs. 2-912-2-940. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM 

Sec. 2-941. - Established. 
    The city hereby establishes the "Bryan Self-Insurance and Risk Management Program," which shall consist of the policies, rights, and duties embodied in the program ordinance. The program shall be implemented and administered as provided by the program ordinance. 
(Code 1988, § 2-521; Ord. No. 719, § 2.01, 11-28-1988) 
Sec. 2-942. - Administration. 
    The city manager is hereby directed to establish a claims review process subject to the provisions of this article so as to ensure the legal and technical review of all claims made against the city and/or its employees. 
(Code 1988, § 2-522; Ord. No. 719, § 2.02, 11-28-1988) 
Sec. 2-943. - Risk management fund created. 
(a)  The risk management fund is hereby created. 
(b)  The fund is a special trust fund of the city, created for the purpose of providing capital for the program to be used as provided by the program ordinance. 
(c)  No person (including any plan member), other than the city, has, or is granted or vested with, any right to any of the money in the fund. 
(d)  The fund shall be maintained at the city's depository bank unless required to be maintained elsewhere by another city ordinance or by written agreement entered into by the city. 
(Code 1988, § 2-523; Ord. No. 719, § 2.03, 11-28-1988) 
Sec. 2-944. - Capitalizing the fund. 
    The fund may be funded with money: 
(1)  Provided by contributions made from time-to-time, upon the order of the city council, from budgeted, appropriated, and currently available city money; or 
(2)  Derived from time-to-time by the city pursuant to agreements entered into with any third person source of funding. 
(Code 1988, § 2-524; Ord. No. 719, § 2.04, 11-28-1988) 
Sec. 2-945. - Risk retention policy. 
    It is the policy of the city, subject to budgetary and general economic conditions to self-insure against program risks through the fund and to provide such self-insurance by depositing money into the fund in amounts sufficient, under actuarial determinations, to provide for the defined self-insurance coverage prescribed by this article. It is further the policy of the city, under the appropriate conditions to obtain program insurance as provided by this article. 
(Code 1988, § 2-525; Ord. No. 719, § 2.05, 11-28-1988) 
Sec. 2-946. - No admission of liability for claims. 
    The city, by virtue of establishing and maintaining the program, is not admitting liability for any claim. The city reserves the right to assert any defense to the payment or collection of any claim that is lawfully available to it. 
(Code 1988, § 2-526; Ord. No. 719, § 2.06, 11-28-1988) 
Sec. 2-947. - City officer and employee liability plan. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City vehicle shall mean a vehicle or mobile equipment either leased or owned by the city. 
    Loss shall mean an amount which a plan member is legally obligated to pay resulting from an act or omission of the plan member which is covered under this plan. 
    Plan shall mean the City of Bryan Officer and Employee Liability Plan. 
    Plan member shall mean a person who is: 
(1)  An employee of the city; 
(2)  A member of a city board, commission, or committee created by Charter, ordinance, or resolution of the city; 
(3)  A member of the city council; 
(4)  A volunteer who has been approved as a volunteer by a departmental volunteer coordinator and who is working under the direction of an employee of the city; 
(5)  A member of the board of directors of the Bryan Business Council, Inc.; or 
(6)  The executive director of the Bryan Business Council, Inc., but only if employed as a regular fulltime employee of that corporation. 
(b)  Coverage. 
(1)  The city shall indemnify and defend a plan member, in accordance with the terms of this section, against a loss arising out of a claim, suit, or judgment resulting from an act or omission of the plan member during the discharge of his or her duties as a plan member or within the scope of his or her office, employment, or assigned volunteer work with the city. 
(2)  A plan member whose position with the city or with the Bryan Business Council, Inc., terminates is entitled to coverage in accordance with this section for any event that occurred while the person was a plan member. 
(c)  Defense. 
(1)  The city will defend any suit against a plan member who is covered under this plan even if the suit is groundless or fraudulent. 
(2)  The city may investigate, negotiate, and settle any claim or suit as it determines necessary. 
(d)  Limits of coverage. 
(1)  The city will pay losses covered by this plan that a plan member is legally obligated to pay, except, that in cases arising from incidents or occurrences where the city's liability exists by virtue of the Texas Tort Claims Act (V.T.C.A., Civil Practice and Remedies Code ch. 101), whether or not the city is a party defendant, the city will pay those losses covered by this plan that a plan member is legally obligated to pay up to, but not exceeding the limits of liability provided by that Act, as amended, for units of local government. 
(2)  In addition to the coverage provided in subsection (d)(1) of this section the city will pay: 
a.  The city's expenses in investigating and defending the claim or lawsuit; 
b.  Costs taxed against a plan member in a suit covered by this section and interest that accrues after entry of judgment before the city has deposited payment with the court on that part of the judgment which does not exceed the limits of coverage; 
c.  Reasonable expenses of the plan member incurred at the city's request; and 
d.  Attorney's fees ordered by the court to be paid by the plan member. 
(e)  Notice of occurrence, claim, or suit; cooperation. To be entitled to coverage under the plan a plan member must: 
(1)  Notify the city attorney as soon as practicable upon receipt of written notice of a claim or lawsuit, but no later than three working days after receipt; 
(2)  Cooperate with the city attorney and, upon the city attorney's request, assist in making settlements, in the conduct of suits, and in enforcing any right of contribution or indemnity against a person or organization who may be liable to the city because of injury or damage covered under the plan; 
(3)  Attend hearings and trials and assist in securing and giving evidence and obtaining the attendance of witnesses; 
(4)  Not, except upon advice of the city attorney or when questioned by a police officer at the scene of an accident, give any oral or written statement or enter into any stipulation or agreement concerning a claim or lawsuit; and 
(5)  Not, except at his or her own cost, voluntarily make any payment, assume any obligation, or incur any expense with respect to a claim or lawsuit without the consent of the city. 
(f)  Plan period. This plan covers only acts or omissions occurring or alleged to have occurred: 
(1)  While the plan is in effect; 
(2)  Before the plan was in effect and which are not barred by any statute of limitations; and 
(3)  If the plan is canceled, while the plan is in effect and which are not barred by any statute of limitations. 
(g)  Exclusions. Coverage under this plan does not apply to a claim or lawsuit that is brought against a plan member: 
(1)  By the city; 
(2)  Arising out of the intentional or knowing violation of a penal statute or ordinance committed by or with the knowledge or consent of the plan member, or any claim arising out of acts of fraud committed by or at the direction of the plan member with intent to deceive or defraud; 
(3)  Arising either while the plan member is operating a city vehicle with no authority to operate the vehicle, or while the plan member is operating a city vehicle in the course of personal or private business; 
(4)  For liability assumed by the plan member under a contract, unless the contract is entered into at the request of the city; 
(5)  If the plan member joins or attempts to join with the suit against the plan member a claim against the city for benefits under this plan; or 
(6)  If the plan member fails to comply with subsection (e) of this section. 
(h)  Subrogation. If payment or legal representation is provided under this section, the city is subrogated to the plan member's rights of recovery against any person or organization to the extent of the city's liability and payments, and the plan member must execute and deliver to the city attorney whatever documents are necessary to secure those rights. The plan member must not do anything after a loss to prejudice those rights. 
(i)  Legal representation. 
(1)  The city will provide legal representation for a plan member in a claim or suit for which the plan member is covered under this section. 
(2)  If the city attorney determines that there is a conflict of interest for the city attorney in representing a plan member, and the plan member is otherwise entitled to coverage under this section, the city will pay the reasonable fee of a private attorney to represent the plan member. The private attorney will be selected by mutual agreement of the plan member and the city attorney. 
(j)  Determination of coverage. If the city denies coverage to the plan member, the plan member may seek a determination of coverage by a court of proper jurisdiction in the county. If the court rules in favor of the plan member, the city shall provide the plan member all benefits under the plan and shall reimburse the plan member for reasonable attorney fees, expenses and costs incurred in obtaining the determination of coverage. 
(k)  No creation of cause of action. Nothing contained in this section shall be construed as creating a right or cause of action against a plan member nor as giving a right to a third party to institute or maintain a suit which would not otherwise exist under law as a legal claim against a plan member. 
(Code 1988, § 2-527; Ord. No. 719, § 2.07, 11-28-1988; Ord. No. 765, § 1, 5-28-1990; Ord. No. 1493, § 1, 9-28-2004) 
Secs. 2-948-2-967. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - REGULATION OF RISK MANAGEMENT FUND 

Sec. 2-968. - Authorized withdrawals from fund. 
(a)  Money may be withdrawn from the fund only for the following purposes: 
(1)  To reimburse the city for administrative expenses; 
(2)  To pay any program claim; 
(3)  To pay any fund surplus to the city, if approved by the city council; 
(4)  To retire (by scheduled payments, prepayment, defeasance, or otherwise) any obligation of the city incurred in connection with providing funding for the fund; or 
(5)  To reimburse the city for any payment made under any agreement to provide funding for the fund that is permitted to be paid to the city pursuant to such agreement, or, to the extent and under the terms and conditions provided in such agreement, to cure a default in payment by the city under such agreement. 
(b)  Money may not be withdrawn from the fund to make any excluded payment. 
(Code 1988, § 2-531; Ord. No. 719, § 3.01, 11-28-1988) 
Sec. 2-969. - Control of withdrawals from fund. 
(a)  Subject to the restrictions and limitations provided by the program ordinance, the determination of whether money in the fund is to be withdrawn is in the discretion of the city manager in accordance with the laws and ordinances of the city. 
(b)  An aggregate amount exceeding $15,000.00 may not be withdrawn from the fund to pay the program claims of any one claimant that arise from the same occurrence unless the city council approves a greater amount for that purpose. 
(Code 1988, § 2-532; Ord. No. 719, § 3.02, 11-28-1988) 
Sec. 2-970. - Method of withdrawal from fund. 
    Withdrawals from the fund may be made, upon the order of the city manager, by check or draft drawn on the fund. 
(Code 1988, § 2-533; Ord. No. 719, § 3.03, 11-28-1988) 
Sec. 2-971. - Withdrawal of fund surplus. 
    Fund surplus may not be withdrawn from the fund more often than twice a year. 
(Code 1988, § 2-534; Ord. No. 719, § 3.04, 11-28-1988) 
Secs. 2-972-2-1000. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - ADMINISTRATION OF CLAIMS 

Sec. 2-1001. - Administration of claims generally. 
    The city manager or his or her designee is responsible for the administration of claims. Workers' compensation claims shall be administered in accordance with the Texas Workers' Compensation Act (V.T.C.A., Labor Code ch. 407 et seq.), as amended from time-to-time. 
(Code 1988, § 2-541; Ord. No. 719, § 4.01, 11-28-1988) 
Sec. 2-1002. - Claims adjusters. 
(a)  The city manager may allow one or more claims adjusters to adjust or otherwise administer claims for the city. 
(b)  Each person that is to serve as a claims adjuster shall be approved by the city manager or his or her designee. A claims adjuster may be selected from among the city's administrative staff, or a professional claims handling or management service may be retained as a claims adjuster. 
(c)  If a professional claims handling or management service is to be retained as a claims adjuster, such employment shall be on a nonexclusive basis and the contract under which such service is retained shall be approved by the city council. 
(d)  Each claims adjuster shall be directly responsible to the risk manager and shall follow any claims administration policies and procedures as established. 
(Code 1988, § 2-542; Ord. No. 719, § 4.02, 11-28-1988) 
Sec. 2-1003. - Defense of claims. 
(a)  The city manager, with the advice of the city attorney, shall direct the defense of the city in claims. 
(b)  The city manager, with the advice of the city attorney, may retain attorneys, experts, and investigators in connection with the defense of any claim. 
(Code 1988, § 2-543; Ord. No. 719, §4.03, 11-28-1988) 
Sec. 2-1004. - Settlement of claims. 
(a)  The city manager, in his or her discretion, may settle claims except for workers' compensation claims, subject to the limitations prescribed by this section. Workers' compensation settlements shall be under the discretion of the city manager, or his or her designee, subject to the Texas Worker's Compensation Act (V.T.C.A., Labor Code ch. 407 et seq.). 
(b)  The claims of any one claimant that arise from the same occurrence may not be settled for an aggregate amount exceeding $100,000.00 without the approval of the city council. 
(Code 1988, § 2-544; Ord. No. 719, § 4.04, 11-28-1988; Ord. No. 1145, § 2, 11-24-1998) 
Sec. 2-1005. - Payment of noncovered claims. 
    Any claim that the city is legally obligated to pay that is not a program claim, may be paid by the city only at such times and from such sources of payment as are required by law. 
(Code 1988, § 2-545; Ord. No. 719, § 4.05, 11-28-1988) 
Secs. 2-1006-2-1023. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - ADMINISTRATION OF RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM 

Sec. 2-1024. - Risk manager. 
    The city manager or his or her designee shall administer a risk management program. 
(Code 1988, § 2-551; Ord. No. 719, § 5.01, 11-28-1988) 
Sec. 2-1025. - Program insurance. 
(a)  Insurance ("program insurance") may be obtained under the following circumstances: 
(1)  As excess coverage over that provided by the fund, as reinsurance for the fund, or as first-dollar coverage in lieu of that provided by the fund (which may result in converting coverage provided by the fund into excess coverage) if, in each case, the insurance is obtainable on a fiscally sound basis, giving consideration to the investment opportunities for the fund and any shock-loss exposure of the city due to the program risks; 
(2)  When services that are necessary to effectively administer the program can be obtained only through the obtaining of the insurance; 
(3)  When the city is required by contract or law to obtain the insurance, or 
(4)  When the limitations on coverage under the fund do not result in long-term economic advantage to the city, and the insurance obtained either does not contain, or offsets or reduces, such limitations. 
(b)  The procurement of program insurance shall be coordinated by the risk manager and approved by the city manager. 
(c)  Program insurance shall be obtained from sources determined to be in the best interests of the city. No particular insurance or financial quality rating is required, but the insurance provider must be in excellent financial condition as determined by the city finance director. 
(d)  When practicable, the remuneration of agents or brokers providing insurance services to the city pursuant to this article shall be on a fee basis. 
(Code 1988, § 2-552; Ord. No. 719, § 5.02, 11-28-1988) 
Secs. 2-1026-2-1048. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - OTHER PROGRAM PROVISIONS 

Sec. 2-1049. - Report to city council on program status. 
    The city manager, at least once annually, shall report to the city council on the status and experience of the program, including the financial status of the fund. 
(Code 1988, § 2-561; Ord. No. 719, § 6.01, 11-28-1988) 
Sec. 2-1050. - Alteration and termination of program. 
(a)  Subject to subsection (b) of this section, the city, by ordinance, may alter the program from time-to-time or terminate the program at any time without notice to any plan member or other person. 
(b)  The city, by agreement approved by the city council, may limit its right to alter or terminate the program. 
(Code 1988, § 2-562; Ord. No. 719, § 6.02, 11-28-1988) 
Sec. 2-1051. - Duration of program. 
    The program shall continue in effect until 5:00 p.m. on the termination date. 
(Code 1988, § 2-563; Ord. No. 719, § 6.03, 11-28-1988) 
Secs. 2-1052-2-1099. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - HIGHER EDUCATION AUTHORITY 

Sec. 2-1100. - Creation. 
    The city council hereby declares and finds that it is to the best interest of the city and its inhabitants to create a higher education authority and hereby creates the "City of Bryan Higher Education Authority" (the "authority"). 
(Code 1988, § 2-586; Ord. No. 976, § 1, 12-5-1995) 
Sec. 2-1101. - Board of directors. 
(a)  Membership. The board of directors of the authority shall consist of seven members, who are neither officers nor employees of the city. 
(b)  Term. Each member shall serve a term of two years. 
(c)  Appointment. The board of directors shall be appointed by resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1988, § 2-587; Ord. No. 976, § 2, 12-5-1995) 
Sec. 2-1102. - Powers. 
    All of the powers of the authority described in V.T.C.A., Education Code ch. 53, as amended, are hereby incorporated by reference. 
(Code 1988, § 2-588; Ord. No. 976, § 3, 12-5-1995) 
Sec. 2-1103. - Bonds. 
    The authority shall have the power to issue bonds as described in Subchapter C, Chapter 53, Texas Education Code (V.T.C.A., Education Code § 53.31 et seq., as amended), including such power for the benefit of the academy. 
(Code 1988, § 2-589; Ord. No. 976, § 4, 12-5-1995) 
Secs. 2-1104-2-1129. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - FINANCE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-1130. - Fiscal year. 
    The fiscal year of the city shall begin with October 1 of each year, and shall end with September 30 of the following year. 
(Code 1975, § 1-10; Code 1988, § 26-1) 
Charter reference- City may select fiscal year, § 12(d). 
Sec. 2-1131. - Electronic funds transfer. 
(a)  The city manager may cause to be established and operated in accordance with this section an electronic funds transfer system to transfer the following items directly into officer's and employees' accounts in financial institutions: 
(1)  The net pay of the officers and employees; 
(2)  Payments for the travel subsistence of the officers and employees; and 
(3)  All other forms of compensation, payment, or reimbursement paid to the officers and employees. 
(b)  An authorized payee must request in writing to participate in any electronic funds transfer system established hereunder. 
(c)  The city treasurer, or the equivalent local official with approval of the city council, shall establish the procedures for administering the system and may use the services of financial institutions, automated clearinghouses, and the federal government. 
(d)  A single transfer may contain payments to multiple payees without the necessity of issuing individual warrants for each payee. 
(e)  The use of an electronic funds transfers means of payment does not create any rights that would not have been created if an individual warrant had been used as a means of payment. 
(Code 1988, § 26-17; Ord. No. 752, § 1, 11-13-1989) 
Secs. 2-1132-2-1155. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PURCHASES[12] 

Footnotes:

Sec. 2-1156. - Expenditures for budgeted items. 
    Expenditures for budgeted items shall be made in accordance with state law, as amended from time-to-time. All contracts and purchases shall be handled in a manner to obtain the best value for the city and in accordance with LGC 252.043. 
(Ord. No. 1722, § 2, 10-23-2007) 
Charter reference- Finance generally, §§ 12, 13. 
Sec. 2-1157. - Expenditures for budgeted items not exceeding $50,000.00. 
    The city manager is authorized to make expenditures for budgeted items not exceeding $50,000.00 and all such expenditures shall be made in accordance with state law. 
(Ord. No. 1722, § 2, 10-23-2007) 
Sec. 2-1158. - Expenditures for budgeted items of over $50,000.00. 
(a)  All expenditures of funds for budgeted items in excess of $50,000.00 shall be made by the city council. 
(b)  Subject to the further restrictions stated herein, the city manager is authorized to expend funds in a cumulative amount of $50,000.00 or less if such expenditure is for the purpose of discharging an obligation that arises by reason of a contract which has already been approved by the city council. Such expenditures shall be reported to the city council on a periodic basis so that the city council is kept informed as to the progress toward completion of the particular contract. The city manager is authorized to approve any individual change order involving a decrease or an increase of $25,000.00 or less. The original contract price may not be increased by more than 25 percent. The original contract price may not be decreased by more than 25 percent without the consent of the contractor. 
(Ord. No. 1722, § 2, 10-23-2007) 
Sec. 2-1159. - Notice to bidders. 
    If the competitive sealed bidding or sealed proposal requirement applies to a contract, notice of the deadline for submission of bids and the time and place at which the bids will be publicly opened and read aloud must be published at least once in a newspaper as defined by the Texas Local Government Code or posted for at least 14 days on the city's internet website. The date of the publication or internet posting must be before the 14th day before the date set to publicly open the bids and read them aloud. 
(Ord. No. 1722, § 2, 10-23-2007) 
Sec. 2-1160. - Determination of the purchase method. 
    The city manager or designee is authorized to determine the purchase method for goods and services that provides the best value to the city in accordance with state law. 
(Ord. No. 1722, § 2, 10-23-2007) 
Chapter 3 - AIRPORT 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
DIVISION 1. - AIRPORT MANAGEMENT 

Sec. 3-1. - Airport director-Created; supervision. 
    The affairs of the airport shall be administered by an airport director who shall be an employee of the city, appointed by the city manager, and shall serve under the general supervision of the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
Sec. 3-2. - Same-Powers and duties. 
    The airport director shall oversee all airport operations and shall be in charge of the administrative duties pertaining to and connected with the management and operation of the Coulter Airfield Airport. The airport director shall make recommendations to the city manager and to the city council with reference to questions of policy regarding the operations and development of the airport and all aviation matters which affect the city and the airport, and shall perform such other duties as may be prescribed from time to time by the city manager or the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
Sec. 3-3. - Airport manager. 
    The airport manager shall be authorized by the city council to act as on-site manager of the airport, and shall have general control over the day-to-day operations of the airport and persons in, on or over it; as specified by contract with the city. The airport manager shall provide reports to, and take policy direction from, the airport director. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
Sec. 3-4. - Closing airport. 
    The airport manager may suspend or restrict any or all operations at the airport whenever such action is deemed necessary in the interest of safety. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
Sec. 3-5. - Conduct at airport; airport manager to have control. 
    The airport manager shall have the authority to remove aircraft or persons from the airport who are in violation of any of the rules and regulation set forth as provided herein. Any towing charges necessary to remove aircraft will be charged against the owner of such aircraft and, upon failure to pay, shall become a lien against that aircraft. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
Sec. 3-6. - Safeguard of persons and property. 
    The airport manager shall at all times have authority and responsibility to take such action as may be necessary to safeguard any person, aircraft, equipment or property at the airport. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
DIVISION 2. - DEFINITIONS 

Sec. 3-7. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms shall have the meaning respectively ascribed to them in this section. 
    Airport shall mean the Coulter Airfield Airport. 
    Airport director shall mean the administrative head of the Coulter Airfield Airport operations. The airport director shall be an employee of the city and the designee of the city manager, and shall serve under the general supervision of the city manager. 
    Airport manager shall mean the fixed base operator and on-site manager of the airport. 
    Airport rules and regulations shall mean these rules and regulations. 
    Airport tenant shall mean a person leasing or using airport property solely for the purpose of storing an aircraft and is not engaged in or providing any aviation related commercial activity or service at the airport. An airport tenant is not authorized to function as or to provide the services of an FBO. 
    City shall mean the City of Bryan, Texas and includes its employees, agents and designated representatives. 
    Commercial activity shall mean the buying or selling of any goods, products or services. 
    Commercial operator shall mean a person who provides for compensation, goods or services to the public on or from the airport. 
    FAA shall mean the Federal Aviation Administration. 
    FAR shall mean the Federal Aviation Regulations. 
    FBO shall mean fixed base operator. 
    Fixed base operator shall mean a primary commercial operator authorized to do business or to provide goods or services to the public for compensation on the airport property and meets at least the minimum requirements for an FBO set out in the minimum operating standards for commercial and noncommercial aeronautical activity at Coulter Airfield Airport. A copy of the minimum operating standards for Commercial and Noncommercial Aeronautical Activity Coulter Airfield Airport shall be on file with the city secretary and copies shall be available at the office of the airport director and the airport manager. 
    Flying club shall mean a not-for-profit membership organization consisting of six or more natural persons, operating for the purpose of providing flight instruction for its members only and/or providing aircraft for use by its members. 
    Fuel handling shall mean the transporting, delivering, dispensing, or draining of fuel, or draining of fuel waste products. 
    Line service shall mean the dispensing of aviation fuel, checking aircraft engine oil, adding aircraft engine oil, windshield cleaning, etc. 
    NOTAM shall mean an air traffic advisory or notice filed with an FAA Flight Service Station containing information concerning the establishment, condition or change in any aeronautical facility, service, procedure or hazard. 
    NTSB shall mean the National Transportation Safety Board. 
    Person shall mean any individual, firm, partnership, corporation, association or company. 
    SFBO shall mean a specialty fixed-base operator. 
    Specialty fixed-base operator shall mean a person other than an FBO who offers and/or provides for compensation to the public general aviation specialty services on the airport property, and meets at least the minimum requirement set out in the minimum operating standards for commercial and noncommercial aeronautical activity at Coulter Airfield Airport. A copy of the minimum operating standards for Coulter Airfield Airport shall be on file with the city secretary and copies shall be available at the office of the airport director and the airport manager. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
Secs. 3-8-3-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COULTER AIRFIELD AIRPORT-RULES AND REGULATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - USE OF AIRPORT RESTRICTED 

Sec. 3-11. - Use of airport restricted. 
    No person shall use the airport for any commercial activity, unless approved by a written permit from the city council or the airport director, as authorized by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
DIVISION 2. - GENERAL RULES AND REGULATIONS 

Sec. 3-12. - Article to contain rules and regulations for airport. 
    The provisions of this article contain rules and regulations to be observed in the use, operation, and conduct of said Coulter Airfield Airport. It shall be unlawful for any person to violate these provisions. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
Sec. 3-13. - Federal Aviation Administration rules adopted. 
    The federal air traffic rules promulgated by the Federal Aviation Administration for observance by aircraft operated anywhere in the United States, and presently or hereafter effective, are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof as though fully set forth and incorporated herein. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
Sec. 3-14. - Posting, distribution of article provisions. 
    The airport manager is directed to have copies of this article printed and posted where appropriate. Copies will be retained in the office of the airport manager for review by anyone during normal business hours, and copies will be furnished to airport tenants and operators of aircraft based on the airport. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
Sec. 3-15. - Resolution of conflicts. 
    If and where there is conflict in the provisions of this article and the Federal Aviation Rules (FAR's) the latter shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
Sec. 3-16. - Entry upon airport. 
    All persons entering upon airport property shall comply with the rules and regulations set forth herein. Unless specifically stated, no culpable mental state shall be required as an element of a violation of these rules and regulations. Further, any person desiring to use the airport shall observe and obey all valid laws, resolutions, orders, rules and regulations promulgated and enforced by the city or by any other authority having jurisdiction over the conduct and operation of the airport. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
Sec. 3-17. - Surreptitious activities. 
    Any person observing suspicious, unauthorized or criminal activities shall report such activities immediately to the airport manager, police, or officers of the department of public safety, or other peace officer. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
Sec. 3-18. - Wrecked aircraft. 
    Every aircraft owner, his pilot and agents, shall be responsible for notifying FAA and for the prompt removal from the operational areas of the airport, under the direction of the airport manager, of disabled or wrecked aircraft. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
Sec. 3-19. - Disabled aircraft. 
    Airport tenants may not store aircraft on the airport premises which do not satisfy one of the following conditions: 
(1)  Airworthy aircraft; 
(2)  FAA registered aircraft with airworthiness certificate in a continuing process of overhaul and/or repair; or 
(3)  Final assembly of aircraft in preparation for airworthiness certification. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
Sec. 3-20. - Repairs to aircraft. 
    No aircraft shall be repaired on any part of the landing or takeoff area. Persons causing damage to runway and taxiway lights, as a result of negligent operation of an aircraft or willful acts will be liable for replacement cost of the lights. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
Sec. 3-21. - Agricultural spraying operations. 
    Agricultural (Ag) spraying operations will be conducted in accordance with procedures approved by the airport manager and made known to all persons conducting agricultural spraying operations. Said operations shall be conducted only on the designated airport areas, and shall not include reckless flying or careless chemical handling. Chemicals used in agricultural operations shall be dispersed, maintained, and stored and the dispensing area shall be cleaned with all empty chemical containers stored and promptly disposed of in accordance with label directions. Washing of Ag aircraft and flushing of Ag aircraft spray tanks or hoppers will be accomplished in accordance with the standards of the Environmental Protection agency and the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality in an area so designated by the airport manager. Each Ag operator shall carry liability insurance in an amount approved by the city's risk management director for the clean up of any hazardous chemical spills on airport property caused by the Ag operator. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
Sec. 3-22. - Damage to airport. 
    Any person or the owner of any aircraft causing damage of any kind to the airport, whether through violation of any of these rules, through vandalism, or any act of negligence, shall be liable therefore in and to the city. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
Sec. 3-23. - Interference with aircraft. 
    No person shall interfere or tamper with any aircraft or its parts, or start the engine of any aircraft at the airport without the consent of the owner or operator or said aircraft. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
Sec. 3-24. - Radio interference. 
    No person shall operate equipment, radios or other devices on the airport that interferes with aircraft radio communications or any navigational aid. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
Sec. 3-25. - Injury to person. 
    Persons entering upon the airport ground side property by automobile, other vehicular conveyance, or pedestrian traffic (does not include persons in aircraft using approved air side facilities) do so at their own risk and with no liability incurring to the city for any injury or damage to risk and with no liability incurring to the city for any injury or damage to person or property. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
Sec. 3-26. - Licensed pilots. 
    Only properly registered aircraft and persons holding current airman and medical certificates issued by the FAA shall be authorized to operate aircraft upon the airport except as provided in this ordinance. This limitation shall not apply to students in training under licensed instructors nor to public aircraft of the federal government or of a state territory, or political subdivision thereof, or to aircraft licensed by a foreign government with which the United States has a reciprocal agreement covering the operation of such licensed aircraft. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
Sec. 3-27. - Registration. 
    Each person owning an aircraft based at the airport, employed, or receiving instruction at the airport shall register at the office of the airport manager their name, address, telephone number, aircraft model, aircraft registration "N" number, and the name, address, and telephone number of their next of kin or person to be notified in case of an accident or emergency. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
Sec. 3-28. - Intoxicants and narcotics prohibited. 
    No person under the influence of any intoxicant, narcotic, or other illicit drug shall operate or fly in any aircraft to or from the airport. Such prohibition shall not apply to a passenger under the care of a medical doctor and accompanied by a doctor, nurse, or caretaker. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
Sec. 3-29. - Foreign objects. 
    No foreign objects, including bottles, cans, scrap, nuts, bolts, nails, or any object that may cause damage to an aircraft, shall be left upon the surface of the air operations area of the airport. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
Sec. 3-30. - Garbage disposal. 
    No person shall place, discharge, or deposit in any manner, garbage or any refuse in or upon any part of the airport, except at such places and in such containers specifically designated and marked for such purpose and under such conditions as the airport manager may from time to time prescribe. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
Sec. 3-31. - Solicitation and advertising. 
    No person shall solicit funds, erect signs, advertise, distribute or post circulars on any part of the airport without written permission from the airport manager and only in compliance with city ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
Sec. 3-32. - Unauthorized structures. 
    No permanent or portable, buildings, structures or house trailers may be erected, moved in or installed on the airport property without approval of the Bryan City Council and must be in compliance with all city ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
Sec. 3-33. - Storage of cargo or other property. 
    No person shall use any area of the airport for the storage of cargo or other property without the permission of the airport manager. The airport manager may move or cause to be moved, any such cargo or property at the expense of the owner and with no liability to the city or its agent or employees for damages resulting from such removal. This section shall not apply to a lessee using property described by an executed lease agreement. 
(Ord. No. 1568, § 1, 1-10-2006) 
Sec. 3-34. - Fueling of aircraft-Safety regulations. 
(a)  All aircraft shall be gassed at the gas pump, or by truck on the ramp clear of all hangars, other buildings and aircraft by at least 50 feet, unless otherwise approved by airport manager and fire marshal. 
(b)  Aircraft authorized by the FAA to use auto gas may be privately fueled by the owner in a location designated by the airport manager and approved by the fire marshal in accordance with all rules pertaining to aircraft fueling and fire safety contained in this chapter. 
(c)  Aviation or auto fuels shall not be stored within a hangar or building except in small quantities, not to exceed five gallons, and in approved containers manufactured and marked for such purpose, and with the approval of the fire marshal. 
(d)  Public sale of automobile gas for use in aircraft will not be permitted on the airport without the written approval of the airport director. 
(e)  All aviation fuel storage tanks, aviation fuel pumps, hydrant fuel services, aircraft fuel service vehicles, whether publicly or privately owned, shall have the type of aviation fuel dispensed printed in large number, and "NO SMOKING" signs.
