ARTICLE XI. - COMPLIANCE AND ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 62-698. - Generally. 
(a)  Court action. On behalf of the city, the city attorney shall, when directed by the city council, institute appropriate action in a court of competent jurisdiction to enforce the provision of this chapter or the standards referred to herein with respect to any violation thereof which occurs within the city. 
(b)  Notice of alleged violation. Whenever the city manager or his or her designee determines that there are reasonable grounds to believe that there has been a violation of any provision of this chapter, he or she shall give notice of such alleged violation to the person to whom the permit or license was issued, as herein provided. Such notice shall: 
(1)  Be in writing. 
(2)  Include a statement of the reason for its issue. 
(3)  Allow a reasonable time for the performance of the act if required. 
(4)  Be served upon the owner or his or her agent as the case may require, provided that such notice or order shall be deemed to have been properly served upon such owner or agent when a copy thereof has been served with such notice by any method authorized or required by the laws of this state. 
(5)  Contain an outline of remedial action which, if taken, will effect compliance with the provisions of this section. 
(c)  Reinspection. At the end of such period as noted in section 62-698(b), the city manager or his or her designee shall reinspect the site and, if such conditions or practices have not been corrected they shall suspend any permits or certificates and give notice of such suspension, and such person shall cease activities. 
(Ord. No. 2110 , § 2, 8-25-2015) 
Sec. 62-699. - Penalties. 
    Any person violating any provision of this chapter, upon conviction, is punishable in accordance with the general penalty provisions of City Code section 1-14. 
(Ord. No. 2110 , § 2, 8-25-2015) 
Chapter 66 - LAW ENFORCEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal law enforcement, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 341. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 66-1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Per the city's instruction Ord. No. 1313, § 1, adopted Nov. 13, 2001, rescinded § 66-1, which pertained to field training officer assignment pay and derived from Code 1988, § 21-1; Ord. No. 1104, § adopted Feb. 24, 1998. 
Sec. 66-2. - Escort services provided by police department. 
(a)  Fee; staffing requirement. There shall be a fee assessed for all escort services provided by the police department. The fee amount shall be based on the staffing requirements of a requested escort, said staffing requirements to be determined by the chief of police or his or her designee. Staffing requirements shall be made on a case-by-case basis, taking into consideration traffic, weather, road conditions, anticipated size of procession, and anticipated duration of services, with the primary concern being public safety. In no case will the police department be obligated to perform an escort if the determination has been made that there is not sufficient personnel available to provide police services. 
(b)  Request; estimate of cost; billing. The police department will not be obligated to provide escort services unless the escort has been requested 24 hours prior to the date of the requested service. 
(c)  Waiver of fee. A waiver of the escort fee may be obtained if the requesting party: 
(1)  Is a law enforcement agency or other governmental entity; and 
(2)  Gives the police department three days' notice of the request. The three-days' notice requirement may be waived by the chief of police or his or her designee if he or she determines that said requirement would be contrary to the public interest. 
(d)  Fees set by resolution. The fees will be set by resolution of the city council of the city. 
(Code 1988, § 21-2; Ord. No. 1432, §§ 1-4, 9-9-2003; Ord. No. 1966, § 1, 8-28-2012) 
Secs. 66-3-66-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - INTERLOCAL ASSISTANCE 

Sec. 66-23. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Law enforcement officer shall mean any police officer, sheriff, deputy sheriff, constable, deputy constable, marshal or deputy marshal regularly employed by the city. 
(Code 1975, § 19-1; Code 1988, § 21-16) 
Sec. 66-24. - Authorization to chief of police. 
    The chief of police of this city is authorized to assign the regularly employed law enforcement personnel of his or her department to assist any other county, municipality or joint airport in this state, when a state of civil emergency in such other county, municipality or joint airport in this state has been declared by proper authority, upon request by such proper authority, and when, in the opinion of such proper authority, the need exists in such other county, municipality or joint airport, to protect its inhabitants, and the visitors thereto, by reason of riot, threat of concealed explosives, unlawful assembly characterized by the use of force and violence, or threat thereof by three or more persons acting together or without lawful authority, or during time of natural disaster or manmade calamity. 
(Code 1975, § 19-2; Code 1988, § 21-17) 
State Law reference- Interlocal assistance, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 362. 
Sec. 66-25. - Law enforcement officers assigned to this city. 
    Whenever any law enforcement officer of any other county, municipality or joint airport is assigned to this city, under authority of an order adopted by the governing body of such other county, municipality or joint airport, to assist under circumstances as described in section 66-24 which may exist in the city, such officer shall be a peace officer of this city and shall be under the command of the chief of police of this city, while so assigned, and he or she shall have all powers of a regular law enforcement officer of this city as fully as though he or she were within the county, municipality or joint airport where regularly employed and his or her qualifications, respectively, for office where regularly employed shall constitute his or her qualifications for office in this city, and no other oath, bond, or compensation shall be made. 
(Code 1975, § 19-3; Code 1988, § 21-18) 
Sec. 66-26. - Wage, salary and other benefits for service outside city. 
    When any law enforcement officer of this city is ordered by proper authority to perform peace officer duties outside the territorial limits of this city, he or she shall be entitled to the same wage, salary, pension, disability payments and all other compensation and all other rights for such service, including injury or death benefits, the same as though the service had been rendered within this city, and he or she shall also be paid for any reasonable expenses of travel, food, or lodging, as well as for damage to equipment and clothing, and medical expenses, which he or she may incur while on duty outside such limits, or while traveling to or from such assignment. 
(Code 1975, § 19-4; Code 1988, § 21-19) 
Secs. 66-27-66-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - POLICE RESERVE FORCE 

Sec. 66-56. - Established. 
    There is hereby established a police reserve force for the city. 
(Code 1975, § 19-6; Code 1988, § 21-36; Ord. No. 599, § 3(19-6), 1-13-1986) 
Sec. 66-57. - Appointment, tenure. 
    Members of the police reserve force shall be appointed and/or relieved at the discretion of the chief of police and shall serve as police officers during the actual discharge of official duties. 
(Code 1975, § 19-7; Code 1988, § 21-37; Ord. No. 599, § 3(19-7), 1-13-1986) 
Sec. 66-58. - Maximum number. 
    The police reserve force shall not exceed in number the total number of regular police officers authorized. 
(Code 1975, § 19-8; Code 1988, § 21-38; Ord. No. 599, § 3(19-8), 1-13-1986) 
Sec. 66-59. - Call to service. 
    Members of the police reserve force shall serve at the discretion of the chief of police and may be called into active service at any time the chief of police considers it necessary to have additional police officers to preserve the peace and enforce the law. 
(Code 1975, § 19-9; Code 1988, § 21-39; Ord. No. 599, § 3(19-9), 1-13-1986) 
Sec. 66-60. - Status of members. 
    Members of the police reserve force may serve without compensation. Uniforms and uniform compensation may be provided to the reserve police officers at the discretion of the chief of police. The uniform compensation shall be based solely upon time served by the member of the police reserve while in training for or in the performance of official duties. The city may provide hospital and medical assistance to members of the police reserve force who sustain injury in the course of performing official duties, in the same manner as provided by the city for its fulltime police officers, and reserve officers shall be eligible for death benefits as set out in V.T.C.A., Government Code ch. 615; provided, however, that nothing in this section shall be construed to authorize or permit a member of the police reserve force to become eligible for participation in any pension fund created pursuant to state statute, to which regular officers may become a member by payroll deductions or otherwise. Reserve police officers shall act only in a supplementary capacity to the regular police force and shall in no case assume the fulltime duties of regular police officers. 
(Code 1975, § 19-10; Code 1988, § 21-40; Ord. No. 599, § 3(19-10), 1-13-1986) 
Sec. 66-61. - Special police force not limited. 
    This article shall not limit the power of the mayor to summon into service a special police force as provided by state law. 
(Code 1975, § 19-11; Code 1988, § 21-41; Ord. No. 599, § 3(19-11), 1-13-1986) 
Sec. 66-62. - Qualifications. 
(a)  Reserve police officers must comply with the minimum training standards established by the state commission on law enforcement officer standards and education for all reserve law enforcement officers identical to the standards so established which must be fulfilled before a person appointed as a reserve law enforcement officer may carry a weapon or otherwise act as a peace officer. The chief of police shall establish qualifications and standards of training for members of the police reserve force and shall establish rules and regulations governing reserve police officers. 
(b)  The chief of police may establish minimum physical, mental, educational and moral standards as used by the regular police services division, but in no case shall the standards be less than that established by the state commission on law enforcement officer standards and education. 
(Code 1975, § 19-12; Code 1988, § 21-42; Ord. No. 599, § 3(19-12), 1-13-1986) 
Sec. 66-63. - Misrepresentation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to wear, carry or display a police reserve identification card or otherwise represent himself or herself to be connected with the police reserve unless he or she is in fact a member thereof in good standing. 
(Code 1975, § 19-13; Code 1988, § 21-43; Ord. No. 599, § 3(19-13), 1-13-1986) 
Chapter 70 - LIBRARY 

Sec. 70-1. - Failure to return library materials. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if he or she intentionally or knowingly fails to return library materials to the Bryan Public Library, which were loaned to the actor or borrowed in the actor's name. 
(b)  The actor's intent and knowledge shall be presumed if: 
(1)  Pursuant to agreement, the library materials were to be returned on a date specified; 
(2)  Actual notice is given or notice in writing is sent by depositing in the United States mail stating that the library materials were not returned on the date specified, the notice when mailed to be sent to the address shown on the records of the library; and 
(3)  The library material is not returned to the owner within 20 days of receipt of such notice. 
(c)  If notice is sent by mail in accordance with subsection (b)(2) of this section, it is presumed that the notice was received no later than five days after it was sent. 
(d)  In prosecution under this section, it is no defense that the actor, though the actual borrower, no longer possesses the library materials. 
(Code 1975, § 17-13; Code 1988, § 17-6) 
Chapter 74 - MANUFACTURED HOUSING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Texas Manufactured Housing Standards Act, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code ch. 1201; regulation by municipality, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code § 1201.008. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 74-1. - Rules of construction and definitions. 
(a)  Rules of construction. For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meanings ascribed to them: 
The word "should" is suggestive. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Accessory building shall mean any building customarily incidental to the principal building, which may include a garage, porch, storage, toolshed or workshed. 
    Chief building official shall mean the chief building official of the city or his or her duly authorized representative charged with the administration and enforcement of this chapter. 
    Health authority shall mean the state department of health or county health official. 
    License shall mean an authorization, or written evidence thereof, issued by the city to maintain and operate a manufactured/mobile home park. 
    Manufactured home shall mean a structure, constructed on or after June 15, 1976, according to the rules of the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, transportable in one or more sections, which in the traveling mode, is eight body feet or more in width or 40 body feet or more in length, or, when erected on site, is 320 or more square feet, and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities, and includes the plumbing, heating, air conditioning and electrical systems, and does not include a recreational vehicle as defined by 24 CFR 3282.8(g). 
    Manufactured/mobile home lot shall mean a parcel of land designated within a manufactured/mobile home park and on its park plan for the placement of a single manufactured/mobile home and the exclusive use of its occupants. 
    Manufactured/mobile home park shall mean any lot, block, tract or parcel of contiguous lots, blocks, tracts or parcels of land, under common ownership, which has been so designed and improved that it contains two or more manufactured/mobile homes or manufactured/mobile home lots available for lease or rent to the public and for the placement of mobile homes and/or manufactured homes for occupancy. 
    Manufactured/mobile home stand shall mean that part of a manufactured/mobile home park which has been improved for the placement of one manufactured/mobile home including all required appurtenant structures and having provisions for available utility connections. 
    Mobile home shall mean a structure that was constructed before June 15, 1976, transportable in one or more sections, which, in the travel mode, is eight body feet or more in width, 40 body feet or more in length, or, when erected on site is 320 or more square feet, and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities and includes the plumbing, heating, air conditioning, and electrical systems. 
    Nonconformities shall mean lots, structures, uses of land and structures and characteristics of uses, which are prohibited under the terms of article III of this chapter. They may be permitted to continue under the conditions of article II of this chapter unless there is a compelling reason, such as imminent danger to health, to eliminate the nonconformity. 
    Park management shall mean the person who owns or has charge, care or control of the manufactured/mobile home park. 
    Parking space shall mean a minimum space nine feet in width by 18 feet in length located entirely within the boundaries of a manufactured/mobile home lot to accommodate an automobile. 
    Permanent buildings shall mean buildings or structures permanently affixed to foundations and not including mobile or manufactured homes, or accessory buildings on manufactured/mobile home lots. 
    Permit shall mean an authorization, and written evidence thereof, issued by the city to construct, alter and extend a manufactured/mobile home park or to move or relocate a mobile home or manufactured home. 
    Recreational vehicle shall mean a vehicle type portable structure without a permanent foundation, which can be towed, hauled or driven and primarily designed as temporary living accommodation for recreational, camping and travel use and including but not limited to travel trailers, truck campers, camping trailers and self-propelled motor homes. 
    Sewer connection shall mean all pipes, fittings and appurtenances from the drain outlet of the manufactured/mobile home to the inlet of the corresponding sewer riser pipe of the sewage system serving the manufactured/mobile home park. 
    Street shall mean any street, area, avenue, boulevard, drive, public place or highway designed for or commonly used for the purpose of travel by vehicles within the corporate limits of the city. Distinctions are made in this chapter between public streets, which are those outside the boundaries of the manufactured/mobile home park, and private streets, which are those within the manufactured/mobile home park. 
    Trailer shall mean a structure standing on wheels, towed or hauled by another vehicle and used for short-term human occupancy, carrying materials, goods or objects, or as a temporary office. 
    Travel trailer shall mean a recreational vehicle that is towed by a car or a truck. 
    Water connection shall mean the construction consisting of all pipes, fittings and appurtenances from the water riser pipe to the water inlet pipe of the distribution system within the manufactured/mobile home. 
    Water riser pipe shall mean that portion of the water supply system serving the manufactured/mobile home park which extends vertically to the ground elevation and terminates at a designated point at each manufactured/mobile home lot. 
(Code 1975, § 15-1; Code 1988, § 16-1; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. I, § 4), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-2. - General authority. 
    The provisions of this chapter are adopted under the authority of the constitution and laws of the state. Regulation of the development, construction, expansion and/or alteration of manufactured/mobile home parks and the attachment of reasonable conditions to such activities are exercises of valid police powers delegated by the state through state law and further authorized in the Charter. The developer has the duty of compliance with reasonable conditions laid down by the city for design, dedication, and improvement of the land so as to conform to the safety and general welfare of the park residents and the community at large. 
(Code 1988, § 16-2; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. I, § 2), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-3. - Scope and purpose. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall govern the establishment and operation of all manufactured/mobile home parks within the corporate limits of the city and its extraterritorial jurisdiction. 
(Code 1988, § 16-3; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. I, § 3), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-4. - Enforcement. 
    On behalf of the city, the city attorney shall, when directed by the city council, institute appropriate action in a court of competent jurisdiction to enforce the provisions of this chapter or the standards referred to herein with respect to any violation thereof which occurs. 
(Code 1988, § 16-4; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. I, § 16), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-5. - Administrative authority for modification of application requirements. 
    When justified in special circumstances as determined by the director of development services or his or her designee (director), the director is authorized to modify the content or review procedures for applications and associated documents required by this chapter, and as provided in section 62-82. 
(Code 1988, § 16-5; Ord. No. 1025, § 2, 10-8-1996) 
Secs. 74-6-74-28. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MANUFACTURED OR MOBILE HOME REGULATIONS 

Sec. 74-29. - Use restricted. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to connect utilities to or to occupy a trailer, travel trailer, recreational vehicle, mobile home or manufactured housing in a manufactured/mobile home park within the limits of the city unless the park is duly licensed under the terms of this chapter. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to occupy a manufactured/mobile home other than as a private dwelling, provided; however, that a mobile home or manufactured home may be parked at a construction site for use as a field office for a period not exceeding the period of construction. Provided further that not more than one mobile home or manufactured home may be connected to city utilities if used for demonstration and as an office at a manufactured/mobile home sale lot. 
(c)  Specifically permitted uses are as follows, although this list is not exclusive: 
(1)  Manufactured/mobile homes as single-family dwelling units. 
(2)  Open space in the park for recreational purposes. 
(3)  Home occupation unless otherwise prohibited by specific technical codes or specific ordinance. 
(d)  Specifically recognized and permitted accessory uses are as follows: 
(1)  Park management office. 
(2)  Community or recreation building. 
(3)  Laundry building. 
(4)  Service equipment or action building. 
(5)  Storage facility. 
(Code 1975, § 15-2; Code 1988, § 16-21; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. I, § 5), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-30. - Utility services. 
(a)  The city shall not provide electric, water or sewer service to the site of the manufactured/mobile home park until a license has been granted and a certificate of occupancy has been issued by the city manager and/or his or her designee. 
(b)  Water, sewer, and electric service shall be provided in accordance with applicable codes and regulations adopted by the city and in force at the time of park plan approval. 
(c)  All placement, construction, expansion, etc., of units and/or parks shall comply with all applicable codes regarding construction, natural gas, liquefied petroleum gas, fuel oil, fire protection (extinguishers), all other applicable city ordinances and state laws and stormwater management. 
(Code 1975, § 15-3; Code 1988, § 16-22; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. I, § 6), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-31. - Park permits. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to place, construct, or extend any manufactured/mobile home park within the city limits unless a plan for the park has been approved by the city planning and zoning commission and unless that person holds a valid permit issued by the city in the name of such person for the specific construction, alteration or extension proposed. 
(b)  Application. All applications for permits required by this section shall contain the following: 
(1)  A written request by applicant containing name and address of applicant. 
(2)  Location and legal description of the manufactured/mobile home park. 
(3)  Plans and specifications of the alteration to the water supply and sewerage disposal facilities. 
(4)  A revised manufactured/mobile home park plan. 
(5)  Plans and specifications of roadways, walkways, driveways and parking areas. 
(6)  A complete plat or layout of the manufactured/mobile home park drawn in India ink on tracing linen or stable base film sheets 24 inches wide and 30 inches long, with a bonding margin of not less than 11/2 inches on the left side of the sheet and margins on the three other sides of not less than three-fourths inch. The plat shall be drawn to a scale of 100 feet to one inch. When more than one sheet is necessary to accommodate the entire area, an index sheet showing the entire park area at an appropriate graphic scale shall be attached to the plat. The plat shall show, but not be limited to, the following: 
a.  Names and addresses of the record owner, engineer and/or surveyor. 
b.  The area and dimensions of the tract of land. 
c.  The park boundary lines indicated by heavy lines. 
d.  The number, location, and size of all manufactured/home lots with a number or letter to identify each lot or site. The size of manufactured/mobile homes on the lots, length and width, by lot number. 
e.  The location and width of roadways, walkways, driveways and parking areas. 
f.  The location of water, sewer, gas, and telephone lines and any utility riser pipes. 
g.  Date of preparation, scale of plat and north point. 
h.  Location of city limits line, the outer border of the city's extraterritorial jurisdiction, and boundaries, if they traverse the park, form part of the boundary of the park, or are contiguous to such boundary. 
i.  Vicinity sketch or key map on the plat at a smaller scale approved by the division manager of municipal development. 
j.  The location, dimensions, description, and flow line of existing watercourses and drainage structures within the park or on contiguous tracts. 
k.  The location and details of lighting and electrical systems. 
l.  The setback lines on all lots and sites with respect to property lines and roadways. 
(c)  Fee. All applications shall be accompanied by the deposit fee, the amount of which is on file in the planning and development services office. 
(d)  Issuance. When, upon review of the application, the chief building official is satisfied that the proposed plan meets the requirements of this chapter, a permit shall be issued. 
(e)  Hearing on denial. Any person whose application for a permit under this chapter has been denied or unreasonably delayed may request and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the planning commission under the procedure provided by this chapter. 
(Code 1988, § 16-23; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. I, § 7), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-32. - Permits for manufactured/mobile home units in parks. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to place, construct, or extend a manufactured/mobile home in a manufactured/mobile home park unless that person holds a valid permit issued by the inspections division in the name of such person for the specific placement, construction, alteration or extension proposed. 
(b)  Application. All applications for permits required by this section shall be on a form provided by the city and shall be accompanied by or have already on file with the inspections division approved master plans and licenses as provided for in this chapter. The inspections division shall review permit applications and inspect the premises to determine that the same comply with this chapter and any other applicable codes and ordinances relative to location, construction, arrangement, safety and sanitary facilities of the manufactured/mobile home. 
(Code 1988, § 16-24; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. I, § 7A), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-33. - Licenses. 
(a)  Application and renewal. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any manufactured/mobile home park within the limits of the city unless he or she holds a valid license issued annually by the chief building official in the name of such person for the specific manufactured/mobile home park. All applications for licenses shall be made to the chief building official who shall issue a license upon compliance by the applicant with provisions of this chapter. Application for original licenses shall be in writing, signed by the applicant, accompanied by an affidavit of the applicant as to the truth of the application and by the deposit of a fee and shall contain at a minimum; the name and address of the applicant; the location and legal description of the manufactured/mobile home park; and a master plan of the manufactured/mobile home park. Applications for renewals of licenses shall be made in writing by the holders of the licenses, shall be accompanied by the deposit fee plus a fee for each lot added since the last license renewal which fees are on file in the city secretary's office, and shall contain any change in the information submitted since the original license was issued or the latest renewal granted. 
(b)  Transfer. Every person holding a license shall give notice in writing to the chief building official within 72 hours after having sold, transferred, given away, or otherwise disposed of interest in or control of any manufactured/mobile home park. Such notice shall include the name and address of the person succeeding to the ownership or control of such license and the deposit of a fee, the amount of which is on file in the planning and development services office. The license shall be transferred if the manufactured/mobile home park is in compliance with all applicable provisions of this chapter. When asked to do so by the park owner, the chief building official or his or her agent shall issue a letter or certificate of compliance within 30 days of the date of such request certifying that the park is legally operating under this chapter if the park owner holds a valid license, and that the park could continue to operate if sold and the new owner would be eligible to apply for a new license or a renewal of its current license. The park owner shall pay to the city a fee for such letter or certificate of compliance in an amount equal to the actual cost to the city for employee time and equipment used in verifying the facts necessary to issue such letter or certificate. The fee shall be due and payable upon billing sent by the city to the park owner's address as required by law. 
(c)  Denial or suspension. Any person whose application for a license under this chapter has been denied may request and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the planning commission under the procedure provided by this chapter. Whenever, upon inspection of any manufactured/mobile home park, the chief building official finds that conditions or practices exist which are in violation of any provision of this chapter, the chief building official shall give notice in writing in accordance with section 74-35 to the person to whom the license was issued that unless such conditions or practices are corrected within a reasonable period of time specified in the notice by the chief building official, the license shall be suspended. At the end of such period, the chief building official shall reinspect such manufactured/mobile home park, and if such conditions or practice have not been corrected, he or she shall suspend the license and give notice in writing of such suspension to the person to whom the license is issued. Upon receipt of notice of suspension, such person shall cease operation of such manufactured/mobile home park except as provided in section 74-35. 
(Code 1988, § 16-25; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. I, § 8), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-34. - Inspection of manufactured/mobile home parks. 
(a)  The chief building official or his or her agent is hereby authorized to make such inspections as are necessary to determine satisfactory compliance with this chapter and shall have the power to enter at a reasonable time upon any private or public property for the purpose of inspecting and investigating conditions relating to the enforcement of this chapter. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of park management to give access to the park register and to all lots during normal business hours to the chief building official or his or her agent for the purpose of inspection. 
(Code 1988, § 16-26; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. I, § 9), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-35. - Compliance. 
(a)  Notices. Whenever the chief building official or his or her agent determines that there are reasonable grounds to believe that there has been a violation of any provision of this chapter, he shall give notice of such alleged violation to the person to whom the permit or license was issued as hereinafter provided. Such notice shall. 
(1)  Be in writing. 
(2)  Include a statement of the reasons for its issuance. 
(3)  Allow a reasonable time for the performance of any act it requires. 
(4)  Be served upon the owner or his or her agent as the case may require, provided that such notice or order shall be deemed to have been properly served upon such owner or agent when a copy thereof has been sent by registered or certified mail to his or her last known address, or when he or she has been served with such notice by any method authorized by the laws of this state. 
(5)  Contain an outline of remedial action which, if taken, will effect compliance with this chapter. 
(b)  Appeal. 
(1)  Any person adversely affected by a notice which has been issued in connection with the enforcement of any provision of this chapter, may request and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the planning commission, provided that such person shall file in the office of the chief building official a written petition requesting a hearing and setting forth a brief statement of the grounds therefor within ten days after the day the notice was served. 
(2)  The filing of the request for a hearing shall operate as a stay of the suspension. 
(3)  Upon receipt of such petition, the chief building official shall coordinate with the chair of the planning commission to set the time for the hearing and shall give the petitioner written notice thereof. At the hearing the petitioner shall be given an opportunity to be heard and to show why the notice should be modified or withdrawn. The hearing shall be commenced not later than ten days after the day on which the petition was filed, provided that the chair of the planning commission may postpone the date of the hearing for a reasonable time when in his or her judgment good and sufficient reasons for the postponement exist. 
(c)  Orders. 
(1)  After the hearing the planning commission shall make findings as to compliance with the provisions of this chapter and shall issue 1022 an order in writing sustaining, modifying or withdrawing the notice which shall be served as provided herein. Upon failure to comply with any order sustaining or modifying a notice, the license of the manufactured/mobile home park affected by the order shall be revoked. 
(2)  The minutes of the hearing, including the findings and decision of the planning commission, and together with a copy of every notice and order related thereto shall be entered as a matter of public record in the office of the chief building official. 
(3)  Whenever the chief building official finds that an emergency exists which requires immediate action to protect the public health, he or she may without notice or hearing issue an order reciting the existence of such an emergency and requiring that certain action be taken as he or she may deem necessary to meet the emergency including the suspension of the permit or license. Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, such order shall be effective immediately. Any person to whom such an order is directed shall comply therewith immediately, but upon petition to the chief building official shall be afforded a hearing as soon as possible. The provisions of this chapter shall be applicable to such hearing and the order issued thereafter. 
(Code 1988, § 16-27; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. I, § 10), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-36. - Variances. 
(a)  General. The planning commission may authorize a variance from these regulations when, in its opinion, undue hardship will result from requiring strict compliance. In granting a variance, the planning commission shall prescribe only conditions that it deems necessary to or desirable in the public interest. In making the findings hereinbelow required, the planning commission shall take into account the nature of the proposed uses of the land involved, existing uses of land in the vicinity, the number of persons who will reside or work in the proposed manufactured/mobile home park, and the probable effect of such variance upon traffic conditions and upon the public health safety, convenience and welfare in the vicinity. 
(b)  Grant. No variance shall be granted unless the planning commission finds that: 
(1)  There are special circumstances or conditions affecting the land involved such that the strict application of the provisions of this chapter would deprive the applicant of the reasonable use of the land; and 
(2)  The granting of the variance will not be detrimental to the public health, safety or welfare, or injurious to other property in the area. 
(c)  Findings. Such findings of the planning commission, together with the specific facts upon which findings are based, shall be incorporated into the official minutes of the planning commission meeting at which such variance is granted. Variances may be granted only when in harmony with the general purpose and intent of this chapter so that the public health, safety and welfare may be secured and substantial justice done. 
(Code 1988, § 16-28; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. I, § 10A), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-37. - Revision of plan after approval. 
    No changes, erasures, modifications or revisions shall be made in any plan of a manufactured/mobile home park after approval of it has been given by the planning commission, unless the change, modification or revision is first submitted to and approved by the planning commission. 
(Code 1988, § 16-29; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. I, § 11), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-38. - Water supply. 
(a)  General requirements. All manufactured/mobile home parks subject to this chapter shall use the water service provided by the city. 
(b)  Individual water riser pipes and connections. Individual water riser pipes shall be located within the confined area of the manufactured/mobile home stand at a point where the water connection will approximate a vertical position and shall include a cut-off valve before entering the manufactured/mobile home. 
(Code 1988, § 16-30; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. I, § 12), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-39. - Sewage disposal. 
(a)  General requirements. An adequate and safe sewage system shall be provided in all manufactured/mobile home parks for conveying and disposing of all sewage. Such system shall be designed, constructed and maintained in accordance with state and local laws. 
(b)  Sewer lines. All sewer lines shall be located in trenches of sufficient depth to be free of breakage from traffic or other movements and shall be separated from the manufactured/mobile home park water supply system by a safe distance as approved by the plumbing inspector. Sewers shall be at a grade which will ensure a velocity of two feet per second when flowing full. All sewer lines shall be constructed of materials approved by the plumbing inspector, shall be adequately vented, and shall have watertight joints. 
(c)  Individual sewer connections. 
(1)  Each manufactured/mobile home stand shall be provided with at least a four-inch diameter sewer riser pipe. The sewer riser pipe shall be so located on each stand that the sewer connection to the manufactured/mobile home drain outlet will approximate a vertical position. 
(2)  The sewer connection shall have a nominal inside diameter of at least three inches, and the slope of any portion thereof shall be at least one-fourth inch per foot. The sewer connection shall consist of one pipeline without any branch fittings. All joints shall be watertight. 
(3)  All materials used for sewer connections shall be semirigid, corrosive resistant, nonabsorbent and durable. The inner surface shall be smooth. 
(4)  Provision shall be made for using a Fernco rubber adaptor, or equivalent, with cap, for connecting the mobile home to riser pipe and for plugging the sewer riser pipe when a manufactured home does not occupy the lot. Surface drainage shall be diverted away from the riser. The rim of the riser pipe shall extend at least two inches aboveground elevation. 
(Code 1988, § 16-31; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. I, § 13), 2-9-1987; Ord. No. 781, § 1, 10-8-1990) 
Sec. 74-40. - Electrical distribution system. 
(a)  General requirements. Every manufactured/mobile home park and every manufactured/mobile home shall contain an electrical wiring system consisting of wiring, fixtures, equipment, and appurtenances which shall be installed and maintained in accordance with the city electrical code and the current edition of the National Electrical Code governing such systems and approved by the electrical inspector. 
(b)  Power distribution lines. 
(1)  Main power lines not located underground shall be suspended at least 18 feet above the ground. There shall be a minimum horizontal clearance of three feet between overhead wiring and any manufactured/mobile home, service building or other structure. 
(2)  Outlets (receptacles or pressure connectors) shall be housed in a weatherproof outlet box, and shall be located not more than 25 feet from the over current protective device in the manufactured/mobile home. A three-pole, four-wire grounding type shall be used. 
(3)  Receptacles, if provided, shall be in accordance with American Standard Outlet Receptacle C73.1. 
(4)  Connectors, if not substituted by more than one receptacle, shall be provided where the calculated load of the manufactured/mobile home is more than 50 amperes. 
(5)  The manufactured/mobile home shall be connected to the outlet box by an approved type of flexible supply cord with a male attachment plug or with pressure connectors. 
(c)  Required grounding. All exposed noncurrent carrying metal parts of manufactured/mobile homes and all other equipment shall be grounded by means of an approved grounding conductor with branch circuit conductors or other approved method of grounded metallic wiring. 
(Code 1975, § 15-14; Code 1988, § 16-32; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. I, § 14), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-41. - Fire protection. 
(a)  Manufactured/mobile home parks shall be kept free of litter, rubbish and other flammable materials. 
(b)  Portable fire extinguishers rated for classes B and C fires shall be kept in service buildings and maintained in good operating condition. Their rating shall not be less than six BC (Underwriters' Laboratories, Inc., rating). 
(Code 1975, § 15-14; Code 1988, § 16-33; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. I, § 15), 2-9-1987) 
Secs. 74-42-74-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MANUFACTURED/MOBILE HOME PARKS OPERATING OR IN EXISTENCE PRIOR TO JANUARY 1, 1987 

Sec. 74-71. - Site drainage requirements. 
    The ground surface in all parts of every manufactured/mobile home park shall be graded and equipped to drain all surface water in a safe, efficient manner. 
(Code 1988, § 16-51; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. II, § 1(A)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-72. - Areas for nonresident uses. 
(a)  No part of any park shall be used for nonresidential purposes, except such uses that are required for the direct servicing and well-being of park residents and for the management and maintenance of the park. 
(b)  Nothing contained in this article shall be deemed as prohibiting the sale of a manufactured/mobile home located on a manufactured/mobile home stand and connected to the pertinent utilities. 
(Code 1988, § 16-52; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. II, § 1(B)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-73. - Separation between manufactured/mobile homes. 
    Manufactured/mobile homes shall be separated from each other by 15 feet and from other buildings by at least ten feet; provided that manufactured/mobile homes placed end-to-end may have a clearance of ten feet where opposing rear walls are staggered. 
(Code 1988, § 16-53; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. II, § 1(C)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-74. - Recreation areas. 
(a)  In all parks accommodating or designed to accommodate 25 or more manufactured/mobile homes there shall be one or more recreation areas which shall be easily accessible to all park residents. 
(b)  The size of such recreation areas shall be based upon a minimum of 100 square feet for each lot. No outdoor recreation area shall contain less than 2,500 square feet. 
(c)  Recreation areas shall be so located as to be free of traffic hazards and shall, where the topography permits, be centrally located. 
(d)  If there is a public recreation area within two miles of the park, then and in that event no park recreation area as defined herein shall be required. 
(Code 1988, § 16-54; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. II, § 1(D)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-75. - Setbacks, buffer strips and screening. 
(a)  All manufactured/mobile homes shall be located at least 25 feet from any manufactured/mobile home park property boundary line abutting upon a major public street or highway as defined in the major thoroughfare plan, and at least five feet from other manufactured/mobile home park property boundary lines. 
(b)  There shall be a minimum distance of five feet between the manufactured/mobile home stand and abutting manufactured/mobile home park street. 
(c)  All manufactured/mobile home parks located adjacent to industrial or commercial land uses shall be provided with screening such as fences or natural growth along the property boundary line separating the manufactured/mobile home park and such adjacent nonresidential uses. 
(d)  Accessory buildings shall be located so as to comply with the fire code. 
(Code 1988, § 16-55; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. II, § 1(E)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-76. - Street system and car parking-General requirements. 
    All manufactured/mobile home parks shall be provided with safe and convenient vehicular access from abutting public streets or roads to each manufactured/mobile home lot. Such access shall be provided by streets, driveways or other means. 
(Code 1988, § 16-56; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. II, § 1(F)(1)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-77. - Same-Park entrance. 
    Entrances to manufactured/mobile home parks shall be designed to minimize congestion and hazards and allow free movement of traffic on adjacent streets. No parking shall be permitted on the manufactured/mobile home park entrance street for a distance of 100 feet from its point of beginning, unless the manufactured/mobile home park entrance is at least 34 feet wide. 
(Code 1988, § 16-57; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. II, § 1(F)(2)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-78. - Same-Internal streets. 
    Surfaced roadways shall be of adequate width to accommodate anticipated traffic, and in any case shall meet the following minimum requirements: 
(1)  All streets, 20 feet. 
(2)  Dead-end streets shall end with a turnaround having an outside roadway diameter of at least 80 feet. 
(Code 1988, § 16-58; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. II, § 1(F)(3)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-79. - Same-Car parking. 
(a)  Off-street parking areas or on-street parking lanes shall be provided for the use of park occupants and guests. Such areas shall: 
(1)  Be furnished at a rate of at least 11/4 car spaces for each manufactured/mobile home lot. 
(2)  Be located within a distance of 200 feet from the manufactured/mobile home to be served, unless other vehicular access is provided. 
(b)  The minimum street width requirement shall be increased by eight feet if on-street parking is the only type of car parking provided in a manufactured/mobile home park. 
(Code 1988, § 16-59; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. II, § 1(F)(4)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-80. - Required illumination of street systems. 
    All manufactured/mobile home parks shall be furnished with lighting units so spaced and equipped as will provide levels of illumination for the safe movement of pedestrians and vehicles at night. 
(Code 1988, § 16-60; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. II, § 1(F)(5)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-81. - Street construction, design standards. 
    All streets shall be provided with a smooth, hard and dense surface which shall be durable and well drained under normal use and weather conditions. 
(Code 1988, § 16-61; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. II, § 1(F)(6)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-82. - Stands. 
    The area of the manufactured/mobile home stand shall be improved to provide adequate support for the placement and tie-down of the manufactured/mobile home, thereby securing the superstructure against uplift, sliding, rotation and overturning. 
(Code 1988, § 16-62; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. II, § 1(G)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-83. - Responsibilities of the park management. 
(a)  The person to whom a license for a manufactured/mobile home park is issued shall operate the manufactured home park in compliance with this chapter and shall provide adequate supervision to maintain the manufactured/mobile home park, its facilities and equipment in good repair and in a clean and sanitary condition. The manufactured/mobile home park management shall notify park occupants of all applicable provisions of this chapter and inform them of their duties and responsibilities under this chapter. 
(b)  The manufactured/mobile home park management shall supervise the placement of each manufactured/mobile home on its manufactured/mobile home stand. 
(c)  The manufactured/mobile home park management shall maintain a register containing the names of all manufactured/mobile home park occupants identified by lot number or street address. Such register shall be available to any authorized person inspecting the manufactured/mobile home park. 
(Code 1988, § 16-63; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. II, § 2(A)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-84. - Responsibilities of park occupants. 
(a)  The manufactured/mobile home park occupant shall comply with all applicable requirements of this chapter and shall maintain his or her manufactured/mobile home lot, its facilities and equipment in good repair and in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(b)  The manufactured/mobile home park occupant shall be responsible for proper placement of his or her manufactured/mobile home on its stand and proper installation of all utility connections in accordance with the city requirements. 
(c)  The occupant shall ensure that an address identifier is affixed to his or her manufactured/mobile home so that emergency personnel in responding to a call for help can locate the home. 
(Code 1988, § 16-64; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. II, § 2(B)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-85. - Master park plan/licensing requirements special provision. 
    Notwithstanding, anything in this chapter to the contrary, the following provisions apply: 
(1)  During the period January 1, 1987, through and to March 31, 1988, all manufactured/mobile home parks in the city which were in operation or existence prior to January 1, 1987, shall submit a new master park plan in accordance with section 74-31, if a plan acceptable to the city is not already on file, to the planning commission and shall apply for a license to operate in accordance with section 74-33 within 90 days of the effective date of the ordinance from which this section was derived, the city manager or his or her designee shall review the master plans of all manufactured/mobile home parks licensed to operate in the city and shall notify the owners of such parks as to the acceptability/unacceptability of the master plans on file. This notice shall be sent by registered or certified mail to each park owner or his or her agent and shall also state what action must be taken by the park owner to meet the plan submittal requirements of the city. 
(2)  The city manager or his or her designee shall also notify the park owners by regular mail of the calendar quarter in the hereinabove time period within which they should expect to receive their relicensing notice. Drawings and license applications shall be submitted within 90 days of the owner's notification by the city. 
(3)  Upon completion of the review of the drawing and application submitted in accordance with this law if the city manager or his or her designee shall have identified a situation which is an immediate or potential serious hazard to the public welfare, the city manager or his or her designee shall make an on-site inspection of the manufactured/mobile home park to confirm that such a hazard exists. Upon confirmation, written notice shall be provided the manufactured/mobile home park owner, operator, or his or her representative and he or she shall take immediate action to correct the hazard to the satisfaction of the city within 90 days or sooner if possible. A new manufactured/mobile home park license shall not be issued unless and until such condition has been corrected. If the hazard is one of immediate peril, the city may take such action as is deemed necessary to protect the public. 
(4)  At any time a manufactured/mobile home park operating or existing before January 1, 1987, reaches a lot compliance rate such that 65 percent of its lots fail to comply with this article then, and in that event, the manufactured/mobile home park owner shall submit within 60 days a park redesign plan required to be approved by the planning commission. This plan shall bring the park into compliance with article IV of this chapter. Failure to submit such a plan shall result in the immediate expiration of the park license. 
(Code 1988, § 16-65; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. II, § 3), 2-9-1987) 
Secs. 74-86-74-113. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MANUFACTURED/MOBILE HOME PARKS ESTABLISHED ON OR AFTER JANUARY 1, 1987 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 74-114-74-139. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MASTER PARK PLAN 

Sec. 74-140. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place, construct, expand or operate any manufactured/mobile home park within the city limits unless a plan for the park has been approved by the city planning commission. 
(Code 1988, § 16-91; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. III, § 1(A)(1)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-141. - Application, processing. 
(a)  The developer shall comply with all applicable requirements and regulations as stated in the city subdivision development ordinance. 
(b)  The developer/owner shall submit 20 copies of all other required items, including all fees, with the division manager of municipal development at least 17 working days prior to the date on which proper consideration is to be given by the planning commission. No incomplete application shall be accepted by the division manager of municipal development. 
(c)  The division manager of municipal development shall review the park plan as to its conformity with the comprehensive plan, major thoroughfare plan, the recorded plat and the standards and specifications set forth herein or referred to herein. 
(d)  The site review committee shall consider the park plan and shall convey its recommendations concerning the plan to the planning commission at the meeting for which such plan is scheduled for consideration. 
(e)  The division manager of municipal development shall present the park plan to the planning commission with his or her recommendations. He or she may also convey the comments and recommendations of the site review committee, the city division manager of engineering services engineer, or any other person or agency. 
(f)  The planning commission shall study the plan and all recommendations, taking into consideration the requirements of these regulations. Particular attention will be given to the arrangement, location and width of streets, their relation to the topography of the land, sewage disposal, drainage, lot sizes and arrangement, the further development of adjoining lands as yet unsubdivided and the requirements of other ordinances, policies and plans as adopted by the planning commission and the city. 
(g)  The planning commission will advise the applicant of the specific changes or additions it will require in the layout, and the character and extent of required improvements and reservations which it will require as a prerequisite to the approval of the plan. 
(Code 1988, § 16-92; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. III, § 1(A)(2)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-142. - Form and content. 
    The plan shall be drawn on sheets 24 inches wide and 36 inches long. It shall be drawn to a minimum scale of 100 feet to one inch. The plan shall also show the following: 
(1)  Name and address of the record owner; owner's representative, if applicable; and the project engineer or surveyor. 
(2)  Present name of the manufactured/mobile home park and any other names under which the park has been reviewed, if any. 
(3)  Manufactured/mobile home park boundary, indicated by heavy lines, and its computed acreage. 
(4)  Location, on the site and adjacent to the site, of all existing and proposed: 
a.  Buildings and structures. 
b.  Streets and other rights-of-way and easements. 
c.  Locations and sizes of utilities. 
d.  Street paving widths. 
e.  Curb return radii. 
f.  Parking areas. 
g.  Screening. 
(5)  Present tract designation. 
(6)  Description by metes and bounds of the perimeter of the manufactured/mobile home park and its location with respect to an original survey of which it is a part. 
(7)  Primary control points or descriptions and ties to such control points to which all dimensions, and angle bearings, lot numbers and similar data shall be referred. 
(8)  Exact location, dimensions, tract designation and name of existing and proposed residential lots, parks, public areas, and other sites within the manufactured/mobile home park. 
(9)  The location, dimensions and flow line of existing watercourses and drainage structures on the site or adjacent to it. 
(10)  Date of survey, scale and north arrow. 
(11)  Key map, drawn at a satisfactory scale to show the relationship of the property to adjacent existing streets and identifying features for a distance of at least one-half mile. 
(12)  Contour lines on a basis of five vertical feet in terrain with a slope of two percent or more, and on a basis of two vertical feet in terrain with a slope of less than two percent. Contours shall be based upon city datum. 
(13)  A number or letter to identify each lot, or site, and each block. 
(14)  Front building setback lines shown graphically on all lots and sites. Rear and side yard building lines shall be described either graphically or as a note on the plan. 
(15)  Location of city limit line and the outer border of the city's extraterritorial jurisdiction boundaries if they traverse the manufactured/mobile home park or form part of its boundary. 
(16)  Other conditions on the site, both physical and technical, when deemed necessary for complete review. 
(17)  Index sheet if site plan is drawn on more than one sheet showing the entire manufactured/mobile home park at a suitable scale. 
(Code 1988, § 16-93; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. III, § 1(A)(3)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-143. - Revision of plan after approval. 
    No changes, erasures, modifications or revisions shall be made in any plan of a manufactured/mobile home park after approval has been given by the planning commission, unless the changes, erasures, modifications or revisions are first submitted to and approved by the planning commission. 
(Code 1988, § 16-94; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. III, § 1(B)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-144. - Responsibilities of the park management. 
(a)  The person to whom a license for a manufactured/mobile home park is issued shall operate the park in compliance with this chapter and shall provide adequate supervision to maintain the park. 
(b)  The park management shall supervise the placement of each manufactured/mobile home on its manufactured/mobile home stand in accordance with this chapter. 
(c)  The park management shall maintain a register containing the names of all park occupants identified by lot number or street address. Such register shall be available to any herein authorized person inspecting the park. 
(Code 1988, § 16-95; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. III, § 1(C)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-145. - Responsibility of park occupant. 
(a)  The park occupant shall comply with all applicable requirements of this chapter and shall maintain his or her manufactured/mobile home lot, its facilities and equipment in good repair and in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(b)  The park occupant shall be responsible for proper placement of his or her manufactured/mobile home on its mobile home stand and proper installation of all utility connections in accordance with the instructions of the park management and city codes. 
(Code 1988, § 16-96; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. III, § 1(D)), 2-9-1987) 
Secs. 74-146-74-173. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - STANDARDS AND SPECIFICATIONS 

Sec. 74-174. - Screening. 
    All manufactured/mobile home parks shall be enclosed with an approved visual screening barrier not less than six feet in height, with no openings to adjoining property other than the boundaries adjacent to public streets. 
(Code 1988, § 16-111; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. III, § 2(A)(1)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-175. - Drainage. 
    Condition of solid, groundwater level, drainage and topography shall not create hazards to the property or the health or safety of the occupants. No portion of the site subject to unpredictable and/or sudden flooding, subsidence or erosion shall be used for any purpose which would expose persons or property to hazards. 
(Code 1988, § 16-112; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. III, § 2(A)(2)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-176. - Access, traffic circulation and parking access. 
(a)  Intersections. Interior park streets shall intersect adjoining public streets at approximately 90 degrees and at locations which will eliminate or minimize interference with traffic on those public streets. Access shall be in compliance with those standards set forth in the traffic-control ordinance and the major thoroughfare plan. 
(b)  Parking. All parking shall be off-street. Each lot shall be provided with two on-site parking spaces. Each space shall have minimum dimensions of nine feet width and 18 feet length. 
(c)  Guest parking. Guest parking shall be provided at a rate of one space for each four manufactured/mobile home lots. Guest parking shall be located such that no manufactured/mobile home is farther than 200 feet (walking distance) from guest parking. 
(d)  Street standards. Street standards shall be as set forth in the subdivision development ordinance. 
(Code 1988, § 16-113; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. III, § 2(A)(3)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-177. - Electrical power. 
(a)  Outlets (receptacles or pressure connectors) shall be housed in a weatherproof outlet box, and shall be located not more than 25 feet from the over current protective device in the manufactured/mobile home. A three-pole, four-wire grounding type shall be used. 
(b)  Receptacles, if provided, shall be in accordance with American Standards Outlet Receptacle C-73.1. 
(c)  Connectors, if not substituted by more than one receptacle, shall be provided where the calculated load of the manufactured/mobile home is more than 50 amperes. 
(d)  The manufactured/mobile home shall be connected to the outlet box by an approved type of flexible supply cord with a male attachment plug or with pressure connectors. 
(e)  All exposed noncurrent carrying metal parts of the manufactured/mobile home and all other equipment shall be grounded by means of an approved grounding conductor with branch circuit conductors or other approved method. 
(Code 1988, § 16-114; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. III, § 2(A)(4)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-178. - Required illumination. 
    Streetlights shall be installed and compensated for as set forth in the subdivision development ordinance. 
(Code 1988, § 16-115; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. III, § 2(A)(5)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-179. - Fire protection. 
    The manufactured/mobile home park shall be subject to the rules and ordinances of the city fire prevention authority and codes. 
(Code 1988, § 16-116; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. III, § 2(A)(6)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-180. - Nonresident activities. 
(a)  No part of any park shall be used for nonresidential purposes except such uses that are required for the direct servicing and well-being of park residents and for the management and maintenance of the park, except for recreation. 
(b)  Nothing contained in this section shall be deemed as prohibiting the sale of a manufactured/mobile home located on a manufactured/mobile home lot and connected to the pertinent utilities. 
(Code 1988, § 16-117; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. III, § 2(A)(7)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-181. - Sidewalks. 
    All parks shall be provided with all-season pedestrian access walks of adequate width for intended use, from the lots to the park streets and all community facilities provided for park residents. Sudden changes in alignment and gradient shall be avoided. 
(1)  Common walk system. A common walk system shall be provided and maintained between locations where pedestrian traffic is concentrated. Such common walks shall have a minimum width of two feet. 
(2)  Individual walks. All manufactured/mobile home lots shall be connected to common walks, to paved streets, or to paved driveways or parking spaces connecting to a paved street. Such individual walks shall have a minimum width of two feet. 
(Code 1988, § 16-118; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. III, § 2(A)(8)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-182. - Lot layout and stands. 
(a)  Space requirements. Each manufactured/mobile home lot shall contain a minimum area of 3,500 square feet. 
(b)  Density. The density of manufactured/mobile home parks shall not exceed ten manufactured/mobile home lots per acre. Density shall include the gross area of the individual tract of land. 
(c)  Setback requirements. 
(1)  Park boundary. Twenty-five feet from any park property line abutting upon a public street or highway. Ten feet from all other boundaries. 
(2)  Front. Fifteen feet from the park street to the unit (excludes the tongue). 
(3)  Rear. Ten feet. 
(4)  Side. Five feet. 
(5)  Accessory buildings. Accessory buildings shall be located so as to comply with the fire code. 
(d)  Skirting. Manufactured/mobile homes shall be skirted with suitable, weatherized material. 
(e)  Open space. 
(1)  If the park is farther from a community recreational facility than two miles, then not less than eight percent of the gross site area shall be devoted to recreational facilities. Recreation area may include space for community building and community use facilities such as indoor recreational areas, swimming pools, hobby and repair shops and service buildings. 
(2)  Where individual lot areas are substantially above minimum (6,000 square feet and more) and provide for sufficient outdoor recreation and open space (4,000 square feet and more), an exemption shall be granted to an extent that an absolute minimum of 100 square feet per lot be considered sufficient for the site of a centralized recreation area, provided that no recreation area shall contain less than 5,000 square feet or have a dimension of less than 50 feet. 
(3)  Recreation facilities generally shall be provided in a central location and be convenient to the project. In larger parks or subdivisions, however, recreation facilities can be decentralized. 
(Code 1988, § 16-119; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. III, § 2(B)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-183. - Solid waste. 
    The storage, collection and disposal of refuse in the manufactured/mobile home park shall be so conducted as to comply with the city laws. 
(Code 1988, § 16-120; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. III, § 2(C)(1)), 2-9-1987) 
Sec. 74-184. - Community facilities. 
    Community facilities for the residents of each park shall be provided. Facilities shall meet the expected indoor and outdoor leisure time needs and may include common laundry facilities and office space for management. Facilities, when provided, shall be safely accessible to all residents. Such structures shall meet all applicable city codes including those for building, utilities and occupancy. 
(Code 1988, § 16-121; Ord. No. 637, § 1(art. III, § 2(C)(2)), 2-9-1987) 
Chapter 78 - NATURAL RESOURCES[1]

No. 1883, § 2, adopted Sept. 14, 2010, repealed and replaced the former Ch. 78, §§ 78-19-78-28, 78-60-78-69, 78-97-78-102, 78-133-78-143, 78-170-78-180, and enacted a new Ch. 78 as set out herein. The former Ch. 78 pertained to similar subject matter. For complete derivation see the Code Comparative Table at the end of this volume. 

ARTICLE I. - OIL AND GAS WELLS 
DIVISION 1. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 78-1. - Purpose. 
    The exploration, development, and production of oil and gas in the city are activities that necessitate reasonable regulation to ensure that all property owners, mineral and otherwise, have the right to enjoy their property and its benefits and revenues. It is hereby declared to be the purpose of this article to establish reasonable and uniform limitations, safeguards, and regulations for present and future operations related to the exploring, drilling, developing, producing, transporting, and storing of oil and gas and other substances produced in association with oil and gas within the city's corporate limits; to protect the health, safety and general welfare of the public; minimize the potential impact to property and mineral rights owners, protect the quality of the environment and encourage the orderly production of available mineral, oil, and gas resources. 
(Ord. No. 1883, § 2, 9-14-2010) 
Sec. 78-2. - Definitions. 
    All technical industry words or phrases related to the drilling and production of oil and gas wells not specifically defined have the meanings customarily attributable thereto by prudent operators in the oil and gas industry. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article, have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Abandonment means "abandonment" as defined by the commission and includes the plugging of a well and the restoration of any well site as required by this article. 
    Ambient noise level means the all encompassing noise level associated with a given environment, being a composite of sounds from all sources at the location except for those sources related to oil and gas drilling, production, and compression, constituting the normal or existing level of environment noise at a given location. 
    Base flood means the flood having a one percent chance of being equaled or exceeding in any given year as defined by FEMA, commonly referred to as the 100-year flood. 
    Blowout preventer means a mechanical, hydraulic, pneumatic, or other device or combination of such devices secured to the top of a well casing, including valves, fittings, and control mechanisms connected therewith, which can be closed around the drill pipe or other tubular goods which completely close the top of the casing and are designed to prevent blowouts. 
    Building or habitable building means any structure used or intended for supporting or sheltering any use or occupancy. The term "building" will be construed as if followed by the words "or portions thereof." 
    Cathodic protection means an electrochemical corrosion control technique accomplished by applying a direct current to the structure that causes the structure potential to change from the corrosion potential to a protective potential in the immunity region. The required cathodic protection current is supplied by sacrificial anode materials or by an impressed current system. 
    Closed loop mud system means a system utilized while drilling so that reserve pits are not used and instead steel bins are used to collect all drilling waste. 
    Commission means the Texas Railroad Commission. 
    Completion of drilling, re-drilling, and re-working means the date the work is completed for the drilling, re-drilling, or re-working and the crew is released by completing its work or contract or by its employer. 
    Daytime means the timeframe between 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. 
    Derrick means any portable framework, tower, mast, or structure which is required or used in connection with drilling or re-working a well for the production of oil or gas. 
    Drilling means digging or boring a new well for the purpose of exploring for, developing or producing oil or gas or other hydrocarbons, or for the purpose of injecting gas, water, or other fluid or substance into the earth. 
    Drilling equipment means the derrick, together with all parts of an apparatus, machinery or equipment used or erected or maintained for use in connection with drilling. 
    Drill site means the premises used during the drilling or re-working of a well or wells located there and subsequent life of a well or wells or any associated operation. 
    Emergency response plan means a plan that describes procedures to minimize any hazard resulting from drilling, completion or producing of oil or gas wells. 
    Exploration means geological or geophysical activities, excluding seismic surveys, related to the search for oil, gas, or other subsurface hydrocarbons related to a specific operation site or oil well. 
    Fee means an administrative charge assessed by the city and set by city council resolution. 
    Fire department means the City of Bryan Fire Department. 
    Floodplain means any land area susceptible to a general and temporary condition of partial or complete base flood inundation or normally dry land areas from overflow of inland waters or from the unusual and rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters from any source. 
    Frac or fracturing means the process of fracture stimulation of a rock formation. 
    Gas means any fluid, either combustible or noncombustible, which is produced in a natural state from the earth and which maintains a gaseous or rarefied state at standard temperature and pressure conditions and the gaseous components or vapors occurring in or derived from petroleum or natural gas. 
    Gas well means any well drilled, to be drilled, or used for the intended or actual production of natural gas. 
    Inspector means the oil and gas inspector designated by the city manager. 
    Nighttime means the timeframe between 7:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
    Noise management plan means a plan that describes in detail how the equipment used in the drilling, completion, transportation, or production of a well complies with the maximum permissible noise levels of this article. 
    Oil means any liquid hydrocarbons, regardless of gravity, capable of being produced from any well in liquid form at the well by ordinary production methods. 
    Oil well means any well drilled, to be drilled, or used for the intended or actual production of oil. 
    Operation site means the area used for development and production and all operational activities associated with oil and gas after drilling activities are complete. 
    Operator means, for each well, the person listed on the commission Form W-1 or Form P-4 for an oil and gas well that is, or will be, actually in charge and in control of drilling, maintaining, operating, or pumping any well, including, without limitation, a unit operator. If the operator is not the lessee under an oil and gas lease of any premises affected by the provisions of this article, then such lessee will also be deemed to be an operator. If there is no oil and gas lease relating to any premises affected by this article, the owner of the fee mineral estate in the premises will be deemed an operator. 
    Permit means the written license required by the city for any proposed well. 
    Practicable means available and capable of being done after taking into consideration existing technology, cost, and logistics in light of the overall purpose of the activity. 
    Protected use means a habitable building, including but not limited to a residence, retail building, office, warehouse, religious institution, public building, hospital building, or school. Structures such as equipment buildings, pump houses and agricultural barns that are occupied on a daily basis for less than four hours each day are not considered protected uses. All public parks are considered to be protected uses. 
    Public building means all buildings used or designed or intended to be used for the purpose of assembly of persons for such purposes of deliberation, entertainment, amusement, or health care. 
    Public park means any land area dedicated to or maintained by the city for traditional park-like recreational purposes, but does not include trails or publicly-owned golf-courses. 
    Re-drill means re-completion of an existing well by deepening or side-track operations extending more than 150 feet from the existing wellbore. 
    Religious institution means any building in which persons regularly assemble for religious worship and activities intended primarily for purposes connected with such worship or for propagating a particular form of religious belief. 
    Residence means a house, duplex, apartment, townhouse, condominium, dormitory or mobile home designed or used for residential purposes, including those for which a building permit has been issued on the date the application for an oil or gas well permit is filed with the oil and gas inspector. 
    Re-working means re-completion or re-entry of an existing well within the existing borehole or by deepening or sidetrack operations which do not extend more than 150 feet from the existing wellbore, or replacement of well liners or casings. 
    School means any public or private, primary or secondary educational facility providing education up through and including the twelfth grade level and any day care centers licensed by the State of Texas that provides care, training, education, custody, treatment or supervision for more than six children less than 14 years of age, and for less than 24 hours a day. 
    Seismic survey means the geologic or geophysical activities necessary to determine the potential location of subterranean mineral deposits within the city using vibroseis equipment. 
    Street means any street, highway, sidewalk, alley, avenue, recessed parking area, or other public right-of-way, including the entire right-of-way. 
    Tank means a container, covered or uncovered, used in conjunction with the drilling or production of oil and gas or other hydrocarbons for holding or storing fluids. 
    Technical advisor means such person(s) familiar with and educated in the oil and gas industry or the law as it relates to oil and gas matters that may be retained from time to time by the city. 
    Transfer means a change in operator of an oil or gas well. 
    Well means a hole or holes, bore or bores, to any horizon, formation, or strata used for the purpose of producing oil, gas, or liquid hydrocarbon, or used as an injection well for secondary recovery, disposal or production of oil, gas, or other hydrocarbons from the earth. 
(Ord. No. 1883, § 2, 9-14-2010; Ord. No. 2035, § 1, 2-25-2014) 
Sec. 78-3. - Oil and gas inspector. 
(a)  The city manager will designate an oil and gas inspector who will enforce the provisions of this article. The oil and gas inspector has the authority to issue any orders or directives required to carry out the intent and purpose of this article and its particular provisions. Failure of any person to comply with any such order or directive constitutes a violation of this article. 
(b)  The oil and gas inspector has the authority to enter and inspect any premises covered by the provisions of this article to determine compliance with the provisions of this article and all applicable laws, rules, regulations, standards, or directives of the state.
