(d)  The oil and gas board of appeals may reverse or affirm, in whole or part or modify the oil and gas inspector's order, requirement, decision or determination from which an appeal is taken and make the correct order, requirement, decision or determination. Any action under this subsection, including the issuance of any variance authorized by this article requires a three-fourths vote of the entire oil and gas board of appeals. 
(e)  Appeal fees are required for every appeal and will be assessed per well. 
(f)  Any person or entity aggrieved by the decision of the oil and gas board of appeals may present to a court of record a petition, duly verified, setting forth that the decision is illegal, in whole or part, and specifying the grounds of illegality. The petition must be presented within ten days after the date on which the decision of the oil and gas board of appeals was rendered. Judicial review will be pursuant to V.C.T.A. Local Government Code § 211.011, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 1883, § 2, 9-14-2010) 
Secs. 78-42-78-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - PENALTY 

Sec. 78-46. - Penalty. 
(a)  It is unlawful to: 
(1)  Engage in any activity not permitted by the terms of an oil or gas well permit issued under this article; 
(2)  Fail to comply with any condition set forth in an oil or gas well permit issued under this article; or 
(3)  Violate any provision or requirement set forth under this article. 
(b)  Any violation of this article is punishable by a fine of not more than $500.00 per violation per day, subject to applicable state law. Each day that a violation exists constitutes a separate offense. 
(c)  Any violation of this article that governs fire safety, public health, or sanitation is punished by a fine not exceeding $2,000.00 per violation per day, subject to applicable state law. Each day that a violation exists constitutes a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 1883, § 2, 9-14-2010) 
Secs. 78-47-78-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SEISMIC TESTING 

Sec. 78-50. - Seismic survey permit. 
(a)  A permit shall be required for all seismic surveys performed on any property, public or private, within the city. 
(b)  To obtain a permit, the operator must submit an application to the city, must pay the application fee as established by resolution of the city council, and execute a license agreement on a form approved by the city attorney. The city manager or his/her designee is authorized to enter into a license agreement on behalf of the city. 
(c)  The term of the permit shall be for a period of one year. 
(d)  It is a violation of this ordinance to conduct a seismic survey in the city without a valid, existing permit and license agreement with the city. 
(Ord. No. 2035, § 4, 2-25-2014) 
Sec. 78-51. - Permit application. 
    The application for a permit will require the following information to be provided by the operator: 
(a)  Name and address of the operator. If the operator is a corporation, the state of incorporation. If the operator is a limited partnership, the name and address of the general partner(s). 
(b)  Name, address, telephone number, and email address of two individuals who will be the 24-hour emergency contact for the city. 
(c)  Name, address, telephone number, and email address of a point of contact for members of the public and/or media. 
(d)  Seismic project route plan sheets on 24x36 tax maps that identify all utilities, streets, properties, the route to be taken by the vibroseis equipment, the location of source points, and the location of receiver points. 
(e)  Traffic control plan in compliance with the Texas Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices. 
(f)  A video showing the condition of the roads to be used by the vibroseis equipment of sufficient quality to show any existing damage or flaws. 
(g)  A list of the type, weight, and specifications of the vibroseis equipment and/or vehicles to be used in the seismic survey. 
(h)  A certificate of insurance evidencing the insurance required under the license agreement which names the city as an additional insured. 
(i)  A security instrument that secures the operator's obligations to repair any damage caused by the seismic survey to city streets, sidewalks, rights-of-way, easements, water/sewer infrastructure, or other public property or infrastructure. 
(Ord. No. 2035, § 4, 2-25-2014) 
Sec. 78-52. - Violations. 
(a)  It is a violation of this ordinance to conduct surveys: 
(1)  Using pentolite, dynamite, or any other type of explosive; 
(2)  That exceed the particle velocity or frequency allowed pursuant to the license agreement; 
(3)  Using public streets, sidewalks, or drainage ditches for receiver points and/or using other public property for receiver points without permission from the city; or 
(4)  In violation of any of the terms or conditions of the license agreement. 
(b)  This ordinance may be enforced by appropriate civil court action in accordance with state or federal law, including, but not limited to, seeking an injunction pursuant to Tex. Loc. Gov't. Code Ann. Chapter 54. This is in addition to any other remedies at law or in equity available to the city pursuant to agreements, insurance policies, or security provided as required by this ordinance. 
(c)  Any person violating the provisions of this ordinance shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine not exceeding $2,000.00 for each offense. Each day, or part thereof, that the violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2035, § 4, 2-25-2014) 
Secs. 78-53-78-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LEASES OF OIL, GAS, AND MINERAL INTERESTS OWNED BY THE CITY 
DIVISION 1. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 78-56. - Authority of the city manager. 
    The city manager is authorized to execute on behalf of the City of Bryan leases of oil, gas, and mineral interests owned by the city that meet the criteria, standard terms, and are on the lease agreement form approved and adopted by resolution of the Bryan City Council, without further city council action. The city manager is authorized to execute such other ancillary documents as may be necessary or convenient for the execution of said lease agreement, provided, however, that said other documents are in a form approved by the city attorney or the city attorney's designee. 
(Ord. No. 2027, § 4, 1-28-2014) 
Chapter 82 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 82-1. - Crime prevention rewards. 
    The city manager may, from time-to-time upon recommendation of the chief of police, establish and publicize a reward in an amount not to exceed $1,000.00 for information leading to the arrest and final conviction of any person who, within the city, commits a felony offense of burglary, capital murder, murder, robbery or rape as defined in the state penal code. This reward shall not be available to peace officers, private security personnel or the victims of the crime. 
(Code 1975, § 17-11; Code 1988, § 17-1) 
Sec. 82-2. - Leaving wells open. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any well, cistern, or other excavation to be or remain open or uncovered to the danger of others, on any premises owned, controlled, or occupied by him. 
(Code 1975, § 17-4; Code 1988, § 17-2) 
Sec. 82-3. - Injuries, etc., to public property generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to destroy, injure, cut, chip, break, deface, or cover or rub with, or otherwise place filth or excrement of any kind upon any public property in the city or on any public building, statue, monument, office, dwelling, drinking fountain or structure of any kind whatsoever, whether existing or in course of erection, or on the doors, windows, steps, railing, fencing, balconies, balustrades, walls or sides, or the walls of any enclosure thereof, or to write, mark, draw, or paint any word or sign or figure thereon. 
(Code 1975, § 17-8; Code 1988, § 17-3) 
Sec. 82-4. - Trespassing on city property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to trespass upon, enter into or upon any of the property owned or controlled by the city without the consent of some authorized officer, agent or employee of the city; provided, the word "property," as herein used, shall not be construed to mean any public highway, street, park, or public place in the city. 
(Code 1975, § 17-10; Code 1988, § 17-4) 
Sec. 82-5. - Unlawful discharge of firearms, etc. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for a person to discharge within the city any firearm, airgun, BB gun, toy gun, crossbow, or bow and arrow, projecting lead or any missiles with the following exceptions: 
(1)  The discharge of a firearm, crossbow, or bow and arrow in a regularly established and properly supervised shooting range or gallery operating under a permit from the city; 
(2)  The discharge of a firearm by an officer of the law in the performance of his or her duty; 
(3)  The discharge of a firearm, airgun, BB gun, toy gun, crossbow, or bow and arrow by a citizen when lawfully defending person or property; or 
(4)  The discharge of an airgun, BB gun, toy gun, crossbow, or bow and arrow by a citizen on his or her own property, provided such device is not fired into or onto another person's property. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, a "firearm" means any device designed, made, or adapted to expel a projectile through a barrel by using the energy generated by an explosion or burning substance or any device readily convertible to that use. 
(Code 1975, § 17-12; Code 1988, § 17-5) 
Sec. 82-6. - Certain objects prohibited during participation in demonstrations, assemblies, etc. 
(a)  No person shall carry or possess while participating in any demonstration, rally, picket line or public assembly, any strip of wood, stick, board, shaft, mast, pole, stave, rod, plank, pipe, stud, cane, staff, stake, slat or similar object unless that object conforms to the following specifications: 
(1)  All objects which are not generally rectangular in shape shall not exceed one-fourth inch in thickness and two inches in width. 
(2)  All objects which are not generally rectangular in shape shall not exceed three-quarters inch in their thickest dimension. 
(3)  All objects must be constructed of wood, wood products, or other cellulose materials. 
(b)  The fact that an object forms a component part of a sign or placard does not exempt it from coverage under this section. 
(c)  It is an affirmative defense to prosecution under this section that the object is used as an ambulatory aid and that the actor has a valid medical need for such aid. 
(Code 1988, § 17-7; Ord. No. 1121, §§ 1-3, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 1344, § 2, 3-12-2002) 
Sec. 82-7. - Curfew hours for juveniles. 
(a)  Definitions. In this section: 
    Chief of police means the Chief of Police of the City of Bryan or a designated representative. 
    Curfew hours means the time between 12:00 midnight until 5:00 a.m. on any day of the week. 
    Direct route means the shortest path of public travel to reach a final destination without any detour or stop along the way. 
    Emergency means, but is not limited to, a fire, a natural disaster, an automobile accident, or any situation requiring immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury, loss of life or damage to or loss of property. 
    Establishment means any privately-owned place of business operated for a profit to which the public is invited, including but not limited to any place of amusement or entertainment. 
    Holding location means a place designated by the chief of police to which a juvenile taken into custody for a violation of this section will be delivered to await pickup by a parent, responsible adult or juvenile authorities. 
    Juvenile means any person under 17 years of age. 
    Operator means any individual, firm, association, partnership, corporation or other form of entity or association, including the owners, members, managers, partners, officers, agents and employees thereof as applicable, operating, managing, or conducting any establishment. 
    Parent means a person who is: 
(1)  A natural or adoptive parent or step-parent of another person; 
(2)  A court-appointed guardian to have the care and custody of another person; or 
(3)  At least 21 years of age and authorized by a parent or court-appointed guardian to have the care and custody of another person. 
    Public place means any street, alley, highway, sidewalk, playground, park, plaza, building, or other place used by or open to the public. 
    Remain means to: 
(1)  Linger or stay; or 
(2)  Fail to leave premises when requested to do so by a police officer or the owner, operator or other person in control of the premises. 
(b)  Offenses. 
(1)  A juvenile commits an offense if he or she remains in any public place or on the premises of any establishment within the city during curfew hours or fails to return home by a direct route from such public place or establishment after being asked to leave by a police officer or the owner, operator or other person in control of the premises. 
(2)  A parent of a juvenile commits an offense if he or she knowingly permits, or by insufficient control allows, the juvenile to remain in any public place or on the premises of any establishment within the city during curfew hours. 
(3)  The owner or operator of an establishment commits an offense if he or she knowingly allows a juvenile to remain upon the premises of the establishment during curfew hours. 
(c)  Defenses. 
(1)  It is a defense to prosecution under subsection (b)(1), (b)(2), or (b)(3) of this section that the juvenile was: 
a.  Accompanied by the juvenile's parent; 
b.  On an errand at the direction of the juvenile's parent and was using a direct route; 
c.  In a motor vehicle or mode of transportation involved in interstate travel; 
d.  Engaged in an employment activity, including but not limited to newspaper delivery, and was using a direct route; 
e.  Involved in an emergency; 
f.  On the sidewalk abutting the juvenile's residence; 
g.  Attending an activity supervised by adults and sponsored by a school, governmental entity, church, civic or charitable organization or similar entity that takes responsibility for the juvenile with the consent of the juvenile's parent or going to or returning home by a direct route from any such activity; 
h.  Engaged in, participating in, or traveling to or from any event, function or activity to which the application of subsection (b)(1) of this section would contravene the juvenile's First Amendment rights protected by the United States Constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech, and the right of assembly; or 
i.  Married or had been married or had disabilities of minority removed in accordance with Chapter 31 of the Texas Family Code. 
(2)  It is a defense to prosecution under subsection (b)(3) of this section that the owner or operator of an establishment, or any employee or agent thereof, promptly notified the police department that a juvenile was present on the premises of the establishment during curfew hours and refused to leave. 
(d)  Enforcement. 
(1)  A police officer, upon finding a juvenile in violation of subsection (b)(1) of this section, shall: 
a.  Ascertain the name and address of the juvenile; and 
b.  Order the juvenile to go promptly home by a direct route. 
(2)  Notwithstanding subsection (d)(1) of this section, a police officer, upon finding a juvenile in violation of subsection (b)(1) of this section, may: 
a.  Issue the juvenile a citation for the offense and deliver the juvenile to a parent; or 
b.  Take the juvenile into custody and deliver the juvenile to a holding location if: 
1.  A parent to whom custody of the juvenile may be released cannot be located; or 
2.  Reasonable grounds exist to believe the juvenile has engaged in delinquent conduct or conduct indicating a need for supervision in accordance with Sections 51.03 and 52.01 of the Texas Family Code. 
(3)  If a parent cannot be located or fails to take charge of the juvenile, the juvenile shall be released to the appropriate juvenile authorities or responsible adult. 
(4)  A police officer finding any violations of any provisions of this section shall file a written report on the incident if a citation is issued. 
(e)  Penalties. 
(1)  A person who violates a provision of this section is guilty of a separate offense for each day or part of a day during which the violation is committed, continued, or permitted. Each offense, upon conviction, is punishable as follows: 
a.  First offense: a fine not to exceed $100.00; 
b.  Second offense: a fine not to exceed $250.00; 
c.  Third and subsequent offenses: a fine not to exceed $500.00. 
(2)  The municipal court, in its discretion, may order a defendant who is unable to pay all or part of a fine or costs, to discharge all or part of such fine or costs by performing community service. 
(3)  When required by Section 51.08 of the Texas Family Code, as amended, the municipal court shall waive original jurisdiction over a minor who violates subsection (b)(1) of this section and shall refer the juvenile to juvenile court. 
(f)  In accordance with Section 370.002 of the Local Government Code, this section must be reviewed and adopted every three years. At a minimum, the city shall: 
(1)  Review the effects on the community and on problems the ordinance or order was intended to remedy; 
(2)  Conduct public hearings on the need to continue the ordinance or order; and 
(3)  Abolish, continue, or modify the ordinance or order. 
(g)  In accordance with Section 370.002 of the Local Government Code, section 82-7 of the Bryan City Code expires if the city does not review and adopt it every three years. In the event Section 370.002 of the Local Government Code is revoked or amended, the city is required to review and adopt the ordinance every three years. 
(Ord. No. 1563, § 1(§ 17-8), 12-13-2005; Ord. No. 1680, § 1, 4-24-2007; Ord. No. 1865, § 1, 4-27-2010; Ord. No. 1988, § 1, 4-23-2013) 
Sec. 82-8. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
    Camp means using a public street or other public place for one or more of the following activities: erecting tents or any structure providing shelter, laying down bedding for the purpose of sleeping, storing personal belongings, starting a fire, cooking or preparing meals, or living in a parked vehicle. 
    Public parks includes all city parks, playgrounds and dedicated parkland. 
    Public place includes public plazas, transportation facilities, schools, attractions, monuments, and any improved or unimproved public area. 
    Public street includes all public streets and highways, public sidewalks, public benches and public parking lots. 
    Storing personal belongings shall include the leaving of personal effects, such as, but not limited to, clothing, bedrolls, cookware, sleeping bags, luggage, knapsacks, or backpacks, unattended for the purpose of storage. The term shall not include the lawful parking of a bicycle, motor vehicle or other mode of transportation. 
(Ord. No. 1632, § 1, 11-14-2006) 
Sec. 82-9. - Prohibited acts. 
    Camping in any public place or street is prohibited, with the exception of the authorized use of public parks and Lake Bryan during normal operational hours. Camping after hours at all public parks and at Lake Bryan is prohibited, except as authorized by permit. 
(Ord. No. 1632, § 1, 11-14-2006) 
Sec. 82-10. - Penalty. 
    Any person convicted of a violation of any provision of this subsection shall be guilty of a Class C misdemeanor punishable by a fine not to exceed $2,000.00 per occurrence in accordance with section 1-14. 
(Ord. No. 1632, § 1, 11-14-2006) 
Sec. 82-11. - Aggressive solicitation prohibited. 
(a)  The council finds that: 
(1)  Aggressive solicitation is disturbing and disruptive to residents and businesses and contributes to the loss of access to and enjoyment of public places and to a sense of fear, intimidation and disorder. 
(2)  Aggressive solicitation includes approaching or following pedestrians, repetitive soliciting despite refusals, the use of abusive or profane language to cause fear and intimidation, unwanted physical contact, or the intentional blocking of pedestrian and vehicular traffic. 
(3)  The presence of individuals who solicit money from persons at or near banks, automated teller machines, check cashing businesses, public transportation stops and facilities, self serve car washes, self service fuel pumps, exterior public pay telephone and crosswalks is especially troublesome because of the enhanced fear of crime in a place that is confined, difficult to avoid, or where a person might find it necessary to wait. 
(4)  This section is intended to protect citizens from the fear and intimidation accompanying certain kinds of solicitation, and not to limit a constitutionally protected activity. 
(b)  Definitions. 
(1)  Aggressive manner means: 
a.  Intentionally or recklessly making any physical contact with or touching another person in the course of the solicitation without the person's consent; 
b.  Following the person being solicited, if that conduct is: 
(i)  Intended to or likely to cause a reasonable person to fear imminent bodily harm or the commission of a criminal act upon property in the person's possession; or 
(ii)  Intended to or reasonably likely to intimidate the person being solicited into responding affirmatively to the solicitation; 
c.  Continuing to solicit a person within five feet of the person being solicited after the person has made a negative response; 
d.  Intentionally or recklessly blocking the safe or free passage of the person being solicited or requiring the person, or the driver of a vehicle, to take evasive action to avoid physical contact with the person making the solicitation; 
e.  Using obscene or abusive language or gestures toward the person being solicited; 
f.  Approaching the person being solicited in a manner that: 
(i)  Is intended to or is likely to cause a reasonable person to fear imminent bodily harm or the commission of a criminal act upon property in the person's possession; or 
(ii)  Is intended to or is reasonably likely to intimidate the person being solicited into responding affirmatively to the solicitation. 
(2)  Automated teller machine means a device, linked to a bank's account records, which is able to carry out banking transactions. 
(3)  Automated teller facility means the area comprised of one or more automatic teller machines, and any adjacent space that is made available to banking customers. 
(4)  Bank includes a bank, savings bank, savings and loan association, credit union, trust company, or similar financial institution. 
(5)  Bus means a vehicle operated by a transit authority for public transportation. 
(6)  Check cashing business means a person in the business of cashing checks, drafts, or money orders for consideration. 
(7)  Exterior public pay telephone means any coin or credit card reader telephone that is: 
a.  Installed or located anywhere on a premises except exclusively in the interior of a building located on the premises; and 
b.  Accessible and available for use by members of the general public. 
(8)  Public area means an outdoor area to which the public has access and includes, but is not limited to, a sidewalk, street, highway, park, parking lot, alleyway, pedestrian way, or the common area of a school, hospital, apartment house, office building, transport facility, or shop. 
(9)  Public transportation facility means a facility or designated location that is owned, operated, or maintained by a city, transportation authority, public transportation benefit area, regional transit authority or metropolitan municipal corporation within the state. 
(10)  Public transportation stop means an area officially designated as a place to wait for a bus, or any other public transportation vehicle that is operated on a scheduled route with passengers paying fares on an individual basis. 
(11)  Self-service car wash means a structure: 
a.  At which a vehicle may be manually washed or vacuumed by its owner or operator with equipment that is activated by the deposit of money in a coin-operated machine, and 
b.  That is accessible and available for use by members of the general public. 
(12)  Self-service fuel pump means a fuel pump: 
a.  From which a vehicle may be manually filled with gasoline or other fuel directly by its owner or operator, with or without the aid of an employee or attendant of the premises at which the fuel pump is located; and 
b.  That is accessible and available for use by members of the general public. 
(13)  Solicit means to request, by the spoken, written, or printed word, or by other means of communication an immediate donation or transfer of money or another thing of value from another person, regardless of the solicitor's purpose or intended use of the money or other thing of value, and regardless of whether consideration is offered. 
(c)  A person commits an offense if the person solicits: 
(1)  In an aggressive manner in a public area; 
(2)  In a bus, at a public transportation facility or public transportation stop, or at a facility operated by a transportation authority for passengers; 
(3)  Within 25 feet of: 
a.  An automated teller facility; 
b.  The entrance or exit of a bank; 
c.  The entrance or exit of a check cashing business; 
d.  A self service carwash or self service fuel pump; 
(4)  At a marked crosswalk. 
(5)  At a sidewalk café authorized under chapter 62-243 (Sidewalk Cafés) or the patio area of a bar or restaurant. 
(d)  A culpable mental state is not required, and need not be proven, for an offense under subsection (c)(2), (3), (4), or (5). 
(e)  During a permitted street closure event or a permitted city sponsored special event, it shall not be an offense under subsection (c)(3) and (4) for persons registered with the permittee to solicit in such locations when authorized and so defined in the approved street closure or special event permit. 
(f)  This section is not intended to proscribe a demand for payment for services rendered or goods delivered. 
(g)  A violation of this article shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 1812, § 2, 5-26-2009) 
Sec. 82-12. - Illegal smoking products and related paraphernalia prohibited. 
(a)  The council finds that: 
(1)  Local businesses within the city are selling to the general public products containing synthetic cannabinoids, salvia divinorum, or related chemicals that when ingested produce intoxicating effects similar to marijuana. 
(2)  These products are being sold, distributed, and marketed in the form of incense or herbal smoking blends under names such as "Dascents", "Fire N Ice", "Genie", "K-2", "K-2 Sex", "K-2 Summit", "K O Knock-Out 2", "Pep Spice", "Sage", "Salvia Divinorum", "Solar Flare", "Spice", "Spice Cannabinoid", "Spice Diamond", "Spice Gold", "Yucatan Fire", and "Zohai". 
(3)  The National Drug Intelligence Center of the United States Department of Justice issued an immediate alert to law enforcement and public health officials of potential substance abuse problems and harmful side effects related to the use of these synthetic cannabinoid products in EWS Report 000006 dated May 18, 2010. 
(4)  The use of these products is a danger to the public health, safety, and welfare because the adverse side effects from the use of synthetic cannabinoids, salvia divinorum, or related chemicals include panic attacks, vomiting, tachycardia, elevated blood pressure, pallor, numbness and tingling, and in some cases, tremors and seizures. 
(5)  The federal government and the State of Texas have not yet designated synthetic cannabinoids, salvia divinorum, or related chemicals as controlled substances. 
(6)  In order to promote the public health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of this city, products containing synthetic cannabinoids, salvia divinorum, or related chemicals and paraphernalia should be prohibited in the City of Bryan. 
(b)  Definitions. In this section: 
(1)  Illegal smoking paraphernalia means any equipment, product, material or object used or intended for use in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing an illegal smoking product into the human body, including: 
a.  Metal, wooden, acrylic, glass, stone, plastic, or ceramic pipe with or without a screen, permanent screen, hashish head, or punctured metal bowl; 
b.  A water pipe; 
c.  A carburetion tube or device; 
d.  A smoking or carburetion mask; 
e.  A chamber pipe; 
f.  A carburetor pipe; 
g.  An electric pipe; 
h.  An air-driven pipe; 
i.  A chillum; 
j.  A bong; or 
k.  An ice pipe or chiller. 
(2)  Illegal smoking product means any plant or other substance, whether described as tobacco, herbs, incense, spice or any blend thereof, including any of the marketed names of illegal smoking products; regardless of whether the substance is marketed for the purpose of being smoked, which includes any one or more of the following substances or chemicals: 
a.  Salvia divinorum or salvinorin A; all parts of the plant presently classified botanically as salvia divinorum, whether growing or not, the seeds thereof, any extract from any part of such plant, and every compound, manufacture, salts, derivative, mixture or preparation of such plant, its seeds or extracts; 
b.  2-[(1R,3S)-3-hydroxycyclohexyl]-5-(2-methyloctan-2-yl)phenol (also known as CP47,497) and homologues; 
c.  (6aS,10aS)-9-(hydroxymethyl)-6,6-dimethyl-3-(2-methyloctan-2-yl)-6a,7,10,10a-tetrahydrobenzo[c]chromen-1-ol (also known as HU-211 or Dexanabinol); 
d.  1-pentyl-3-(1-naphthoyl)indole (also known as JWH-018); 
e.  1-butyl-3-(1-naphthoyl)indole (also known as JWH-073); or 
f.  1-pentyl-3-(4-methoxynaphthoyl)indole (also known as JWH-081). 
(3)  Marketed names of illegal smoking products means the following commercial names in which some or all of the illegal smoking products are being marketed under: 
a.  "Dascents", "Fire N Ice", "Genie", "K-2", "K-2 Sex", "K-2 Summit", "K O Knock-Out 2", "Pep Spice", "Sage", "Salvia Divinorum", "Solar Flare", "Spice", "Spice Cannabinoid", "Spice Diamond", "Spice Gold", "Yucatan Fire", and "Zohai". 
(4)  Person means an individual, corporation, retailer, wholesaler, partnership, association, or any other legal entity. 
(c)  Offenses. 
(1)  A person commits an offense if he uses, possesses, buys, sells, offers for sale, barters, gives, publicly displays, delivers, or transfers any illegal smoking product. 
(2)  A person commits an offense if he uses, inhales, ingests, or otherwise introduces into the human body any illegal smoking product. 
(3)  A person commits an offense if he uses or possesses any illegal smoking paraphernalia with the intent to inject, inhale, ingest, or otherwise introduce into the human body any illegal smoking product. 
(4)  Any product containing any of the chemical compounds set forth above shall be subject to the provisions of this section, regardless of whether the product is marketed under names other than those listed above. 
(d)  Defenses. 
(1)  It is a defense to prosecution under this section that an illegal smoking product or illegal smoking paraphernalia was: 
a.  In the possession of a peace officer, or a person acting under the authority of a peace officer, acting in the performance of official duties; 
b.  In the possession of or being used by a governmental entity for a health, research, education, or similar program; 
c.  In the possession of or used by a person under a prescription issued by a licensed physician or dentist authorized to prescribe controlled substances in the State of Texas. 
(e)  Penalty. 
(1)  A person who violates a provision of this section is guilty of a separate offense for each day or part of a day during which the violation is committed, continued, or permitted. Each offense, upon conviction, is punishable by a fine not to exceed $2,000.00. 
(Ord. No. 1882, § 1, 9-7-2010) 
Secs. 82-13-82-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ABANDONED OR UNCLAIMED PERSONAL PROPERTY[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Abandoned motor vehicles, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code ch. 683. 

Sec. 82-31. - Disposition of abandoned or unclaimed property. 
    All unclaimed or abandoned personal property of every kind, other than property that is regulated by state law, contraband subject to forfeiture, motor vehicles, whiskey, wine, beer, firearms and prohibited weapons, seized by any peace officer of this city which is not held as evidence to be used in any pending case and has not been ordered destroyed or returned to the person entitled to possession of the same by a magistrate, which shall remain unclaimed for a period of 30 days shall be delivered for sale to the purchasing agent of the city. 
(Code 1988, § 17-75; Ord. No. 865, § 1, 4-13-1993) 
Sec. 82-32. - Notice to owner. 
    The purchasing agent of the city shall mail a notice to the known address of the owner of such property by certified mail. Such notice shall describe the property being held, and shall give the name of the purchasing agent and the address where such property is being held, and shall state that if the owner does not claim such property within 60 days from the date of the notice such property will be sold and the proceeds of such sale, after deducting the reasonable expense of keeping such property and costs of the sale, will be placed in the general funds of the city. 
(Code 1988, § 17-76; Ord. No. 865, § 1, 4-13-1993) 
Sec. 82-33. - Notice to unknown owners. 
    If the owner of such property is unknown or if the address of the owner is unknown, then the purchasing agent shall cause to be published once, in a paper of general circulation in the county, a notice describing the property being held, the name of the owner, if known, the name and address of the purchasing agent, and a statement that if the owner of such property does not claim the property within 60 days from the date of the publication, the property will be sold and the proceeds of such sale, after deducting the reasonable expense of keeping the property and the costs of the sale, will be placed in the general funds of the city. 
(Code 1988, § 17-77; Ord. No. 865, § 1, 4-13-1993) 
Sec. 82-34. - Notice of sale. 
    The sale of any property hereunder shall be preceded by a notice published once at least three weeks prior to the date of sale, in a newspaper of general circulation in the county, stating the description of the property, the names of the owners, if known, and the date and place that such sale will occur. If the purchasing agent shall consider any bid as insufficient, he or she need not sell such property, but may decline such bid and reoffer such property for resale. 
(Code 1988, § 17-78; Ord. No. 865, § 1, 4-13-1993) 
Sec. 82-35. - Claim by owners. 
    The real owners of any property sold shall have the right to file a claim for the proceeds of such sale with the city. If the claim is allowed by the city, it shall pay the owner such monies as were deposited into the general funds of the city. 
(Code 1988, § 17-79; Ord. No. 865, § 1, 4-13-1993) 
Sec. 82-36. - Disposition of perishable property or goods. 
    Any and all perishable property or goods which deteriorate rapidly in value and utility which come into the possession of the city police department during the course and scope of said department's duties shall be disposed of by said department as follows: The police department shall make a good faith effort to identify, locate and give personal notice to the lawful owner of such property. In the event the police department is unable to determine in a timely manner the lawful owner of such property, such department shall dispose of such property in a commercially reasonable manner, or, if necessary, shall dispose of same in a sanitary fashion consistent with applicable health statutes or ordinances. 
(Code 1988, § 17-80; Ord. No. 865, § 1, 4-13-1993) 
Chapter 86 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Parks and playgrounds, § 16(w). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 86-1. - Definition. 
    The term "city park" when used in this chapter, shall be held to mean and include all that land and facilities owned by the city and used for the following purposes: playground, sports, fishing, picnicking, golf, baseball, football, swimming, boating, and other park and recreation type activities. Lake Bryan is not a "city park" under this definition; it is separately owned and operated by the city electric utilities system. 
(Code 1975, § 18-1; Code 1988, § 19-1; Ord. No. 1223, § 1, 4-25-2000; Ord. No. 1304, § 1, 9-11-2001) 
Sec. 86-2. - City parks to be identified. 
    A sign will be erected at all city parks as herein defined, for the purpose of giving notice to the general public that it is a city park. 
(Code 1975, § 18-2; Code 1988, § 19-2) 
Sec. 86-3. - Sue Haswell Memorial Park. 
    Special recognition is given the park known and designated as Sue Haswell Memorial Park for the reason that this particular park was donated to the city by one of its outstanding citizens, Honorable Tyler Haswell, in memory of his mother, Mrs. Sue Haswell. The special stipulation in connection with the operation, care and maintenance of the Sue Haswell Memorial Park is as follows: That no private concessions or privileges of any character whatsoever shall ever be granted in or to such premises or the park thereon, but the same shall at all times be used solely and exclusively as a public park and place of recreation for the public, and particularly for the inhabitants of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 18-3; Code 1988, § 19-3) 
Secs. 86-4-86-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARK REGULATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 86-25-86-51. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - USE OF CITY PARKS AND RECREATION AREAS 

Sec. 86-52. - City parks not to be rented for profit. 
    No agent, servant, or employee of the city having supervision over or jurisdiction over any city parks may rent or allow the use of any park to any person engaged in an enterprise for a profit, except as otherwise provided herein or as expressly permitted by city council. 
(Code 1975, § 18-4; Code 1988, § 19-31) 
Sec. 86-53. - Use by local civic, religious and charitable organizations. 
    Section 86-52 shall not apply to local civic, religious, and charitable organizations. Such organizations shall make application to the operations manager of community services to be approved by the city manager, setting forth in the application the name of the organization and its officers, the purpose for which the city park is desired to be used, the length of time, and a detailed statement showing what the revenue derived from the use of the city park will be used for. Local civic, religious and charitable organizations shall be deemed to mean such organizations now functioning under the head of a slate of local citizens as officers. The city manager is given the authority to require a full showing, by documentary evidence in the application, that any such organization is local in nature and comes under the above classification as the organizations are generally regarded. 
(Code 1975, § 18-5; Code 1988, § 19-32) 
Sec. 86-54. - Concessions in city parks. 
    No person shall have the right to offer for sale or barter, exhibit anything or conduct any place of amusement where a fee is charged within city parks without first obtaining the consent of the parks and recreation director or his or her designee, or his or her authorized agent, paying for such privilege or concession the sum agreed upon with the director, his or her designee, or his or her agent. The right to sell, barter, exhibit, or conduct any amusement will be limited to two days per month, unless authorized by the parks and recreation division manager or his or her designee. 
(Code 1975, § 18-6; Code 1988, § 19-33; Ord. No. 1223, § 2, 4-25-2000) 
Sec. 86-55. - Reservations for pavilions. 
    Reservations must be approved by the city manager or his or her designee and the fees to be charged for the use of the pavilions and shelters shall be set by resolution of the city council and are on file in the city secretary's office. 
(Code 1975, § 18-7; Code 1988, § 19-34; Ord. No. 596, § 2, 12-9-1985) 
Sec. 86-56. - Picnic facilities. 
    Unless otherwise provided herein, picnic facilities are available on a first-come first-served basis. 
(Code 1975, § 18-9; Code 1988, § 19-35) 
Sec. 86-57. - Ballpark facilities. 
    Reservations must be approved by written permit for all ballpark facilities. This permit may be obtained at the parks and recreation administration offices. 
(Code 1975, § 18-10; Code 1988, § 19-36; Ord. No. 1223, § 3, 4-25-2000) 
Sec. 86-58. - Fees for park and recreation activities. 
    Fees for all park and recreation activities shall be set by resolution of the city council and are on file in the city secretary's office. 
(Code 1975, § 18-12; Code 1988, § 19-37; Ord. No. 596, § 3, 12-9-1985) 
Sec. 86-59. - Restricted areas and curfew; penalty. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided herein, all parks and recreation areas shall be closed to the public between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. each day. Except for designated camping areas and exempt events, it shall be unlawful for any person to enter or remain in any park or recreation area during the hours the park or recreation area is closed. 
(b)  The parks and recreation department shall place in each of the municipal parks legible signs stating the hours when the park is closed. At least two signs shall be placed in each park and recreation area, and in parks and recreation areas that have vehicular entrances there shall be a sign at each entrance. 
(c)  The city manager, or his or her designee, may grant permission for civic or educational meetings or entertainments to be held in a park or recreation area at any designated hour and this section shall not apply to persons who are in the park or recreation area in accordance with the terms of such permission. This section shall not apply to the following persons if in the park or recreation area in the performance of their duties: peace officers, physicians, ambulance operators or attendants, employees of the city, and employees of the public utility companies. 
(d)  In the case of parks and recreation areas through which there are dedicated streets used for general travel (that is, not merely for access to the interior of the park or recreation area) this section shall not apply to persons traveling through the park or recreation area on such dedicated streets. 
(e)  It shall also be unlawful for any person to enter or remain in a park or recreation area which has been designated as restricted or is closed for the season. The parks and recreation department shall place in each of the so designated places legible signs stating the fact of their closure. At least two signs shall be placed in each area. 
(Code 1988, § 19-38; Ord. No. 615, § 1, 5-5-1986; Ord. No. 1364, § 1, 8-27-2002) 
Sec. 86-60. - Glass beverage containers prohibited. 
(a)  The following definitions shall apply to the provisions of this section: 
    Exceptions and exclusions, notwithstanding any other provisions of this section, shall mean that nothing in this section shall prohibit the possession of the following glass containers in park and recreation areas: 
(1)  Glass-lined vacuum bottles and glass-lined picnic beverage coolers; and 
(2)  Baby bottles or baby food jars containing products for consumption by a baby. 
    Glass beverage containers shall mean any glass receptacle which meets one or more of the following criteria: 
(1)  Has at some point in time contained a beverage; 
(2)  Currently contains a beverage; 
(3)  Was created for the purpose of containing a beverage. 
    Park or recreation areas shall mean a parcel of land, or water, or land and water which is used for park and/or recreational purposes which is under the administrative control of the parks and recreation division. For the purposes of this section, park or recreation areas shall include but not be limited to the following: Astin Recreational Area, Austin's Colony Park, Bonham Park, Bryan Aquatic Center, Bryan High School tennis courts, Bryan Regional Athletic Complex, Camelot Park, Castle Heights Park, Copperfield Park, Coulter Park, Crescent Park, Garden Acres Park, Sue Haswell Park, Henderson Park, Heritage Park, Lions Recreational Area, Jane Long Park, Municipal Golf Course, Sam Rayburn Park, San Jacinto Park, Scurry Park, Tanglewood Park, Sadie Thomas Park, Tiffany Park, Travis Park, Villa West Park, Washington Park, Neal Park, and Williamson Park. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for anyone to use, dump, exhibit, carry, possess or unlawfully dispose of a glass beverage container in a park or recreation area. 
(c)  A person who violates any part of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction is punishable in accordance with section 1-14. 
(Code 1988, § 19-39; Ord. No. 788, §§ 1, 5, 1-28-1991; Ord. No. 1223, § 4, 4-25-2000; Ord. No. 1304, § 2, 9-11-2001) 
Secs. 86-61-86-78. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - TRAFFIC 

Sec. 86-79. - Applicability. 
    The provisions set forth under this division are applicable to all city parks and recreation areas. 
(Code 1975, § 18-21; Code 1988, § 19-51; Ord. No. 866, § 1, 4-13-1993; Ord. No. 1223, § 5, 4-25-2000; Ord. No. 1304, § 3, 9-11-2001) 
Sec. 86-80. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Light truck shall mean any truck with a manufacturer's rated carrying capacity not to exceed 2,000 pounds and is intended to include those trucks commonly known as pickup trucks, panel delivery trucks and carryall trucks. 
    Motor vehicle shall mean every vehicle which is self-propelled. 
    Motorcycle shall mean every motor vehicle having a saddle for the use of the rider and designed to travel on not more than three wheels in contact with the ground, but excluding a tractor. 
    Overnight camping means using a city park for one or more of the following activities after the close of park hours: erecting tents or any structure providing shelter, laying down bedding for the purpose of sleeping, storing personal belongings, starting a fire, cooking or preparing meals after the close of park hours. 
    Passenger car shall mean every motor vehicle, except motorcycles and motor-driven cycles, designed for carrying ten passengers or less and used for the transportation of persons. 
    Vehicle shall mean every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a street or highway, and every such device which is or may be operated off of a street or highway for sport or recreational purposes. 
(Code 1975, § 18-22; Code 1988, § 19-52; Ord. No. 1632, § 3, 11-14-2006) 
Sec. 86-81. - Vehicle use in city parks restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any motor vehicle to be operated within a city park except on paved or unpaved roadways and paved or unpaved parking areas designated and intended for vehicle use. This restriction shall not apply to equipment and vehicles used to perform maintenance or construction on any city parkland, and city approved catering vehicles. 
(Code 1975, § 18-23; Code 1988, § 19-53) 
Sec. 86-82. - Riding of animals in city parks. 
    It shall be unlawful for the rider of any animal to ride such animal in any city park, except in certain areas which may be designated by the director of the parks and recreation department. This prohibition shall not apply to the riding of horses by law enforcement officers while on duty patrolling city park areas. 
(Code 1975, § 18-24; Code 1988, § 19-54; Ord. No. 965, § 1, 8-22-1995) 
Sec. 86-83. - Parking prohibited in city parks except in designated areas. 
    No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle, except in compliance with directions of a police officer in any city park except in areas so designated by appropriate markers for parking. 
(Code 1975, § 18-25; Code 1988, § 19-55) 
Sec. 86-84. - Authorization. 
    The director of the parks and recreation department is hereby authorized to designate certain areas in city parks for parking as he or she deems necessary. 
(Code 1975, § 18-26; Code 1988, § 19-56; Ord. No. 965, § 2, 8-22-1995) 
Sec. 86-85. - Violations of motor vehicle and traffic laws in city parks prohibited. 
    All motor vehicle and traffic laws which apply on public streets and highways shall also apply in city parks. 
(Code 1975, § 18-27; Code 1988, § 19-57) 
Secs. 86-86-86-113. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - RESTRICTIONS IN PARKS 

Sec. 86-114. - Applicability. 
    The provisions set forth under this division are applicable to all city parks and recreation areas. 
(Code 1975, § 18-31; Code 1988, § 19-71; Ord. No. 866, § 2, 4-13-1993; Ord. No. 1304, § 4, 9-11-2001) 
Sec. 86-115. - Alcoholic beverages and public intoxication in city parks. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to bring into, possess or consume any alcoholic or malt beverages on or in any public park, or loiter in an intoxicated condition in such park located within the city limits. 
(b)  Upon application to the city manager, or his or her duly authorized representative, any person may obtain a use permit to bring in, possess and consume alcoholic or malt beverages on or in the areas described in subsection (a) of this section. All use permit fees, deposits or bonds shall be set by resolution of the city council and are on file in the city secretary's office. 
(c)  A person who violates any subsection of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction is punishable by a fine not exceeding $500.00 per occurrence in accordance with section 1-14. 
(Code 1975, § 18-32; Code 1988, § 19-72; Ord. No. 1045, § 1, 5-13-1997) 
Sec. 86-116. - Overnight camping prohibited. 
    Overnight camping is prohibited in all city parks, except for registered participants in camping special events sponsored by the parks and recreation department and permitted, and then only as authorized by the permit, in areas designated or marked for that purpose. 
(Code 1975, § 18-33; Code 1988, § 19-73; Ord. No. 1304, § 5, 9-11-2001; Ord. No. 1632, § 4, 11-14-2006) 
Sec. 86-117. - Pets. 
    It shall be unlawful for anyone who owns a pet or has a pet under their control to permit such pet to be in any city park unless restricted by a leash. Owner must dispose of any pet excrements in an appropriate container. 
(Code 1975, § 18-34; Code 1988, § 19-74; Ord. No. 1223, § 6, 4-25-2000) 
Sec. 86-118. - Park property. 
    It shall be unlawful to intentionally, knowingly or recklessly damage, mark, deface, disfigure, injure, cut, tamper with, displace or remove any park property owned by the city including, but not limited to, ball fields, buildings, playground equipment, restrooms and water facilities, trees, landscaping, paving, utility installations, signs, grounds, or other structures. 
(Code 1975, § 18-35; Code 1988, § 19-75) 
Sec. 86-119. - Hunting. 
(a)  No person shall hunt in any city park. The carrying of firearms, air rifles, bows (unless posted otherwise), slingshots, or other weapons of any type in a city park and the lands adjacent owned by the city is expressly prohibited. 
(b)  Exceptions to subsection (a) of this section are: 
(1)  Law enforcement officers who are engaged in the lawful discharge of their duties. 
(2)  Those persons who are duly licensed by the state to carry a concealed handgun, may carry a concealed handgun in accordance with the provisions of V.T.C.A., Government Code § 411.171 et seq., commonly referred to as the Texas Concealed Weapons Act. 
(c)  For purposes of this section, "concealed handgun" means any handgun, the presence of which is not openly discernable to the ordinary observation of a reasonable person. 
(Code 1975, § 18-36; Code 1988, § 19-76; Ord. No. 984, § 1, 2-13-1996; Ord. No. 1223, § 7, 4-25-2000; Ord. No. 1304, § 6, 9-11-2001) 
Sec. 86-120. - Water pollution and park littering. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in any city park to, at any time, throw or otherwise discharge any liquid, gaseous, and/or solid waste substance into the water or upon the grounds of any city park. 
(Code 1975, § 18-37; Code 1988, § 19-77) 
Sec. 86-121. - Smoking in parks. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke tobacco products in any city park, except as otherwise permitted at a municipal golf course. 
(b)  The words "smoke" or "smoking" when used in this section shall have the same definition as the city's smoking ordinance, section 50-147, as may be amended. 
(Ord. No. 2262 , § 1, 2-27-2018) 
Secs. 86-122-86-138. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - LAKE BRYAN 

Sec. 86-139. - Secondary use. 
    Lake Bryan utilizes land and lakes which were primarily purchased and constructed for the construction and operation of electric power generation and distribution facilities, and Lake Bryan as a public use facility is a secondary and incidental use which is always subject to present or future use by electric power facilities. 
(Code 1975, § 18-65; Code 1988, § 19-91; Ord. No. 1223, § 8, 4-25-2000) 
Sec. 86-140. - Hunting. 
    It shall be unlawful to hunt at Lake Bryan. 
(Code 1988, § 19-92; Ord. No. 1304, § 7, 9-11-2001) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1304, § 7, adopted Sept. 11, 2001 amended the former § 19-92 and enacted a new § 19-92 as set out herein. The former § 19-92 pertained to authority of lake officer and derived from Ord. No. 634, § 1, adopted Dec. 8, 1986; Ord. No. 823, § 1, adopted Apr. 14, 1992; Ord. No. 910, § 1, adopted May 24, 1994. 
Sec. 86-141. - Prohibition against illegal entry. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to enter Lake Bryan except by the designated entrance which is off Sandy Point Road. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, unless authorized by plant security personnel, to enter into any area of the power plant, which is restricted by sign, buoy, fence, or other restrictive devices. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to enter Lake Bryan unless that person has first obtained an appropriate permit. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to enter Lake Bryan unless that person has paid a required entry fee. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for a person under the age of 16 to enter Lake Bryan unless accompanied by an adult. 
(Code 1975, § 18-56; Code 1988, § 19-93; Ord. No. 823, § 2, 4-14-1992; Ord. No. 1223, § 9, 4-25-2000) 
Sec. 86-142. - Boating. 
    It shall be unlawful to violate the following restrictions: 
(1)  All boats shall observe "no wake zone" areas as designed by buoys or other posted signs. Sailboats shall be excepted from this subsection. 
(2)  All children under 13 years of age riding in a boat must, at all times, wear a U.S. Coast Guard approved flotation device; and all boat operators must, at all times, observe and comply with the provisions of the Texas Water Safety Act. 
(3)  Boats operating at night must have and exhibit all lights as required by the Texas Water Safety Act (V.T.C.A., Parks and Wildlife Code ch. 31). 
(4)  Sailboats must comply with the Texas Water Safety Act. 
(5)  Sailing, boating, personal watercraft, and swimming will not be permitted inside buoys marking power plant intakes. 
(6)  Any boat considered to be "overloaded" by lake personnel and/or Texas Parks and Wildlife employees will not be permitted in the lake. 
(7)  All applicable provisions of the Texas Parks and Wildlife Code, and the U.S. Coast Guard Inland Rules pertaining to boating, and water safety shall apply to all waters of Lake Bryan. 
(8)  Operation of personal watercraft must comply with the Texas Water Safety Act. 
(Code 1988, § 19-94; Ord. No. 1304, § 8, 9-11-2001) 
Sec. 86-143. - Fishing. 
    It shall be unlawful to violate the following restrictions: 
(1)  Use of trot lines, seines, traps, snag lines, or any other device for taking or attempting to take fish is prohibited, except for state or federal park and wildlife agencies who may use nets and seines for conducting studies of fish life. 
(2)  Fishing is prohibited beyond marked areas near the power plant intake and discharge. These areas are hazardous because of swift waters with danger of being swept into underground pipes. 
(Code 1988, § 19-95; Ord. No. 1304, § 9, 9-11-2001) 
Sec. 86-144. - Fireworks. 
(a)  The possession, storage, offer for sale, exposure for sale, sale at retail, use, or discharge of any fireworks, as defined by the currently adopted edition of the International Fire Code/International Code Council, is hereby deemed unlawful. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to supervised public displays of fireworks, provided that a permit for such fireworks display has been obtained from the fire chief or his or her designated representative. 
(Code 1988, § 19-96; Ord. No. 964, § 2, 8-22-1995; Ord. No. 1304, § 10, 9-11-2001) 
Secs. 86-145-86-171. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RECREATION AREAS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 86-172-86-197. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1632, § 2, adopted Nov. 14, 2006, deleted § 86-172, which pertained to camping in the city and derived from Code 1975, § 17-3; Code 1988, § 19-116. 
DIVISION 2. - MUNICIPAL LAKE 

Sec. 86-198. - Boating. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any boat on Municipal Lake except with written permission of the city manager or his or her designee. 
(Code 1975, § 18-51; Code 1988, § 19-131) 
Sec. 86-199. - Swimming. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to swim in Municipal Lake. 
(Code 1975, § 18-52; Code 1988, § 19-132)
